"Following virtue" means following the virtue of Heaven naturally, proceeding without effort, like one climbing a small hill—all who have feet reach the top, yet others assume they arrived through diligence. This is a metaphor for acting without contrivance. "Hill" refers to a small mountain.

Thus, their liking is one, their disliking is one. Their oneness is one, their not-oneness is one. Those who are one follow Heaven as their companion; those who are not one follow man as their companion. Heaven and man do not overcome one another—this is called the true person. "One" means naturalness, the workings of creation. "Liking and disliking" refer to preferences. Their oneness is sameness, their not-oneness is difference. The sameness and difference of preferences do not extend beyond creation, hence "their oneness is one, their not-oneness is one." If one can regard preferences as the same, they know Heaven. Thus, "those who are one follow Heaven as their companion." If one regards preferences as different, they know man but not Heaven. Thus, "those who are not one follow man as their companion." Man cannot overcome Heaven, nor can Heaven overcome man. The true person has no preferences, no differences, no sameness, no division between Heaven and man—only following nature.

This is what the Buddhists call "abandoning both existence and nonexistence," what Laozi calls "both returning to the mysterious." Thus, "Heaven and man do not overcome one another"—this means that both oneness and not-oneness are one. "One" is the great master.

Life and death are fate, possessing the constancy of night and day—this is Heaven. What man cannot intervene in is the nature of things. They regard Heaven as their father and cherish it, yet how much more should they cherish what is loftier? They regard having a lord as better than themselves and die for it, yet how much more should they cherish what is true? Life and death are like day and night, as the *Yijing* says: "Understanding the Dao of day and night." "Nature" means reality. What human effort cannot influence is the true principle of Heaven and Earth, of the myriad things—this is called fate, called Heaven. These lines elucidate the meaning of life and death as Heaven’s mandate, clarifying the idea of oneness and not-oneness.

Father and lord are the most revered and beloved in the human world, yet the greatness of the Dao surpasses even lord and father, hence it is said to be "the father of all fathers." Thus, "there is a true lord within." "Lofty" means high, unattainable. "True" means natural. These words imply that people know lords and fathers but do not know the Dao as the great master.

When springs dry up, fish find themselves on land, moistening one another with breath, wetting one another with foam—better to forget one another in rivers and lakes. Rather than praising Yao and condemning Jie, it is better to forget both and be transformed by the Dao. The great clod burdens me with form, labors me with life, eases me with old age, and rests me with death. Thus, those who are good to my life are also good to my death.

"Moistening one another with breath, wetting one another with foam" means facing one another and sharing moisture. Being on land and wetting one another is not as good as forgetting one another in rivers and lakes—this metaphor means that acting in the world is not as good as embodying the Dao and practicing non-action. The line praising Yao and condemning Jie may seem absurd, but it reveals a unique insight. Without Jie, there is no Yao; without decline, no rise; without good, no evil; without slander, no praise. Praise and slander, rise and decline, good and evil all arise in mutual dependence. Rather than distinguishing between them, it is better to forget both and entrust them to nature—entrusting to nature is being transformed by the Dao.

The Buddhists say: "All dharmas are equal, without high or low." They also say: "Abandon both existence and nonexistence." And: "The great Dao is not difficult, only disliking discrimination." All these express the same idea.

Two clay oxen fight and plunge into the sea—no news of them to this day. This line is most excellent.

The great clod is heaven and earth. Only after form arises does life come to be; once born, one cannot be without toil. When old age comes and sinews and strength wane, one naturally finds repose. "Repose" means cessation. To "cherish our life" is to preserve our body whole. This is what is meant by "Hear the Dao in the morning, and in the evening death may come."

Hiding a boat in a ravine, concealing a mountain in a marsh—this is called secure. Yet in the dead of night, a strong man may carry them away, and the deluded do not know it. Even when concealing the small within the great is done fittingly, there is still escape. But to hide the world within the world is to leave no room for escape—this is the great truth of all things.

People delight in possessing human form, yet if one has human form, the myriad transformations have no end. How can their joy be measured? Thus the sage wanders where things cannot be pursued yet all abide.

To master early death, to master old age, to master beginnings, to master endings—even men emulate this, let alone that on which the myriad things depend and by which all transformations are sustained.

The boat in the ravine, the mountain in the marsh—these may be called securely hidden, yet at times they are lost. "In the dead of night, a strong man" refers to the workings of creation. "Carrying them away" is loss. It means that even when human plans are most deeply laid, there are times when one cannot act freely—this is like "forging iron to make a doorstep, where even ghosts clap their hands in laughter." The "deluded" are those who do not know.

"Small and great" refer to the boat and ravine, the mountain and marsh. A ravine large enough can hide a boat; a marsh large enough can hide a mountain—concealing the small within the great is fitting. Yet "escape" means loss. To hide the world within the world is to entrust it to nature. All that lies beneath heaven is entrusted to heaven, leaving no room for escape. This is the true and constant nature of all things.

People rejoice in having form, yet do not know that the human body undergoes a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations—how can one know where it will end? If one could know this, then the myriad things would all be complete within me, heaven and earth would be one with me, and how could their joy be measured?

The sage’s mind wanders in the natural, so there is no gain, no loss. Thus it is said: "He wanders where things cannot be pursued yet all abide."

To master early death, to master old age, to master beginnings, to master endings—this is the work of creation. "Master" means "to be able." If even creation can do this, men emulate it—how much more so the Dao, on which the myriad things depend and by which all transformations are sustained. This is what is meant by the "Great Master."

Each passage rises higher than the last—this is the style of Zhuangzi’s brush. The words of sages and worthies, by contrast, are plain and unadorned.

The Dao has essence and trustworthiness, is without action and without form. It can be transmitted but not received, attained but not seen. It is self-originating, self-rooted; before heaven and earth existed, it was already firmly established. It spiritually animates ghosts and gods, gives birth to heaven and earth. It stands before the Supreme Ultimate yet is not high; it lies beneath the six directions yet is not deep. It preceded the birth of heaven and earth yet is not ancient; it is older than high antiquity yet is not aged.

The earlier passage did not mention the word "Dao," but here it is finally introduced to speak of the Great Master.

"Essence" means reality; "trustworthiness" also means reality. "Without action" means there is no place to begin. "Without form" means it has no shape or bounds. "Can be transmitted but not received, attained but not seen"—these two lines are known only to those who understand the Dao. Guan Yinzi has a chapter that elucidates the meaning of "transmission" most aptly.

"Self-originating, self-rooted" means tracing back to its origin. Tracing the origin of this Dao, we find that before heaven and earth existed, the Dao was already present—this is what is meant by "the Supreme Ultimate without yet being the Ultimate."

"Ghosts" are the traces of creation; "Emperor" is like the "Emperor" in the *Yi* who emerges from the east. That ghosts and emperors can be spiritually potent is due to this Dao. Even heaven and earth exist only because of the Dao—thus it is said to "give birth to heaven and earth." The *Yi* says: "The Supreme Ultimate gives birth to the Two Modes"—this is the same idea.

The four lines—"not high," "not deep," "not ancient," "not aged"—are expressed with utmost clarity.

The "six directions" are the six directions of space.

When Fu Xi obtained it, he harnessed the mother of qi. The Northern Dipper obtained it and has never erred since time immemorial; the sun and moon obtained it and have never ceased since time immemorial. Kan Pei obtained it and thereby possessed Kunlun. Feng Yi obtained it and thereby roamed the great rivers. Jian Wu obtained it and thereby dwelt in the great mountains. The Yellow Emperor obtained it and thereby ascended to the cloudy heavens. Zhuan Xu obtained it and thereby dwelt in the Dark Palace. Yu Qiang obtained it and stood at the North Pole. The Queen Mother of the West obtained it and sat in the Lesser Expanse—none knew her beginning, none knew her end. Peng Zu obtained it and lived from the time of Youyu down to the Five Hegemons. Fu Yue obtained it and thereby assisted Wu Ding, ruling over all under heaven. He rode the eastern cord and mounted the tail of the Winnowing Basket, becoming equal to the ranks of the stars.

From Fu Xi onward, there are thirteen instances of "obtained"—all speak of obtaining this Dao and thereby achieving such things.

Fu Xi was an ancient emperor-king. "Harnessing the mother of qi" means harmonizing yin and yang within oneself—this is the origin of the practices of those who cultivate refinement. Kan Pei is a mountain spirit. "Possessing Kunlun" means having Kunlun. Feng Yi is a water spirit. Jian Wu is the spirit of Mount Tai. The Yellow Emperor’s ascent to the cloudy heavens refers to the affair at Mount Dinghu. The Dark Palace is like the present-day Pure True Realm. Yu Qiang is the spirit of the north. The Lesser Expanse is the dwelling of immortals.

The phrase "entering without knowing beginning or end" shares the same meaning despite variations in sentence length—this is a matter of literary technique. Among these thirteen sentences, the sun, moon, and Dipper are interspersed, and Peng Zu and Fu Yue are cited as later evidence. Such stylistic liberties transcend conventional rules; one cannot judge this by the standards of the sages’ writings but must regard it with a different perspective.

Nanbo Zikui asked Nü’ou, “You are advanced in years, yet your complexion is like that of a child—how is this so?”
“I have heard the Dao,” she replied.
Nanbo Zikui said, “May I study it?”
“Alas, how could that be? You are not the right person. Now, Bu Liangyi possesses the talent of a sage but not the Dao of a sage, while I possess the Dao of a sage but not the talent of a sage. I wished to teach him, hoping he might truly become a sage. Otherwise, conveying the Dao of a sage to one with the talent of a sage would be easy. I still guarded and instructed him: after three days, he was able to put the world outside himself. Once he had put the world outside, I guarded him again, and after seven days, he was able to put things outside himself. Once he had put things outside, I guarded him again, and after nine days, he was able to put life outside himself. Once he had put life outside, he could then attain morning clarity. With morning clarity, he could then perceive the solitary. Perceiving the solitary, he could then transcend past and present. Transcending past and present, he could then enter the state of neither death nor life. That which kills life does not die; that which gives life does not live. As a thing, it sends off all without exception, welcomes all without exception, destroys all without exception, and completes all without exception—its name is *yingning*. *Yingning* is that which is completed only after disturbance.

Nanbo Zikui said, “From whom did you alone hear this?”
She replied, “I heard it from the son of *Fumo*; the son of *Fumo* heard it from the grandson of *Luosong*; the grandson of *Luosong* heard it from *Zhanming*; *Zhanming* heard it from *Niexu*; *Niexu* heard it from *Xuyi*; *Xuyi* heard it from *Wou*; *Wou* heard it from *Xuanming*; *Xuanming* heard it from *Canliao*; *Canliao* heard it from *Yishi*.”

Zikui and Ziqi are both allegorical figures. To be advanced in years yet possess the complexion of a child—this is the teaching of present-day refinement cultivators. The distinction between “the talent of a sage” and “the Dao of a sage” is exceptionally well put; none but Zhuangzi could have said it, for no one before him had. Only those who possess both Dao and talent—aside from the Five Emperors and Three Kings—are Yi Yin, the Duke of Zhou, and Confucius. The three, seven, and nine days need not be rigidly parsed; they merely signify one stage surpassing the next. “Putting life outside” means forgetting one’s own body. “Morning clarity” is the luminous state of the mind, like the sky at dawn, suffused with limpid qi. “Perceiving the solitary” means seeing for oneself what others cannot. Transcending past and present means transcending life and death. Here, “killing life” is said to be “not dying,” and “giving life” is said to be “not living”—this is a common flourish in Zhuangzi’s writing. It means that though one may kill, it is not death; though one may give life, it is not life. “Sending off” means escorting; without welcoming or sending off, without completion or destruction, it is simply the natural course. *Ying* means disturbance; though buffeted by turmoil and chaos, that which is constant remains undisturbed. *Ning* means stillness. Only after disturbance does one perceive this stillness—hence *yingning*. *Yingning* is the name that arises from disturbance.

The nine instances of “heard” are truly extraordinary. *Fumo* refers to writing. Words are first spoken, then recorded on bamboo and silk—hence *fumo* (supplementary ink). Speech is the rectification of form; writing is the ink’s supplement. *Luosong* means reciting by heart. One reads with the text before them and recites from memory, like a son begetting a grandson—hence the use of “son” and “grandson” below. *Zhan* means to see; seeing clearly is called *Zhanming*. *Nie* is the same as *nie* (to whisper); to affirm oneself in speech is called *Niexu*. *Yi* means to employ; *xu* means to await. One may await the right moment to act—hence *Xuyi*. *Wou* means to chant when words are insufficient; *yu* expresses admiration, signifying the joy of self-attainment. All these phrases suggest that the Dao is attained through reading, inventing many names along the way—an astonishing feat, yet ultimately ascribed to the workings of creation. *Xuanming* is the beginning of qi; *Canliao* is the beginning of the nameless; *Yishi* is the beginning before the beginning—what is called “having a beginning” is also “having a beginning before the beginning,” and “having a beginning before the beginning before the beginning.” This implies that though the Dao may be obtained through writing, it is in truth inherent in our nature.

*Southern Florescence True Scripture: Oral Exegesis*, Scroll Eight (concluded)
---
*Southern Florescence True Scripture: Oral Exegesis*, Scroll Nine
By Lin Xi of Yuanzhai

Within the "Great Master" chapter of the Inner Chapters, Zisi, Ziyu, Zili, and Zilai spoke among themselves, saying: "Who can take non-action as the head, life as the spine, and death as the tailbone? Who understands that death, life, existence, and extinction are of one body? Such a one I would befriend." The four looked at one another and smiled, their hearts in perfect accord, and so they became friends.

Soon after, Ziyu fell ill. Zisi went to visit him and said: "How mighty is the Creator! To make me like this—so crooked and bent!" His back was hunched, his spine curved, and five organs protruded from his upper body. His chin was sunken into his navel, his shoulders towered above his head, and his neck-growths pointed to the sky. The qi of yin and yang had fallen into disorder, yet his heart remained untroubled. He limped to a well and gazed at his reflection, saying: "Alas! The Creator has again made me like this—so crooked and bent!"

Zisi asked: "Do you resent this?"
He replied: "No. Why should I resent it? If, little by little, the Creator transforms my left arm into a rooster, I will use it to crow at dawn. If, little by little, my right arm becomes a crossbow, I will use it to hunt owls for roasting. If, little by little, my tailbone turns into a wheel and my spirit into a horse, I will mount it—why would I need another steed? Moreover, what comes to me is timely, and what leaves me is in accord with the natural order. To be at peace with the times and dwell in accord with the natural order is to keep sorrow and joy from entering the heart—this is what the ancients called 'suspended release.' Yet those who cannot release themselves are bound by things. Furthermore, things have never triumphed over Heaven for long—why should I resent anything?"

The head, spine, and tailbone signify only the beginning and end in sequence. "Nothingness" refers to existence arising from non-existence, and after existence comes life and death. "No resistance in the heart" means the heart naturally awakens, harmonizing and aligning with all. How grand is the Creator—this speaks of the vastness of transformation. "Bound and constrained" describes the state of illness. "Hunched" depicts a bent body. "Back carbuncle" is an ulcer. The "five orifices" are where ulcers emerge. The chin sinks to the navel, the shoulders rise above the crown—all portray the form of a diseased body. "Knotted bun" refers to a topknot. "Pointing to heaven" means the crown is exposed. When the yin and yang qi of the body fall out of harmony, illness arises—hence it is said, "there is disorder." Yet his heart remains untroubled, unburdened by his affliction. "Hobbling" describes the manner of being propped up and dragged along. Gazing at his reflection in the well, he sighs: "It is the Creator who has made me thus bound and constrained." "Do you resent it?"—this is Zi Si’s playful question. "Suppose" means "if." "Little by little" means "gradually." This passage is most extraordinary, and the phrase "little by little suppose" alone is strikingly unique. It suggests that if the Creator were to gradually transform my body into other things, I would simply make use of them—this embodies the idea of following the transformations of nature without preference or aversion. Though presented as a parable, it holds its own truth. "What comes is timely, what departs is in accord"—this echoes the earlier words: "Your arrival was timely; your departure is in accord." It also speaks to the principle of life and death. "Suspended release" means the heart is free from attachment. If one becomes entangled with things, one cannot free oneself—hence it is said, "those who cannot release themselves are bound by things." How could the myriad things ever long triumph over Heaven? All of this expresses contentment with the natural order, and the natural order of Heaven is the great master. Le Xuan once remarked that the thirty-two chapters of *Zhuangzi* revolve around the two words "nature" and "spontaneity."

Presently, Zi Lai fell ill, gasping as if near death, his wife and children gathered around weeping. Li went to visit him and shouted: "Away! Stand back. Do not startle the one undergoing transformation." Leaning against the doorframe, he spoke to him: "How grand is the Creator! What will it make of you next? Where will it send you? Will it make you into a mouse’s liver? Or an insect’s limb?" Zi Lai replied: "For a child, parents may send them east or west, north or south, and one follows their command. Heaven and Earth are to man no less than parents. If they approach my death and I refuse to heed them, I would be obstinate. What fault is theirs? The great earth burdens me with form, labors me with life, eases me with old age, and rests me with death. Thus, to treat my life well is to treat my death well. Now, if a great smith were casting metal and the metal leapt up, saying, 'I must become a *Mo Ye* sword!' the smith would surely deem it ill-omened metal. Yet when one assumes human form and declares, 'I am a man! I am a man!' the Creator must surely deem them an ill-omened person. Now, if we take Heaven and Earth as a great furnace and the Creator as a great smith, where could one go and not be at ease?" Then he fell into a peaceful sleep and awoke refreshed.

When Master Zeng changed his mat, his words were as such—this is the learning of sages and worthies. Zhuangzi’s discourse here is that of a heroic spirit. "Shout" is the sound of rebuke; "stand back" means to send his wife and children away. "Startle" means to alarm the one undergoing transformation.

The rat’s liver, the insect’s arm—these speak of the tiniest of things, akin to the discourse of a single reed sprouting after Zhao Zhou’s fire has burned all away, yet its phrasing is extraordinary. "Only follow the mandate"—if I refuse to heed it, I am defiant and rebellious, echoing the earlier theme that things cannot overcome Heaven. The metaphor of casting metal is likewise singularly striking. Jia Yi said: "Yin and yang are the charcoal, the myriad things are the copper," all drawn forth from this crucible. If metal could speak, people would surely deem it monstrous. The Creator’s view of man is no different from the great smith’s view of metal—who but Zhuangzi could craft such parables? *Cheng* means "at ease"; *cheng ran* describes the state of slumber. *Qu ran* describes the state of waking. To take life as sleep and death as waking—these six words thus conclude the preceding passage, revealing the true marvel of the prose.

Zi Sang Hu, Mengzi Fan, and Zi Qin Zhang, the three friends, said to one another: "Who can join together in non-joining, act together in non-acting? Who can ascend the heavens and wander the mists, leaping and bounding without end, forgetting one another in life, without beginning or end?" The three looked at one another and laughed, their hearts in perfect accord, and so became friends.

After a time, Zi Sang Hu died. Before he was buried, Confucius heard of it and sent Zigong to attend to the rites. One wove a funeral mat, another strummed the zither, and together they sang in harmony: "Alas, Zi Sang Hu! Alas, Zi Sang Hu! You have returned to your true nature, while we remain as men." Zigong hurried forward and said: "May I ask—is it proper to sing before the corpse?" The two looked at each other and laughed: "What does he know of the meaning of ritual?"

"Joining together in non-joining" means to join without intent. "Acting together in non-acting" means to act without acting. *Nao tiao* means leaping and bounding. *Wu ji* means without end. "Ascending the heavens and wandering the mists" means to wander beyond things. "Forgetting one another in life, without beginning or end" is what was meant earlier by "not forgetting one’s beginning, not seeking one’s end." Where they spoke of "not forgetting," here they speak of "forgetting"—thus these eight words are but the five words "not seeking one’s end." *Mo ran* describes the vast and empty expanse; *you jian* means after a while.

Awaiting affairs is like assisting Yuan Rang in washing his staff. *Bian qu* refers to woven reeds used as markers. Some wove reeds, others played the zither—this refers to Mencius Fan and Zi Qin Zhang. *Yi* is an auxiliary particle. *Jie lai* are the opening words of the singer’s chant. "Returning to one’s true nature" means reverting to one’s origin. "I am still suspected by others" is like suddenly hearing the bells and drums from above, adding yet another day to this floating life. Such passages are among the text’s most striking. *Li yi* means the essence of ritual.

Though Zhuangzi speaks in parables, the *Book of Rites* records Yuan Rang’s "Badger-Head Song," showing that between heaven and earth, from ancient times, there have been those who practiced a learning of detachment from the world. Today, people say Buddhism first entered China during Emperor Ming’s reign, unaware that such people existed long before Buddhism.

Zigong returned and reported to Confucius: "What manner of men were they?" "They cultivated no conduct and treated their bodies as external things, singing before the corpse without change of countenance—what name could one give them?" "What manner of men were they?" Confucius said: "They wander beyond the bounds, while I wander within them. Outer and inner do not reach one another, yet I sent you to offer condolences—how shallow I am!"

"Those men roam as companions to the Creator, wandering in the single qi of heaven and earth. To them, life is an excrescent tumor, death the bursting of a boil. How could such as they know the priority of life and death? Borrowing from strange things, entrusting themselves to a shared body, they forget their liver and gall, disregard their ears and eyes, revolve through beginnings and ends without discerning head or tail. Vaguely they drift beyond the dust and grime, carefree in the work of non-action. How could they muddle themselves with worldly ritual to perform for the eyes and ears of the crowd?"

"Cultivating no conduct" means having no virtue or practice. "What name could one give them" means what could one call them. *Beyond the bounds* and *within the bounds* are like what Buddhists call worldly dharma and supramundane dharma. Their aims differ, and sending you to offer condolences was my mistake. Thus it is said: "Outer and inner do not reach one another, yet I sent you to offer condolences—how shallow I am!"

"Companions to the Creator" means befriending the Maker. "Wandering in the single qi of heaven and earth" means roaming in the primal state of creation. "Excrescent tumor" compares this body to a superfluous growth in heaven and earth, which must be burst and drained to bring relief—this is the meaning of "life burdens me, death gives me rest." "Borrowing from strange things" refers to the *Round Awakening*’s discourse on earth, water, fire, and wind; the four great elements combine to form the body, hence "entrusting themselves to a shared body." Even liver and gall, ears and eyes are not known to themselves—this is the meaning of "forgetting the body." "Revolving through beginnings and ends without discerning head or tail" means seeking the origin and end without finding the beginning. *Panghuang* means to drift and float. *Mangran* describes a state of unknowing. "Beyond the dust and grime" is the same as *beyond the bounds*. "The work of non-action" is spontaneity. *Kuikuiran* describes a state of self-inflicted confusion. Performing ritual for the eyes and ears of the world is mere self-delusion—this is Laozi’s meaning when he spoke of ritual as a forced imposition on the world.

Zigong said: "Then to what Way does the Master adhere?" Confucius said: "I am one punished by Heaven. Yet I share this with you." Zigong said: "May I ask what this Way is?" Confucius said: "Fish come together in water, men come together in the Dao. Those who come together in water dig ponds to secure their sustenance; those who come together in the Dao are without affairs and attain stillness. Thus it is said: Fish forget one another in rivers and lakes, men forget one another in the arts of the Dao."

Zigong said: "May I ask about the *qi ren*?" Confucius said: "*Qi ren* are askew among men but companions to Heaven. Thus it is said: Heaven’s petty men are men’s noble ones; men’s noble ones are Heaven’s petty men."

"What Way do you adhere to?" means: Does the Master follow the Way beyond the bounds or within them? "Punished by Heaven" echoes the earlier "condemned by Heaven—how could it be undone?"—meaning I cannot be a man of the Way beyond the bounds. "I share this with you" means I wish to speak with you of the joy of the Way beyond the bounds. "May I ask what this Way is" means "may I ask its reason?"

Fish gather in water, yet if they moisten one another with foam, it is not the same as forgetting one another in rivers and lakes. To dig a pond and keep them—though one may deem it sufficient—speaks only to having water, regardless of quantity. To attain the Dao is to live according to one’s allotted measure, to be still without affairs, for "without affairs" is "non-action."

The *qi ren* are those who are solitary—unique, set apart from others. *Mou* means "to align"; thus, the solitary do not pair with men but align with Heaven. What Heaven deems noble, men deem base; what men deem noble, Heaven deems base. In what Zhuangzi calls "noble ones," there lies a mockery of the sagely and worthy. For rites, music, laws, and measures do not arise from nature; only when scales are shattered and balances broken, when the people no longer contend, may one be called Heaven’s noble one. This is but a lofty discourse born of indignation toward a perverse world.

Yan Hui asked Confucius: "Mengsun Cai, when his mother died, wept without tears, felt no grief in his heart, and showed no sorrow in mourning. Lacking these three, yet praised for his mourning—does Lu indeed have those who gain renown without substance?" Hui had long marveled at this.

Confucius said: "Mengsun Cai has fully realized it; he has advanced in understanding. Though he sought to simplify, he could not—yet he has already simplified much. Mengsun Cai knows not why he lives, knows not why he dies, knows not what comes first, knows not what comes last. As if transformed into a thing, he awaits the transformations he does not know. And even as he is about to transform, how could he know it is not already transformed? Even as he is not transforming, how could he know it has not already transformed? You and I are but those who dream and have not yet awakened.

Lu values the reputation for proper mourning above all else. *Yi* means "constantly"; Hui had long been perplexed. "Advanced in understanding" means he has progressed, progressed to knowing the Dao. "Sought to simplify but could not" refers to mourning rites—such as weeping—he wished to cast aside but could not. Though he could not simplify, what he did was already quite simple, thus: "he has already simplified much." "Knows not why he lives, knows not why he dies" echoes the idea of reversal and recurrence, without beginning or end. "What comes first" is the beginning; "what comes last" is the end. He follows the transformations of creation, becoming one with things, awaiting the unknown transformations—this is to follow nature. *Yihu* is an emphatic particle.

Having followed nature, how could he know whether he is transforming, has transformed, or will not transform? Such are the stirring, soaring words of one who understands. He who knows the Dao and follows nature—yet I marvel at him—am I not the one still dreaming, not yet awake?

Moreover, he may be startled by form yet suffer no harm to his heart; he may dwell in a new abode yet feel no true death. Mengsun Cai merely awakens to others’ weeping and weeps in turn—this is simply how he is. "Startled by form" refers to the changes of body from youth to age; though such changes may astonish, his heart remains at ease, untroubled—thus "no harm to his heart." *Zhai* means "to dwell"; *dan* means "life." Life and death are like day and night. Knowing that life’s dwelling is temporary, death is not truly death—thus "no true death." *Qing* means "real." "Merely awakens to others’ weeping and weeps in turn" means he follows the crowd. This is where he wished to simplify but could not.

"This is simply how he is"—these six words are most extraordinary. Though he wished to simplify but could not, he nonetheless followed the crowd in weeping—this is the marvel of his self-attainment. This line is most difficult to parse, and in many versions, the *nai* of the previous clause and the *qie* of the following are combined, a pairing that is rather amusing.

Moreover, we are merely companions in this—how could we know what I call "I"? *Qie* here is simply *qie* with an added *ye*, as seen repeatedly in earlier passages. *Wu* means "I." Now, as we are together, I marvel at him through my own "I"—how could I know what this "I" truly is? Thus: "Moreover, we are merely companions in this—how could we know what I call 'I'?"

Zhuangzi’s writing often stirs and soars in this way; without a discerning eye, it is difficult to read.

Moreover, you dream of being a bird soaring to the heavens, or a fish diving into the depths. But how can we know whether the speaker now is awake or still dreaming? One’s intent may reach fulfillment before laughter arises; laughter may come before one can arrange it. To calmly accept what is arranged and follow transformation is to enter the vast oneness of Heaven.

The dreams of bird and fish reprise the earlier theme of the butterfly. "Is the speaker now awake or dreaming?" echoes: "Was it the butterfly dreaming of Zhuang Zhou, or Zhuang Zhou dreaming of the butterfly?" When intent is fulfilled, there may be no time for laughter—this speaks to the intensity of the moment. It is like Du Fu’s line: "Only when the shock subsided did I wipe my tears." Mr. Le Xuan also said: "By the time I could weep, the shock had already passed." Here, *zao shi* speaks to joy, as *jing* speaks to shock—though their emotions differ, the sense of "not yet" is the same.

* Pai* means "to arrange." Laughter arises naturally from things, as if things offer laughter to me—what need is there for arrangement? Thus: "laughter may come before one can arrange it." Though this *pai* and the *pai* below share the same character, their rhetorical force differs, and they should not be linked.

Between the workings of creation, all things are arranged: life and death, success and failure, fortune and misfortune—all are already fixed. If I but calmly accept what is arranged and follow transformation, only then may I enter the mystery of creation. *Liao tian yi* is but another name for creation. *Liao* means "vast."

The "One" of *Liao Tian* is what was previously called "its goodness," while the "One" of its "not-goodness" is also this "One." Here, Zhuangzi is merely playing with words, coining terms as he goes.

Yi’erzi went to see Xu You. Xu You asked: "How has Yao aided you?" Yi’erzi replied: "Yao told me, 'You must personally embrace benevolence and righteousness and clearly distinguish right from wrong.'" Xu You said: "Then why have you come here? Yao has already branded you with benevolence and righteousness and mutilated you with right and wrong—how will you wander the paths of carefree roaming, uninhibited freedom, and ceaseless transformation?" Yi’erzi said: "Even so, I wish to wander along its borders." Xu You said: "That will not do. The blind have no part in the beauty of brows and eyes, nor the deaf in the splendor of blue and yellow, embroidered patterns."

Yi’erzi said: "Wu Zhuang’s loss of beauty, Ju Liang’s loss of strength, and the Yellow Emperor’s loss of wisdom—all occurred in the space between the furnace and hammer. How do we know the Creator will not cease branding me, mend my mutilation, and let me ride perfection to follow you, Master?" Xu You said: "Alas, it cannot be known. Let me tell you its general outline. O my teacher! O my teacher!"

Embracing the myriad things yet not deeming it righteousness, bestowing blessings upon ten thousand generations yet not deeming it benevolence, enduring since high antiquity yet not deeming it age, encompassing heaven and earth, carving and sculpting all forms yet not deeming it artifice—this is the realm in which I wander.

What you possess is but instruction. To clarify right and wrong, to distinguish truth from falsehood—these are acts. "For" is an auxiliary word, as is "zhi." "Why have you come?" means "Why must you come?" "Branding and mutilation" besmirch you, as if to say you have been corrupted by such teachings. "Carefree roaming, uninhibited freedom, and ceaseless transformation" echo what was previously called "unfettered stirring, boundless wandering, and roaming beyond the dust and grime." "Carefree" means unbounded; "uninhibited" means unrestrained; "ceaseless transformation" means constant change. "Borders" refer to the fence. To say, "I dare not seek the inner chamber but only wish to reach the fence," is to express a desire to hear its general outline. The analogy of the blind and deaf that follows means you lack the capacity to comprehend the Dao.

Wu Zhuang was a beauty of old; Ju Liang, a paragon of courage. If you could embody the Dao and transform me, making the beautiful forget their beauty, the brave forget their strength, and the wise forget their wisdom—shedding old habits and awakening of your own accord—this would occur in the space between the furnace and hammer. "To ride" means to follow, to act in accordance with the perfection of nature. To cast off my former habits and act in accord with nature, serving you, Master, is to cease my branding, mend my mutilation, and let me ride perfection to follow you.

"Alas" expresses doubt. "It cannot be known" means I have yet to see if you can truly do this. The lines beginning with "O my teacher!" reveal the title of this chapter: *The Great and Venerable Teacher*.

Embracing and nurturing the myriad things yet not naming it righteousness, bestowing blessings upon ten thousand generations yet not naming it benevolence—this speaks of non-action that acts, of spontaneity itself. I harbor no deliberate intent, so such names do not apply. The *Yijing* says, "It stirs the myriad things yet shares no sage’s worries"—this is the same idea. "Enduring since high antiquity" means existing before heaven and earth. How can one who has endured for a thousand ages, for ten thousand ages, be named young or old?

Above, heaven covers with sun, moon, and stars; below, earth bears mountains, rivers, and hills—how much artifice is there! The heavens rotate leftward, the fixed stars cling to the sky and do not move, while the sun, moon, and five planets turn rightward, some swiftly, some slowly, some flowing, some hidden. The rivers, rocks, and waters—how many wonders! All are wrought by the Creator. Among the myriad forms, like the hundred grasses and myriad trees—how many marvels! What is this if not artifice? Yet it cannot be called artifice. These lines all describe the Dao of spontaneity.

To wander the mind in spontaneity is to see heaven and earth born together with me, the myriad things as one with me. Thus it is said, "This is the realm in which I wander," meaning this is where I roam.

Yan Hui said, "I have made progress."
Confucius said, "What do you mean?"
"I have forgotten benevolence and righteousness."
"That is good, but it is not yet enough."

Another day, they met again, and Yan Hui said, "I have made progress."
"What do you mean?"
"I have forgotten ritual and music."
"That is good, but it is not yet enough."

Another day, they met again, and Yan Hui said, "I have made progress."
"What do you mean?"
"I have forgotten myself in sitting."
Confucius started and said, "What do you mean by 'forgetting yourself in sitting'?"
Yan Hui said, "I cast off my limbs, dim my intelligence, leave my form, abandon knowledge, and merge with the Great Thoroughfare. This is what I call 'forgetting myself in sitting.'"
Confucius said, "To merge is to have no preferences; to transform is to have no constancy. You are truly worthy! I would follow after you."

This passage borrows the name of Yanzi to illustrate the subtleties of attaining the Dao, for even Zhuangzi in his time knew that Yanzi was second only to the sage. Yet the doctrine of "sitting in forgetfulness" belongs to Zhuangzi’s teaching—seeking it in Yanzi would be mistaken.

"Progress" here means gaining something. First benevolence and righteousness are forgotten, then ritual and music, implying that ritual and music are a step higher than benevolence and righteousness. For Zhuangzi, the terms "benevolence and righteousness" refer merely to love and aversion. All such meanings differ from those of the sages and worthies. First forgetting benevolence and righteousness, then proceeding to forget ritual and music, is like "setting aside the world, then all things." As for "sitting in forgetfulness," everything is forgotten entirely—this is the moment when both being and non-being are cast off, akin to the saying, "Now I have lost myself." The limbs and senses no longer know themselves, hence "casting off the limbs, dimming intelligence." "Leaving form" is casting off the limbs; "abandoning knowledge" is dimming intelligence. "Great Thoroughfare" is the Great Dao.

The sage is called "all-penetrating," and "penetrating" means "thoroughfare." Consider these two characters, "sitting in forgetfulness"—they form the same case as the Chan school’s "facing the wall." "To merge" is to become one with the Dao. Becoming one with the Dao means having no preferences; having no preferences means transformation; transformation means "no abiding, yet giving rise to the mind." Thus it is said, "To merge is to have no preferences; to transform is to have no constancy."

"To follow after you" means you surpass me, and I, falling short, stand behind you. "Worthy" means surpassing—surpassing the worthiness of others.

Ziyu and Zisang were friends. After ten days of ceaseless rain, Ziyu said, "Zisang must be ill." He wrapped rice and went to feed him. Arriving at Zisang’s gate, he heard sounds like singing, like weeping—plucking the zither, Zisang cried: "Father! Mother! Heaven! Man!" His voice could not sustain itself, and he hurriedly recited his verse.

Ziyu entered and asked, "Why do you sing your poem in this manner?"

Zisang replied, "I pondered who brought me to this extremity, but found no answer. Would my parents wish me poor? Heaven covers without partiality; earth bears without partiality. Would heaven and earth single me out for poverty? I sought the cause but could not find it. Yet here I am at this extremity—it is fate."

This passage speaks only of poverty and success as matters of fate, crafting such words in a most extraordinary way. Fearing Zisang might fall ill from hunger, Ziyu said he must be ill. In ancient times, playing the zither was always accompanied by song, as when Shun plucked the zither and sang *The South Wind*. "Like singing, like weeping" describes his strength failing, his voice faint. "His voice could not sustain itself" means he lacked the strength to project it. "Hurriedly recited his verse" refers to his distressed emotions constricting his words—his song lacked coherence, hence "hurried recitation." "Would my parents wish me poor? Would heaven and earth wish me poor?"—these lines are most exquisite. "I sought the cause but could not find it" means since it is neither heaven nor earth, neither father nor mother, then who is responsible? Yet what has brought me to this extremity is fate. This implies that the principle of spontaneity lies beyond heaven and earth. Fate is the principle of spontaneity—this is what is called the Great Master. Reading this chapter of *Zhuangzi*, one sees that *Liezi*’s "Power and Fate" falls far short.

**Inner Chapters: "Responding as Emperor and King"**

This chapter speaks of the Dao of emperors and kings, which must be thus in accord. Nie Que questioned Wang Ni four times, and four times received no answer. Thereat Nie Que leapt with great joy and went to tell Master Pu Yi.

Master Pu Yi said: "Have you only now come to know this? The Lord of Yu falls short of the Lord of Tai. The Lord of Yu concealed his benevolence to bind men to him—thus he gained men, yet never transcended the realm of the non-human. The Lord of Tai lay at ease, awoke in leisure; now taking himself for a horse, now for an ox. His knowledge was true to his nature, his virtue most genuine, and he never entered the realm of the non-human."

Four questions met with four answers of unknowing—this is the meaning of the *Vimalakīrti Sūtra*, where non-speech is the non-dual gateway. "Pu Yi" may also be read as "cloaked one." The names and figures in *Zhuangzi* are often fictive, like Master Wu You or Lord Absence—no need to dispute them.

Nie Que grasped the meaning of non-speech, hence his joy in telling Master Pu Yi. "Have you only now come to know this?" means "you have only now awakened." *Er* (而) means "you." The Lord of Tai was an ancient emperor, akin to the Lord of Great Court. *Cang* (藏) means "to harbor"; *yao* (要) means "to bind." To bind men’s hearts with benevolence is also a way to gain them. Yet this does not rise to the level of heaven—it merely keeps company with heaven. The "non-human" is heaven, hence "never transcended the non-human." "Never transcended" means "no more than this." To say "non-human" rather than "heaven" is but a flourish of his brush.

"Lay at ease" means tranquility; "awoke in leisure" means self-contentment. Now taking himself for a horse, now for an ox—all was left unquestioned, as if heedless of others’ judgments. What he knew was the true principle. *Qing xin* (情信) means "true in nature." His virtue was wholly natural. At this point, even "heaven" is insufficient to name it, for his spontaneity transcended even creation, hence "never entered the non-human." First "transcended," then "entered"—observe his choice of words. The Dao of emperors and kings lies in spontaneity alone; the title "Responding as Emperor and King" precisely conveys this.

---

Jian Wu met the madman Jie Yu, who asked: "What did Ri Zhong Shi tell you?"

Jian Wu said: "He told me that one who rules men must issue from himself the constant norms, models, and right principles to transform them. Who would dare disobey and fail to be transformed?"

Jie Yu said: "This is deceptive virtue. To govern the world thus is like crossing the sea by digging a river or making a mosquito bear a mountain. When the sage governs, he governs externally—acting only after rectifying himself. He is resolute in fulfilling his task, and that is all."

Moreover, birds fly high to escape the harm of arrows and nets, and field mice burrow deep beneath sacred mounds to avoid the peril of fumigation and digging—yet you are less wise than these two creatures.

Jian Wu first met Ri Zhong Shi, then Jie Yu, hence Jie Yu questioned him thus. *Jing* (经) means "constant"; *shi* (式) means "model"; *yi* (义) means "right principle in handling affairs." That the constant norms, models, and right principles issue from oneself means making oneself the model for the world. *Du ren* (度人) means "to transform men." To transform the world by modeling oneself is thus called "issuing from oneself the constant norms, models, and right principles to transform men." The phrasing of *jing shi yi* (经式义) aligns with "harmony and ease." *Du* is pronounced *du* (渡), "to cross."

"Who would dare disobey and fail to be transformed?" means the people would all heed and be transformed. "Deceptive virtue" means self-deception, not true virtue. To govern the world thus is harder than crossing the sea by digging a river or making a mosquito bear a mountain. "Digging a river" refers to dredging the Nine Rivers and the like.

"Governing externally" means transforming through the mind leaves no trace, while transforming through the body leaves traces. "Acting only after rectifying himself" means following the principles of nature and fate. "Fulfilling his task" means exhausting this natural course. *Que hu* (确乎) means "resolute"—his governance is resolutely thus. *Zhuangzi*’s thought centers on non-action, hence his teaching differs from that of the Confucians.

Birds fly high to avoid nets and arrows, and mice burrow deep to avoid fumigation and digging—this shows that those who leave traces are self-encumbered. If one cannot practice non-action and instead leaves traces, one’s ignorance is greater than that of these two creatures. The "two creatures" are the bird and the mouse. *Shen qiu* (神丘) means "sacred mound."

---

Tian Gen wandered to Yin Yang and came to the waters of Liao, where he encountered an unnamed man and asked: "May I inquire how to govern the world?"

The unnamed man said: "Begone! You are a vulgar man—why ask so inauspiciously? I am about to become a man with the Creator. When sated, I will ride the boundless bird to soar beyond the six directions and wander in the land of Nothing Whatever, dwelling in the wild expanse. Why trouble my heart with your questions of governing the world?"

He asked again, and the unnamed man said: "Let your mind wander in stillness, harmonize your qi with the vast, follow things as they are without imposing private ends—and the world will be governed."

To ask about governing the world is not the way of non-action, hence he deemed it a vulgar question and made me displeased. *Bu yu* (不豫) means "unhappy." "Becoming a man with the Creator" means dwelling in the human world while following the Creator’s spontaneity. *Yan* (厌) means "sated" or "full"—having had his fill of the human world, he would wander beyond creation. The "boundless bird" is the qi of emptiness. The "land of Nothing Whatever" and the "wild expanse" both refer to the realm of supreme emptiness. *He yi* (何帠) means "why." The annotation glosses *fa* (法) as *gu* (故), "reason."

To ask about governing the world stirred my heart—this is why I was displeased. The word *gan* (感) here means "to stir" or "to provoke." The character *yi* (帠), according to Master Cui, also carries the sense of "why." *Dan* (淡) means "serene and unadorned." *Mo* (漠) refers to the formless, empty expanse. *Qi* here is akin to *xing* (性, nature)—since this mind and this nature both align with spontaneity, it is said: "Let your mind wander in serenity, harmonize your qi with the formless." Earlier, it was said, "Do not listen with the mind but listen with qi"—here, *qi* should be understood as *xing* (nature). Follow the Creator’s spontaneity without imposing the mind, and the world will govern itself. Why must one take governing the world as a task? To act with intent is to introduce private bias.

When Tian Gen asked again, the Nameless Man answered him with words of truth. That he is called the Nameless Man shows that all the names mentioned before and after—such as those of fictitious figures—are like "Zixu" or "bird-that-is-not" (empty designations). Hence, later chapters speak of "parable" and "reiterated words." When names like the Yellow Emperor, Confucius, Yan Hui, or the Madman of Chu are invoked, it is to lend weight to the author’s own teachings. The "parable" refers to figures like the Nameless Man, Tian Gen, and Master Pu Yi.

Yang Ziju asked Lao Dan: "Suppose there were a man swift and strong in action, penetrating in understanding, and tireless in learning the Dao. Could such a one be compared to an enlightened king?" Lao Dan replied: "In the eyes of the sage, such a man is but a petty functionary, bound by skill and toil, exhausting his body and startling his mind. The patterns of tigers and leopards attract hunters; the agility of monkeys and the tameness of hounds bring them to the leash. Could such a one be compared to an enlightened king?"

Yang Ziju, dismayed, asked: "Then may I inquire about the governance of an enlightened king?" Lao Dan said: "The governance of an enlightened king: his achievements cover the world yet seem not his own; his transformative influence nurtures the ten thousand things, yet the people do not rely on him. No name is raised, yet things rejoice of themselves. He stands in the unfathomable and wanders in the realm of Nothing Whatever."

"Suppose there were a man..."—these words describe a certain person without naming him, subtly mocking Confucius. *Xiang ji* (向疾) means "swift and eager"; *qiang liang* (强梁) means "unyielding and vigorous"—referring to one who learns keenly and acts with determination. *Wu* (物) means "affairs"; *che* (彻) means "penetrating."

Those who speak of penetrating all affairs yet perceive with emptiness and clarity—*shu* (疏) means "emptiness." If one were to learn the Dao with such tirelessness, could this be compared to the governance of an enlightened king? This asks whether such learning constitutes the work of a true king.

*Xu* (胥) refers to convict laborers; *yi* (易) means "to change," akin to "taking turns in service." The term *xu yi* must have been an ancient expression, like the Han dynasty’s "ghost-firewood gatherers." *Ji xi* (技系) describes those bound by their craft and technical skills. These two types of people—those who take turns in labor and those shackled by their skills—exhaust their bodies and unsettle their minds through such learning. Their bodies toil and their hearts tremble, as if they were no more than convict laborers or craftsmen in bondage. *Chu xin* (怵心) describes a heart gripped by constant fear.

Tigers and leopards, with their patterned hides, attract hunters. *Ji* (藉) means "rope," the very thing that binds. The *li* (狸), or wildcat—along with dogs that seize them, and the agile monkeys and macaques—all invite the calamity of capture and restraint. Thus, any ability inevitably brings its own entanglement. The phrase "seizing the wildcat" also appears in the "Heaven and Earth" chapter.

If one were to govern through such active, worldly learning, then even tigers and leopards could be compared to enlightened kings—this is the harshest of rebukes. These three lines stand out for their striking phrasing.

"His achievements cover the world yet seem not his own" echoes the idea of "accomplishing without claiming." "His transformative influence nurtures the ten thousand things, yet the people do not rely on him" reflects the sentiment that "throughout the realm, none know whence it comes, nor what power the emperor wields." *Dai* (贷) means "to bestow," referring to the ruler’s transformative bestowal upon the people. The glosses for characters often follow tonal patterns—here, *dai* aligns with *shi* (施), both meaning "to grant." "Heaven bestows, earth produces; clouds move, rain is granted"—though the tones of *shi* and *dai* differ, their meaning remains the same.

"None can raise a name for what he possesses" means that no one can name his achievements, nor can the people find words to praise him. "Things rejoice of themselves" suggests that though no merit can be ascribed to him, all things find their own joy—much like Han Yu’s phrase, "people find their own contentment beyond the rivers and lakes."

"Unfathomable" means beyond comprehension, synonymous with "Nothing Whatever." "He stands in the unfathomable" is but another way of saying "he wanders in the realm of Nothing Whatever." The brush dances with such vitality throughout. These passages all expound the meaning of the "Responding to Emperors" chapter.

In Zheng there was a divine diviner named Ji Xian, who could foretell life and death, fortune and misfortune, longevity and early demise—his predictions, precise to the year, month, or day, were as if divine. The people of Zheng, upon seeing him, would flee in haste, but Liezi met him and was utterly enchanted. Returning home, he told Master Huzi: "At first, I believed your Dao was supreme, yet now I see there is something even greater."

Huzhi said: "I have shown you only its outward form, not its true substance—how then could you have grasped the Dao? A flock of hens without a rooster will never produce eggs. If you present the Dao to the world in such a manner, you will surely be believed. Thus, others can read your fortune."

Predictions of "years, months, or days" may be distant or near. A *shen wu* (神巫), or divine diviner, is one whose words prove true as if by magic. Those who "flee in haste" do so out of fear of his accuracy. "Enchanted in heart" means utterly convinced. "Having exhausted its outward form" refers to mastering only the external, while "not yet exhausted its true substance" means the inner truth remains untouched. *Er* (而) means "you."

You have never fully witnessed its true substance—how then could you truly claim to have grasped the Way? The word *gu* (固) implies mistaking partial attainment for mastery; consider its rhetorical force. Only with both male and female does generation occur—eggs are life itself. Without the male, how could there be eggs? This means that without the heart, no trace remains. This line illustrates that your heart has not yet transformed, so it may still be perceived through form.

*Kang* (亢) means "lofty"; if you elevate the Way above the world and demand others believe it, this itself is a trace, a sign of incomplete transformation. Thus, the divine diviner could read your fortune.

"Come again and bring him to me, that I may show myself to him."

The next day, Liezi brought him to see Huzhi. As Huzhi emerged, the diviner said to Liezi: "Alas! Your master is dead—he will not live, not even for ten days. I saw something strange: I saw damp ashes."

Liezi entered, his tears soaking his lapels, and told Huzhi what had happened. Huzhi said: "Just now, I showed him the *earthly pattern*—sprouting yet neither stirring nor settling. This was nearly my *blocked virtue-mechanism*. *Damp ashes* means his vital qi is nearly spent, like embers drenched and about to die out. *Earthly pattern* is akin to the meditative terms of Chan Buddhism, suggesting the faintest stirrings of life that are not yet life. *Not stirring* means unmoving; *not settling* means it cannot be pinned down or described. This *not settling* echoes Mencius’ phrase, 'There must be action, but do not fix it.' Only when there is the semblance of movement yet no movement does the diviner perceive *damp ashes*. Ashes are living fire; damp ashes imply living fire on the verge of extinction. *Blocked virtue-mechanism* is another meditative term: *virtue-mechanism* is the impulse of life, while *blocked* means closed off and unmoving. Thus, the appearance is of life about to fade, and Jixian concluded he would not live."

"Bring him again." The next day, Liezi brought him to see Huzhi once more.

Liezi emerged and said to Liezi: "Fortunate indeed! Your master has met me—he is recovering, fully alive. I saw his *blocked potential*."

Liezi entered and reported this to Huzhi. Huzhi said: "I showed him *Heaven and Earth*—names and realities did not enter, yet the mechanism stirred from the heels. This was the first glimpse of my *virtuous mechanism*. *Blocked potential* is movement within stillness. *Potential* and *mechanism* are the same, but the mechanism is subtle while potential is manifest. Within the blocked closure, the dynamic mechanism was revealed, so Jixian took it as full vitality."

"*Heaven and Earth* is also a meditative term: *Heaven* is the celestial field, the field above, not the *Earth* of soil, but the natural *Earth*—akin to how modern cultivators call the space beneath the tongue *Heavenly Ford* and the top of the head *Mud Pill*. This suggests the stirrings of life rising upward. *Names and realities did not enter* means both being and non-being are transcended. *The mechanism stirred from the heels* describes qi ascending from below, so subtle it cannot be seen—hence *mechanism*. *Virtuous mechanism* refers to the movement of inherent nature."

The next day, Liezi brought him to see Huzhi again. Upon leaving, Jixian said to Liezi: "Your master is unsettled; I cannot divine him. Let him settle himself, then I will divine him again."

Liezi entered and told Huzhi, who said: "I showed him *Supreme Vacuity, Unsurpassable*—this was nearly a glimpse of my *balanced qi-mechanism*. *Supreme Vacuity, Unsurpassable* is also a meditative term: *Supreme Vacuity* is the Great Void; *Unsurpassable* means it cannot be grasped. *Balanced* means level, half—when the dynamic mechanism of qi reaches equilibrium, it is half-moving, half-still. The spirit-diviner saw him as unsettled, for he was half-moving, half-still, and thus indeterminate."

"The *coiled leviathan* confirms the abyss, the *still water* confirms the abyss, the *flowing water* confirms the abyss. The abyss has nine names—here are three. *Coiled leviathan*, *still water*, and *flowing water* are all meditative terms. Modern Buddhists use *contemplation*, but the ancients called it *abyss*—just as Guanyin has twelve contemplations, the abyss has nine names. *Confirms* means truly. The *coiled leviathan* truly forms one contemplation, *still water* truly forms one contemplation, *flowing water* truly forms one contemplation. Only now does Huzhi reveal that what he showed the spirit-diviner were all these abysses. I have nine abysses, and I have shown only three—implying my subtleties are not yet exhausted. The character *confirms* is not *coiled*."

"The *Nine Abysses* in *Liezi* are complete, and Hong Yechu claimed *Liezi* surpasses *Zhuangzi*—this is hardly a sound judgment. If all nine abysses were fully explained, it would no longer be extraordinary prose. The art of leaving some things unsaid is precisely Zhuangzi’s marvel; only those who truly understand literature recognize this. This chapter originally had four sections, but the discussion of the nine abysses is woven into the fourth, demonstrating the art of expansion and contraction."

The next day, Liezi brought him to see Huzhi again. Jixian had not yet taken his stance when he lost himself and fled. Huzhi said: "Pursue him." Liezi chased him but could not catch up. Returning, he reported to Huzhi: "He has vanished, he is gone—I could not reach him."

Huzhi said: "Earlier, I showed him *Not Yet Emerged from My Source*. I met him with emptiness and compliance, so he knew not who or what I was. Thus, he took me for *crumbling reeds*, for *drifting waves*—and so he fled. *Vanished* and *gone* mean he could no longer perceive me. *Not Yet Emerged from My Source* is also a meditative term. *Emptiness* is the void; *compliance* is yielding. As if nothing, as if something—he knew not what I was, hence *he knew not who or what*. *Crumbling reeds* suggests collapse; *drifting waves* suggest boundlessness. Seeing me as formless, he saw only collapse and boundlessness—so he lost himself and fled."

Thereafter, Liezi returned home, believing he had never truly studied. For three years he did not venture out. He cooked for his wife, fed pigs as if feeding people, and took no personal interest in affairs. He carved and polished his faculties only to return to simplicity, standing alone like an unhewn block. Amidst the clamor, he remained bounded, ending thus.

"He cooked for his wife"—he took her place at the stove and did not leave. "Fed pigs as if feeding people"—his spirit gathered inward, and he saw no distinction. "Took no personal interest in affairs"—though he acted, he was unaware, as if not personally involved. He carved and polished his brilliance only to return to simplicity—this is what was earlier called "casting off the branches of the body and dismissing cleverness." "Stood alone like an unhewn block"—like a wooden figure. *Bounded* means having edges; *clamor* means excess. If his form was like a wooden figure, how could there be excess edges? "Ending thus"—he remained so for the rest of his life. *Thus* means always thus.

"Do not be a master of fame, do not be a storehouse of schemes, do not take on tasks as your burden, do not be a host of knowledge. Embody the boundless and wander without trace, exhaust what you have received from Heaven without seeking gain—be empty, and that is all. The mind of the perfected one is like a mirror: it neither advances nor retreats, responds but does not store, and thus can master things without harm."

Zhuangzi here exhaustively describes the practice of non-action. *Master* means to preside. Not taking fame as master is to *excel without approaching fame*. *Storehouse* means multitude. Earlier, he said, "Do not admire affairs, do not scheme—what use is wisdom?" This is the same idea. If one schemes intentionally, schemes gather here, and where schemes are possible, the mind has no use for them—hence *do not be a storehouse of schemes*. Though affairs cannot be avoided, one should not take them as a personal burden—hence *do not take on tasks as your burden*.

Though man cannot be without wisdom, he should not take wisdom as his master—hence the saying *do not make wisdom your master*. When the mind has a master, it becomes partial.

These four *no’s* serve as prohibitions, akin to the four *not’s* in the *Analects*. *To embody* means to perceive, to see. Seeing the Dao to its utmost without limit, the mind roams in the beginning of nothingness—hence *embody the boundless and wander without trace*. *Trace* means sign, beginning; *without trace* is thus *without beginning*.

Heaven endows me with this principle, and I exhaust it without claiming any gain—hence *exhaust what you receive from Heaven without seeking gain*. To see gain is to approach mere traces.

The Buddhist sutras speak of "awakening through illusion" in the same way. Having expounded thus far, he concludes with a single word: *empty*—this line carries great force. *Empty* is spontaneity, freedom from attachment.

When a mirror reflects things—beauty or ugliness, coming or going—it reflects of itself. It neither sends nor receives. *Sends* means to escort. It reflects forms and reveals forms, reflects things and reveals things—this is called *responding in the mirror*. Yet it never retains them, hence *responds but does not store*.

The mind of the perfected one is like this, so it remains unobstructed by things—hence *masters things without harm*. The Dao of Heaven does not contend yet excels at mastery—this is the meaning of *mastery*. These lines on the mirror clearly explicate the earlier *empty*. The rise and fall of the prose—is it not marvelous? Within its plainness lies divine artistry; such is this writing.

The Lord of the Southern Sea was Shu, the Lord of the Northern Sea was Hu, and the Lord of the Center was Hundun. Shu and Hu often met in Hundun’s land, and Hundun treated them very well. Shu and Hu plotted to repay Hundun’s virtue, saying: "All men have seven apertures for seeing, hearing, eating, and breathing—only he has none. Let us try boring them for him." Each day they bored one aperture, and on the seventh day, Hundun died.

This passage simply illustrates how intelligence can burden the body. Thus, to cast off limbs and reject cleverness is to become Hundun. Though told in plain speech, the tale of boring one aperture each day is a stroke of genius.

Shu, Hu, and Hundun are all allegories; one must not cling to them literally, or one becomes like a fool recounting dreams. Hundun is primordial qi. The human body has seven apertures—like a newborn infant, whose ears, eyes, nose, and tongue exist but lack knowledge; this is the wholeness of Hundun. When knowledge begins to sprout, likes and dislikes arise—this is the boring of apertures.

Mencius said, "The great man does not lose the heart of a newborn infant"—this is Hundun unborrowed. Zhuangzi’s inversion renders it so strangely, yet the writing remains extraordinary.

Zhuangzi’s thirty-two chapters are divided into Inner and Outer sections. The seven Inner Chapters are each named with three characters, while those from *Webbed Toes* onward take only the first two or three characters of the opening line as their titles, following the example of *The Analects*’ *Learning* and *Governance*. The book makes no distinction of refinement; Inner and Outer Chapters speak in the same voice, merely arranged thus to inspire future generations.

Some Outer Chapters contain passages of sprawling prose, leading some to claim the Inner Chapters are refined and the Outer Chapters coarse—this is not so. Others attempt to explain the sequence of the seven Inner Chapters, saying: first one must *Wander Freely*, then *Equalize Things*; having equalized things, one should *Nourish the Life*; after mastering life-nourishment, one may *Roam the World of Men*; roaming the world, one draws all to oneself, hence *Signs of Full Virtue*; with inner virtue full and outer signs manifest, one becomes a teacher of men, hence *The Great Ancestral Master*; possessing this Dao, one may instruct emperors and kings, hence *Responding to Emperors and Kings*.

Though this interpretation holds, such rigid adherence lacks deeper principle and differs from the *Sequence of Hexagrams* in the *Book of Changes*. The true way to read Zhuangzi lies not here, but in grasping the momentum of the text itself—then boundless delight follows.

The most crucial part of any writing is its conclusion. In the seven Inner Chapters, each ends distinctively: *Wandering Freely* with *use and uselessness*, *Equalizing Things* with *the butterfly dream and transformation of things*, *Nourishing Life* with *fire transmitted*, *Signs of Full Virtue* with *hard and white cry out*, *Roaming the World of Men* with *"it is fate!"*

Each carries its own intent, and when all seven are complete, he contrives the tale of Shu, Hu, and Hundun, concluding with *"on the seventh day, Hundun died."* Observe his mechanism—is it not singular?

The *Doctrine of the Mean* begins with *"What Heaven imparts to man is called human nature..."* and ends with *"Only the utmost of the world’s Way leaves no sound, no scent"*—this too is a textual mechanism, though few perceive it thus.

Once, while attending my late teacher’s lecture on the *Spring and Autumn Annals* at the passage *"In the western hunt, a unicorn was captured,"* my teacher said: *"When it reaches its utmost, even the sage has what he does not know—hence he ended his brush here."* That night, as we strolled along the western veranda, he suddenly asked: *"How do you see the place where the unicorn was captured?"*

Xiyi replied: *"Applying the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s line about what the sage does not know—no other school has done this."* He added: *"The *Annals* begins with *'In the first year of the king’s reign'* and ends with *'In the western hunt, a unicorn was captured.'* Had there been one more line, the Master would surely not have recorded it."*

My teacher asked: *"How so?"*

Xiyi said: *"With such a conclusion, what more could be added?"*

My teacher made no reply and left. The hour was late, so he knocked at the gate of Uncle Qiu of Boyi and said: *"Master Su’s reading of the *Spring and Autumn Annals* is excellent. I and my friends have studied it for many years, yet none have matched this insight."*

Delighted by these words, he did not return until midnight. Two days later, Uncle Qiu of Boyi spoke of this to Xiyi.

*The True Classic of Southern Florescence: Oral Exegesis*, Scroll Ten, concludes.¹
¹Originally "Three"; emended according to the Ming edition.
²"King": originally "Five"; emended according to the Ming edition.
³"Reveal": originally "Gaze"; emended according to the Ming edition.
⁴"Correct": originally "Return"; emended according to the Ming edition.
⁵"Pellet": originally "Nine"; emended according to the Ming edition.

*The True Classic of Southern Florescence: Oral Exegesis*, Scroll Eleven
By Lin Xiyi of Yuanzhai

**Outer Chapters: "Webbed Toes"**

Webbed toes and supernumerary fingers arise from nature, yet exceed in virtue. Wens and hanging warts arise from form, yet exceed in nature.

Those who employ the manifold methods of benevolence and righteousness arrange them among the five viscera, yet this is not the correct alignment of the Dao and virtue.

Thus, toes webbed together are but conjoined useless flesh; fingers branched apart are but limbs of useless digits. Those who apply manifold methods to the passions of the five viscera indulge in deviant practices of benevolence and righteousness, employing manifold methods in the use of hearing and sight.

The *mǔ* is the big toe; the *zhǐ* is the finger. *Pián* means "to join"; *zhī* means "to branch." What is born together with birth is called *nature*; what all humans equally receive is called *virtue*. Webbed toes and supernumerary fingers are both afflictions. Though they arise naturally, compared to what all humans equally receive, they are excessive—*excess* meaning surplus.

The meanings of *nature* and *virtue* here differ somewhat from those of the sages and worthies.

Wens and hanging warts are also afflictions. Webbed toes and branched fingers exist from birth, whereas wens and warts arise after form has taken shape. Thus, they are said to arise from form yet exceed in nature.

*Duōfāng* means "manifold methods"; *yòng zhī* means "to employ them externally." *Liè yú wǔzàng zāi* means they do not arise from within. They are not the natural expression of the Dao, hence they are said to be "not the correct alignment of the Dao and virtue."

Gaozi spoke of *yi* (righteousness) as external, while Zhuangzi went further, treating even transformation as external. He regarded benevolence and righteousness as excesses and perversions, grouping them with cleverness and acuity—all as teachings that fail to focus inwardly, hence appearing merely as "manifold affairs." *Duōfāng* here means "manifold affairs."

Thus, those who are *paired in clarity* disrupt the five colors, indulge in ornate patterns, and dazzle with azure, yellow, embroidered, and brocaded splendor—is this not so? And is not Li Zhu such a one? Those *excessive in hearing* disrupt the five tones, indulge in the six pitch-pipes, and revel in the sounds of metal, stone, silk, and bamboo, of *Huangzhong* and *Dalü*—is this not so? And is not Shi Kuang such a one? Those *branched in benevolence* pluck at virtue and obstruct nature to seize fame, driving the world to clamor like reed-pipes and drums in service of unattainable laws—is this not so? And are not Zengzi and Shishi such ones? Those *paired in disputation* pile tiles and knot cords, tamper with phrases, and roam their minds amid the debates of "hard and white" or "same and different," exhausting themselves in praise of useless words—is this not so? And are not Yangzi and Mozi such ones? All these are the ways of manifold pairings and branching excesses, not the ultimate correctness of the world.

The five colors, patterns, azure, yellow, embroidery, and brocade were in ancient times meant to nurture the eyes, yet Zhuangzi saw them as disruptive and indulgent. Thus, he spoke of being *paired in clarity*, echoing Laozi’s meaning that "the five colors blind the eyes." Li Zhu was one of clarity. If one deems such things incorrect, those of keen sight would consider them right—hence, "is this not so? And is not Li Zhu such a one?" The same applies to being *excessive in hearing*, for he regarded ritual and music as external things.

*Zhuó* means "to pluck"; *sè* means "obstructed," like overgrown thatch. Virtue and nature are inherently still, yet forcing oneself to practice benevolence is to pluck at virtue and obstruct nature. *Fǎ* refers to ritual laws; "unattainable" means what people find difficult to achieve. Compelling others to follow such difficult laws is to "drive the world to clamor like reed-pipes and drums in service of unattainable laws." *Huánggǔ* describes using words to deceive and stir others. Piling tiles and knotting cords are useless acts; the excessive words of disputers drag on endlessly, like unbroken chains with no meaning—hence the comparison to piled tiles and knotted cords. *Cuàndìng* means "to revise and fix," referring to refining phrases for debate, thus "tampering with phrases and roaming the mind amid 'hard and white' or 'same and different.'" *Bì* means "toil"; *kuǐ* is pronounced *qǐ*, meaning "to stand on tiptoe." Their words are useless yet praised with self-satisfaction, laboring in vain—hence, "toiling in tiptoe praise of useless words." If one deems this incorrect, the followers of Yangzi and Mozi would consider it right.

*Duō pián páng zhī* means "manifold pairings and branching excesses." The Way of nature is fundamentally without excess, yet these are all superfluous affairs, not the ultimate correctness. Ultimate correctness is the principle of inherent nature. Those who are *truly correct* do not lose the truth of their nature and life. Thus, what is joined is not called *paired*, what is branched is not called *excessive*, what is long is not called *surplus*, and what is short is not called *insufficient*. Therefore, though the teal’s legs are short, lengthening them brings sorrow; though the crane’s legs are long, severing them brings grief. Thus, what is long by nature should not be cut, and what is short by nature should not be extended—there is no sorrow to remove.

Does this suggest benevolence and righteousness are not human nature? Why do they bring so much sorrow? *Zhèng zhèng* means "naturally so." Being naturally so does not lose the true principle of nature and life. Though joined, it is not *paired*; though branched, it is not *excessive*; though long, it is not *surplus*; though short, it is not *insufficient*. These lines are deeply meaningful, echoing the earlier idea that "nothing in the world is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small." *Qǐ* means "to rise." To rise is to be unbalanced, and unbalanced is to be ill at ease. Observe how precisely he chooses his words—how could it be casual?

"Long by nature" and "short by nature" mean length and shortness arise from inherent nature. Length and shortness are what nature finds comfortable—there is no sorrow to remove. The analogy of the teal and crane is most apt. *Yì* is like *āi*, an exclamation. Speaking of these two extremes, benevolence and righteousness are manifold—are they not contrary to human nature? Thus, he sighs and says: if benevolence and righteousness arose naturally, they would not bring such sorrow. "Much sorrow" refers to the toil of practicing benevolence and righteousness.

In making these remarks, Zhuangzi includes all from Confucius and Mencius back to Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang in his ridicule. As for those with *paired toes*, severing them brings tears; those with *branched fingers*, biting them brings wails. Whether surplus in number or deficient in number, their sorrow is the same. The benevolent of today gaze with half-closed eyes, grieving over the world’s calamities; the unbenevolent sever the truth of their nature and life to glut themselves on wealth and honor. Does this not suggest benevolence and righteousness are not human nature? From the Three Dynasties onward, why has the world been so clamorous?

Though *paired toes* and *branched fingers* are both afflictions, they cannot be forcibly removed—removing them brings sorrow. *Branched* means an extra finger, hence "surplus in number." *Paired* means two fingers joined and inseparable, hence "deficient in number." *Hāomù* means half-closed eyes; to close them yet not fully close them leaves the lashes tangled—hence, *hāomù*. *Hāo* refers to mugwort; *hāomù* conveys the sense of sitting alone in sorrow. This is how Zhuangzi chooses his words.
