Sir, if you could make the world not lose its uncarved simplicity, you too would move with the wind and act, holding fast to virtue and standing firm. Why then do you strut about as if shouldering a great drum, seeking a lost child?" *Biting the skin* and *chaff in the eye* are metaphors for things that go against the heart. *Xī* means night, as in the *Zuozhuan*: "At home, one prepares a night’s defense." *Cǎnrán* describes bitterness—it means self-inflicted suffering. "Agitating my heart" means going against my heart. "No disorder is greater" means it disorders one’s nature. "Moving with the wind" means following transformation; acting in accord with transformation is called "moving with the wind." *Zǒng* means to grasp. If the world did not lose its original simplicity, all would act in accord with transformation, grasp virtue, and stand firm—what need would there be for instruction? King Wen set up a drum at his gate to summon the people and teach them, like one shouldering a great drum to seek a lost child. *Jiéran* describes a self-aggrandizing appearance.

The egret is not white from daily bathing, nor is the crow black from daily dyeing. The simplicity of black and white is not worth debating. The spectacle of fame and reputation is not worth expanding. When a spring dries up, fish find themselves on dry land, where they moisten each other with breath and wet each other with foam—yet this is not as good as forgetting one another in rivers and lakes. The whiteness of the egret and the blackness of the crow are naturally so, requiring no bathing or dyeing—these two metaphors are most apt. *Qiān* means to dye black. "The simplicity of black and white" means black and white both have their natural qualities, neither beautiful nor ugly, not worth debating. To display fame and reputation to the world is to introduce the idea of right and wrong; where there is praise, there is blame, and this heart is no longer vast. Black and white are metaphors for right and wrong. How much can fish moisten each other with breath and foam? If they dwelt in rivers and lakes, they would forget one another in the water. In an age of the perfect Dao, each follows spontaneity, without right or wrong, and superiors and inferiors likewise forget one another.

After Confucius visited Lao Dan and returned, he did not speak for three days. His disciples asked: "Master, when you saw Lao Dan, what admonition did you offer?" Confucius said: "Only now have I seen the dragon. The dragon coalesces into form and scatters into pattern, riding the clouds and qi, nourishing itself in yin and yang. My mouth gaped and could not close—what admonition could I offer Lao Dan?" *Guī* means to admonish. "Coalescing into form" means being whole and undifferentiated. "Scattering into pattern" means being distinct and ordered. The dragon in heaven and earth is visible yet not visible, hence the metaphor of scattering and coalescing. "Riding the clouds and qi" means being above the transformations of creation. "Nourishing itself in yin and yang" means delighting in the Dao of heaven and earth. *Xié* means to close. Gaping and unable to close, there was no place for words.

Zigong said: "Then are there indeed people who dwell like corpses yet manifest like dragons, thunderous in voice yet deep in silence, moving like heaven and earth? Could I too observe such a one?" Thereupon he went to see Lao Dan on Confucius’ behalf. Lao Dan was just then sitting arrogantly in the hall when he responded in a low voice: "My years have advanced and departed—what would you warn me about?" Zigong said: "The governance of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors differed, yet all were linked to fame. Why alone do you deem them untrue? How should the sage act?" Lao Dan said: "Young man, come closer. Why do you say they differed?" Zigong replied: "Yao passed the throne to Shun, Shun to Yu, Yu relied on strength, and Tang on arms; King Wen submitted to Zhou and dared not oppose, while King Wu opposed Zhou and would not submit. Thus I say they differed." Lao Dan said: "Young man, come closer. Let me tell you of the governance of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors. The governance of the Yellow Emperor made the people’s hearts not partial—though they had no particular affection, and though the dead were not mourned, the people did not deem it wrong..."

Shun’s governance of the realm made the people’s hearts competitive. Women bore children at ten months, and the infants could speak at five months, asking, “Who is this?” before they could even toddle—thus did people begin to die young. Yu’s governance made the people’s hearts change: each had their own desires, and warfare became a matter of course. Killing bandits was not considered murder; all acted for their own kind, and that was all there was to the world. Thus the realm was greatly alarmed, and the schools of Ru and Mo arose. Their beginnings had order, yet now—what can women say of it?

Confucius’s reputation reached Lao Dan, who remarked on the Master’s disciples and their refined inquiries. Yet when seated in the hall, he reclined with an air of arrogance. His responses were so faint as to be barely audible.

The governance of the Yellow Emperor accorded with nature. The following passages echo this idea, as seen repeatedly in earlier sections. Here, several additional lines appear, rather extraordinary.

Mourning garments were graded by the closeness of kinship, hence it is said, “For their kin they killed their killing.” This refers to the ancient absence of mourning rites, whereas now ritual is established. In ancient times, children were born at fourteen months and did not speak until two years old. To be born at ten months and speak at five is to be precocious. *Shui* means “to ask.” Before reaching the age of toddling, they could already ask, “Who is this?” *Shi* means “early.” *Shui* here means “to identify.” “Made the people’s hearts change” means they changed from ancient ways. “Each had their own desires” means each person had their own private inclinations. “Warfare became a matter of course” means that the use of arms was considered natural. Those who were bandits could be killed without it being deemed a crime or violation of law. At that time, people all divided themselves by kind, each loving their own kin, each cherishing their own children. They merely shared the world together, hence it is said, “and that was all there was to the world.” “Their beginnings had order” means that when such actions first arose, the principles of human relations still existed. Yet their corruption led to the violation of those relations, and when women became wives, what more could be said? That is, there was no room for discussion.

The passage in the *Record of Rites* on “the Great Way being public” conveys a similar idea, though Zhuangzi’s account is far more extreme.

“Let me tell you of the governance of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors. Though called governance, none brought greater disorder. The wisdom of the Three Sovereigns obscured the brightness of sun and moon above, disrupted the essence of mountains and rivers below, and threw into chaos the operations of the four seasons in between. Their cunning was more venomous than the sting of wasps or scorpions, more predatory than the hunting of small beasts. None could preserve the natural state of their lives, yet they still called themselves sages. Is it not shameful that they had no shame?”

Zigong stood uneasily, shifting from foot to foot.

The wisdom of the Three Sovereigns also defied the principles of Heaven and Earth’s creation. Earlier passages often exalted the Three Sovereigns while disparaging the Five Emperors, but here even the Three Sovereigns are condemned. *Yichai* refers to wasps and the like, whose tails bear venom. *Xian* means “few.” *Gui* means “to seek.” Small beasts seek little—foxes and the like—yet their cunning is as poisonous as this. Even small creatures are mocked and belittled. *Can* means “venomous.” *Cujuan* describes an uneasy, restless demeanor.

Confucius said to Lao Dan: “I have studied the Six Classics—*Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, *Music*, *Changes*, and *Spring and Autumn*—for a long time, and I believe I understand their essence. Yet in advising seventy-two rulers, expounding the Way of the former kings and clarifying the borders of Zhou and Shao, not one ruler took up my counsel. How difficult it is to persuade people, and how hard to make the Dao clear!”

Laozi said: “Fortunate indeed that you have not encountered a ruler of a well-ordered age. The Six Classics are but the worn-out traces of the former kings—how could they be the true borders? What you speak of are merely traces. Traces are what shoes produce, but are traces the shoes themselves?”

The *Record of Rites* also records Laozi addressing sages by name, likely during Confucius’s inquiry about rites when he took him as his teacher. “Understood their essence” means he grasped their origins and precedents. “Fortunate not to have encountered” implies that had he met an ancient sage, he would have been ridiculed. Where there are shoes, there are footprints. One may follow the traces but not obtain the shoes themselves—this is like the metaphor of dregs and糟粕.

When white egrets gaze at one another, their pupils do not move, yet they conceive through the wind. When male insects chirp on the windward side, females respond on the leeward, and they conceive through the wind. Each kind produces its own male and female, hence they conceive through the wind. Nature cannot be altered, fate cannot be changed, time cannot be halted, and the Dao cannot be blocked. If one attains the Dao, there is nothing that cannot be done, and nothing that can be lost.

Three months later, Confucius returned and said: “I have grasped it! Crows and magpies rear their young, fish spawn in foam, the slender-waisted transform, and the elder brother weeps for his younger brother—how long has this been so? I, Qiu, do not transform with others into a person; if I do not transform with others into a person, how can I transform others?”

Laozi said: “Good. You have grasped it.”

This passage is among the most extraordinary. Male and female egrets do not mate but conceive merely by gazing at one another. All things are born of the wind. The character for “wind” (*feng*) contains the radical for “insect” (*chong*), implying the power to generate life, hence “wind-transformation” refers to reproduction. When insects chirp on the windward side and respond on the leeward, it signifies their positions above and below. The Yellow Emperor followed the leeward path, which aligns with this. Here, the word “wind” differs from “wind-transformation.” “Each kind produces its own male and female” means that within all things, male and female exist as distinct categories, and thus they conceive through wind. The ichneumon wasp transforms the grub of the *gualei* through incantation, but this is a different kind of transformation—here, conception occurs through mutual gaze. Nature, fate, time, and the Dao all refer to the unalterable principles of spontaneity.

Crows and magpies rear their young; fish spawn in foam; the slender-waisted transform; and the elder brother weeps for his younger brother—how long has this been so?

The slender-waisted is the bee. *Hua* (化) refers to spontaneous generation. When a younger brother is born and the elder brother weeps, it is because siblings of the same mother must first wean from the breast before the next is born—thus, the elder is deprived of milk upon the arrival of the younger, hence the elder’s weeping. This phrase is particularly extraordinary; such passages abound in Buddhist scriptures, for they encompass the finest subtleties of literary art—these must not be overlooked.

Those who "do not unite with transformation to become human" speak of knowing humanity but not Heaven, unable to merge with the creative workings of nature. This chapter expounds the principle of ceaseless generation through transformation, illustrating the Dao of spontaneity. It suggests that what Confucians study consists of *wei*-action rather than *wuwei*-nonaction; only *wuwei*-nonaction achieves the same efficacy as the workings of nature.

The Buddhist categories of birth—womb-born, egg-born, transformation-born, and moisture-born—likely derive from this, though their intent differs: they seek to show that this body arises from nothingness to existence, just as all things do, thereby breaking the worldly attachments of self-cherishing and self-adoration.

The *Oral Exegesis of the Southern Florescence Scripture*, Volume Sixteen, concludes here.

---
*The supreme joy first responds to human affairs, accords with the principles of Heaven, enacts the Five Virtues, and aligns with spontaneity; only then does it harmonize the four seasons and bring perfect harmony to the myriad things.*

The *Oral Exegesis of the Southern Florescence Scripture*, Volume Seventeen, by Lin Xiang of Yongzhai.

**Outer Chapters: Carving Intentions**

Those who carve intentions and esteem conduct, distancing themselves from the world and differing from common customs, indulging in lofty discourse and resentful slander—this is but arrogance. Such are the mountain-valley scholars, those who reject the world, those who delight in withering solitude and plunging into the abyss.

Those who speak of benevolence and righteousness, loyalty and trust, reverence and frugality, deference and yielding—this is but cultivation. Such are the scholars of an orderly age, the teachers of the world, those who delight in travel, residence, and learning.

Those who speak of great achievements, establishing great renown, honoring the rites between ruler and minister, rectifying superior and inferior—this is but governance. Such are the scholars of the court, those who exalt the sovereign and strengthen the state, those who delight in achieving merit and annexing lands.

Those who dwell in marshes and wilds, abide in seclusion and vastness, fish and idle—this is but nonaction. Such are the scholars of rivers and seas, those who flee the world, those who delight in leisure and repose.

Those who practice breath control, exhaling the old and inhaling the new, imitating the bear’s climbing and the bird’s stretching—this is but longevity. Such are the practitioners of Daoist arts, those who nurture the body, those who delight in the long-lived like Pengzu.

Yet there are those who, without carving intentions, attain loftiness; without benevolence and righteousness, achieve cultivation; without merit and fame, bring order; without rivers and seas, find repose; without Daoist arts, attain longevity. They forget nothing, yet lack nothing. Serene and boundless, all virtues follow them—this is the Dao of Heaven and Earth, the virtue of the sage.

*Carving* means sculpting, laboring with intent to esteem conduct. *Arrogance* is loftiness. *Resentful slander* is indignation at worldly corruption. *Rejecting the world* is debating the right and wrong of worldly affairs. *Withering solitude* is desolation. *Plunging into the abyss* is seeking profound stillness—like those who fear the forest is not secluded enough or the mountains not deep enough.

*Cultivation* is delighting in refinement. *Teachers of the world* are those who instruct others. *Achieving merit and annexing lands* reflects the realities Zhuangzi observed in his time.

*Fleeing the world in leisure* describes recluses, those who escape society and transcend right and wrong, differing from the arrogant and world-rejecting.

*Imitating the bear’s climbing and the bird’s stretching* refers to Hua Tuo’s *Five Animal Exercises*.

*Forgetting nothing, lacking nothing* is the same as *nonaction yet nothing left undone*. *Boundless* means without fixed limits. *All virtues follow* means possessing all goodness. The sage embodies the natural Dao of Heaven and Earth, hence this state.

Thus it is said: "Serenity, stillness, emptiness, nonbeing, and nonaction—this is the equilibrium of Heaven and Earth and the essence of the Dao and virtue." Therefore, the sage, resting in ease, is level and yielding; being level and yielding, he is serene and still. Serene and still, worries and troubles cannot enter, and perverse qi cannot assail. Thus his virtue is whole, and his spirit is unharmed.

This entire passage, from here onward, strings together many "thus it is said" phrases, culminating in a parable and concluding with a rustic saying—observe closely the ebb and flow of his brushwork.

The *essence* of the Dao and virtue is their natural state. *Level and yielding, serene and still*—this is the meaning of nonaction. *Spirit unharmed* is the same as *virtue whole*. These three characters heighten the vitality.

Thus it is said: "The sage’s life is the movement of Heaven; his death is the transformation of things. At rest, he shares the virtue of yin; in motion, he flows with the waves of yang. He does not precede fortune nor initiate misfortune. He responds only after being moved, acts only when compelled, rises only when unavoidable. Abandoning cunning and contrivance, he follows the principles of Heaven. Thus he suffers no heavenly disasters, no burdens from things, no human reproach, no ghostly blame. His life is like floating; his death is like repose. He neither schemes nor plans. Radiant yet not dazzling, trustworthy yet not demanding. In sleep, he does not dream; awake, he has no worries. His spirit is pure; his soul is not weary."

*Movement of Heaven* means acting in accord with Heaven’s principles. *Transformation of things* means viewing the body like a cast-off husk. *Flowing with the waves* means moving with the current. Responding only after being moved means having no preconceptions, thus transcending fortune and misfortune. *Acting only when compelled, rising only when unavoidable*—this is the meaning of responding to things without intent.

*Cunning* is private cleverness. *Contrivance* is adherence to past methods. Abandoning private cleverness and departing from past methods, one follows nature.

*Like floating, like repose*—this is the meaning of being unattached. *Neither scheming nor planning*—this is the same as "what thought, what worry?" *Radiant yet not dazzling*—this is self-effacement. *Trustworthy yet not demanding*—this is not seeking anything from things.

His spirit is whole, hence pure; his soul is still, hence not weary. *Weary* is the same as *fatigued*.

Thus it is said: "Sorrow and joy are perversions of virtue; delight and anger are transgressions of the Dao; likes and dislikes are lapses of virtue." Therefore, a heart free from sorrow and joy is the perfection of virtue; unchanging unity is the perfection of stillness; encountering nothing contrary is the perfection of emptiness; not engaging with things is the perfection of serenity; meeting nothing adverse is the perfection of purity.

If there is sorrow and joy, delight and anger, likes and dislikes, it is not natural. Only when worries and joys do not bind the heart is virtue perfected. *Unchanging unity* means focusing on one without distraction. *Encountering nothing contrary* means following nature. *Contrary* means opposition. *Not engaging with things* means responding only after being moved—though interacting with things, one is not burdened by them.

*Stillness, emptiness, serenity, purity*—these all describe the virtue of spontaneity, thus elaborated.

*Contrary* and *adverse* are similar, but *adverse* is deeper, hence two separate phrases. *Purity* means without flaw.

Thus it is said: "When the body labors without rest, it becomes worn; when essence is used without cease, it becomes exhausted; exhaustion leads to depletion. Water, by nature, is clear when unadulterated, level when undisturbed. If obstructed and not flowing, it cannot remain clear—this is the image of Heaven’s virtue."

Thus it is said: "Pure and unadulterated, still and unchanging, serene and nonactive, moving in accord with Heaven’s movement—this is the Dao of nurturing the spirit."

The body’s labor leads to wear, the use of essence leads to exhaustion—these are the earnest words of those who cultivate life, echoing the earlier passage: *"Only by not agitating one’s essence can one attain longevity."* Labor, if unceasing, must lead to depletion, hence it is said: *"Exhaustion leads to depletion."* The water analogy, though seemingly commonplace, reveals a deeper truth: *"If obstructed and not flowing, it cannot remain clear."* This is not the same as withered wood or dead ashes.

*"Unadulterated, it is clear; undisturbed, it is level"*—this is nonaction. *"Not flowing, it cannot remain clear"*—within nonaction, there is action. As Xiangyan said: *"One cannot merely sit idly."* To be obstructed and not flowing is what Chan Buddhists call *"sitting in a ghost’s den"*—the so-called *"silent illumination"* heresy.

Heaven’s movement completes a cycle each day—is this not action within nonaction? Thus it is called *"the image of Heaven’s virtue."*

Nurturing the spirit is nurturing life. To invoke the word *"spirit"* is to make it intimate—this is the learning of the Daoists. The Buddhists, however, refuse to speak of such a *"spirit."* When they say *"from beginningless time"* or call the *"root of birth and death"* the *"original self,"* they are merely evading this term.

A sword of Gan and Yue is treasured in a case and never used—this is the height of reverence. The spirit flows in all four directions, reaching everywhere, ascending to Heaven, coiling upon the earth, transforming and nourishing the myriad things, yet leaving no trace—it is called the *"Dao of unified simplicity with the Emperor."* Only the spirit is to be guarded; guard it without loss, and you become one with the spirit. The unity of essence penetrates and harmonizes with Heaven’s order.

To treasure a sword is to keep it cased and hidden—how much more so the spirit? This is the analogy for *"the use of essence leads to exhaustion."* *"Flowing in all four directions, coiling below and ascending above"* describes the spirit’s function. The transformation and nourishment of the myriad things are also the work of this spirit. Yet no trace is visible, hence it is said: *"no image can be made of it."*

*"Unified with the Emperor"* means its function is equal to that of Heaven’s Emperor. Those who practice *"pure simplicity"* begin by guarding only the spirit, preserving it without loss. Through long practice, they become one with the spirit—this is the time of *"great transformation."* Before transformation, one remains separate from the Dao; after transformation, one is one with the Dao.

*"Heaven’s order"* is Heaven’s principle. Unity, taken to its utmost refinement, merges with Heaven—this is what is called *"sagely and unknowable spirit."*

This chapter aligns closely with my own writings, yet its stirring and dynamic expression veers into heterodoxy. A rustic saying goes: *"The common people value profit, the upright value reputation, the worthy uphold aspiration, the sages treasure essence."* Thus, *"simplicity"* means having nothing mixed in; *"purity"* means not diminishing one’s spirit. One who embodies pure simplicity is called a *"Perfected Person."*

*"Rustic saying"* refers to folk adages, like proverbs. *"The sages treasure essence"*—*"essence"* here is the spirit. The three preceding lines—profit, reputation, aspiration—frame this final line. *"Simplicity"* is undivided color, hence *"nothing is mixed in."* *"Purity"* is whole, hence *"nothing is diminished."* *"Pure simplicity"* is the *"pure and refined essence"* of Qian. The *"Perfected Person"* is the *"Ultimate Person."*

Earlier, it spoke of *"the virtue of the sage,"* and now of the *"Perfected Person"*—just as the *Inner Chapters* say *"the Ultimate Person has no self, the Spirit Person has no name."* These are merely different names for the sage, not that the Perfected Person or Ultimate Person surpass the sage.

The *"Cultivating Intent"* chapter discusses nurturing the spirit with theories of Heaven’s movement and the transformation of things, while the *"Mending Nature"* chapter speaks of preserving the body with doctrines of fate and misguided conduct. Dividing the cultivation of spirit and the preservation of the body into two chapters reveals the distinction in their methods of study. Readers who fail to examine this carefully betray Zhuangzi’s intent across the ages.

The *"Mending Nature"* chapter of the *Outer Chapters* states:
*"Mending nature through vulgar learning to seek a return to one’s origin, drowning desires in worldly thoughts to pursue fame—these are the benighted masses."*

*"Mending nature"* means cultivating one’s nature. *"Mending nature through vulgar learning"* critiques the Confucian and Mohist discourses on human nature of the time. *"Origin"* is the principle of spontaneity—one’s nature. *"Drowning"* means being submerged. *"Drowning desires in the vulgar"* means being submerged in worldly desires. *"Brightness"* is the principle of emptiness and clarity. To cultivate one’s nature through vulgar learning in pursuit of returning to the original principle of reason, or to be drowned in desires while seeking the state of emptiness and clarity—these are the most ignorant, those devoid of knowledge. Such are called the *"benighted masses"*—a term for the foolishness of vulgar learning.

The opening of this passage is most striking, beginning with such force. Only after three sentences does it speak of *"those who cultivated the Dao in ancient times"*—truly fine writing. As Su Dongpo said: *"Reading Zhuangzi, I grasped the method of writing, and only after practicing it did I understand."*

*"Those who cultivated the Dao in ancient times nurtured knowledge with tranquility, living without employing knowledge—this is called nurturing tranquility with knowledge."* Knowledge and tranquility nurture each other, and harmony and principle emerge from one’s nature.

*"Virtue"* is harmony; *"Dao"* is principle. *"Virtue admits all"* is benevolence; *"Dao orders all"* is righteousness. *"Righteousness is clear, and things draw near"* is loyalty. *"Centered, pure, and returning to emotion"* is joy. *"Trust in conduct, receptivity in form, and compliance with pattern"* is ritual. If ritual and music are practiced in isolation, the world falls into chaos.

If one rectifies others while obscuring one’s own virtue, virtue is no longer all-embracing. If virtue is not all-embracing, things lose their nature.

*"Tranquility"* is stillness and stability; stability gives rise to wisdom, hence *"nurturing knowledge with tranquility."* Knowing that in the beginning of one’s existence there was originally nothing—what is there to employ knowledge for? Only then can one attain stillness and stability, hence *"nurturing tranquility with knowledge."* When these two nurture each other, one recovers one’s natural nature.

*"Principle"* means compliance; *"harmony and principle"* is another way of saying *"harmony and compliance."*

Stillness and stability recover one’s original, harmonious, and compliant nature—hence *"harmony and principle emerge from nature."* The term *"nature"* is synonymous with *"natural."* *"Nurturing knowledge with tranquility, nurturing tranquility with knowledge"*—these six characters are most profound. The Buddhists say: *"Precepts give rise to stability; stability gives rise to wisdom."* Yet they do not speak of wisdom giving rise to stability. Such passages merit careful study.

Virtue and the Dao are themselves harmony and compliance—hence *"virtue"* means *"harmony,"* and *"Dao"* means *"principle."* *"Nothing is not embraced"* is *"nothing is not loved,"* and *"nothing is not ordered"* is *"each attains its proper place."* Only when righteousness is luminous within can one be intimate with things—this is exhausting oneself for others, which is called *"loyalty."* Emotion is that which manifests outwardly. When the true purity of the center is expressed externally, and one returns from outward manifestation to seek the center, joy is born—once born, how can it be restrained? Thus, *"inner purity and sincerity returning to emotion"* is *"joy."*

Trusting in the conduct of one’s bearing and following the natural patterns of refinement is to move and turn in accord with ritual in all things. Hence, *"trusting in conduct and bearing, complying with pattern"* is *"ritual."* *"Trust"* means *"to rely upon,"* and *"trusting in conduct"* is like *"acting with ease."* Seeking ritual and music externally while ignorant of their root is called *"practicing in isolation,"* as if seeing only half the matter. *"Obscuring"* means *"concealing."* When virtue accumulates within without self-display, things naturally rectify themselves—hence *"rectifying others while obscuring one’s own virtue."* *"Not all-embracing"* means one does not impose virtue upon others. If virtue is not concealed but sought to be imposed, it loses its naturalness—hence *"if all-embracing is lost, things necessarily lose their nature."* Ruling the world through goodness is not as good as nurturing the world through goodness—this is the meaning here.

In ancient times, people dwelled in primordial obscurity, attaining tranquility and indifference with their age. At that time, yin and yang were harmonious and still, spirits and gods did not disturb, the four seasons kept their rhythm, the myriad things were unharmed, and the multitude of living beings did not die prematurely. Though humans possessed knowledge, there was nothing to employ it for—this was called *"perfect unity."* At that time, nothing was done, yet all was constantly natural.

*"Primordial obscurity"* means *"concealed and not self-displaying."* *"Tranquil and indifferent"* suggests no seeking between above and below. The entire world was pure and complete, lacking nothing in the Dao—hence *"perfect unity."* *"Nothing was done"* means no effort was required. *"Spirits and gods did not disturb"* means mountains, rivers, spirits, and gods were all at peace. *"The four seasons kept their rhythm"* means heaven and earth followed their order, and the four seasons unfolded.

When virtue declined, it reached the era of Suiren and Fuxi, who first ruled the world—thus, compliance was achieved, but not unity. When virtue declined further, it reached the era of Shennong and the Yellow Emperor, who first ruled the world—thus, peace was achieved, but not compliance. When virtue declined yet further, it reached the era of Tang and Yu, who initiated the currents of governance and transformation. Simplicity dissolved, and purity scattered; they departed from the Dao to pursue goodness, flaunted virtue to enact policies, then abandoned nature to follow the heart. Hearts and minds recognized one another, yet knowledge was insufficient to stabilize the world. Only then did they append refinement and augment it with breadth. Refinement destroyed substance, and breadth drowned the heart—thereafter, the people began to be confused and disordered, unable to return to their nature and emotions and recover their origin.

These three declines each exhibit their own peculiarities.

Once one recognizes that principle may be followed, the pure and unified has already departed—hence, "compliance without unity." When each person takes principle as their security, they become aware of the self; aware of the self, they depart from the Dao—hence, "peace without compliance." When one deliberately acts for the world and initiates its teachings and transformations, it is no longer non-action or spontaneity—hence, "simplicity dissolved, and purity scattered." *Li* means dissipation. To possess the name of goodness is already to distance oneself from the Dao; to make virtue visible in action is to render it no longer plain and spontaneous—hence, "departing from the Dao to pursue goodness, flaunting virtue to enact policies." *Xian* means not plain or spontaneous. To abandon one’s natural nature and follow the heart of deliberate action—hence, "abandoning nature to follow the heart." I act with intention, and others respond in kind—hence, "hearts recognizing one another." *Shi* means mutual recognition and discernment. In such cases, the "heart" is always the blazing heart. *Wen* refers to ornamentation; *bo* refers to the multitude of names and things, the completeness of rites, music, and all affairs. When knowledge proves insufficient, and one appends it with rites and music—hence, "knowledge insufficient to stabilize the world, then appending refinement and augmenting it with breadth." *Bo* means profusion lacking essentials. To apply the heart to such things is like drowning. From this perspective, the world has lost the Dao, and the Dao has lost the world—they mutually lose one another. How can the person of the Dao arise in the world? How can the world arise in the Dao? If the Dao cannot arise in the world, and the world cannot arise in the Dao, then even if the sage does not dwell in the mountains and forests, their virtue is concealed. Concealment is not self-concealment. The Dao and the world mutually lose one another, meaning they do not interpenetrate. If they do not interpenetrate, how can the person of the Dao inspire the world’s perceptions? How can the world’s people come to know the Dao? When the entire world does not know the Dao, even if the sage stands before them, they remain unaware. It is not that the sage conceals themselves; others do not recognize them, and thus they are concealed without seeking concealment—hence, "concealment is not self-concealment." The reason for their concealment is not that the sage deliberately hides, but that they stand before others unrecognized. These five characters below are also striking.

The ancients’ so-called "recluses" did not crouch in concealment nor refuse to appear; they did not seal their words nor withhold their knowledge. It was the great perversity of the times. When the times aligned with their destiny and they could fully act in the world, they returned to unity without trace. When the times did not align and they were greatly constrained in the world, they deeply rooted themselves, settled in stillness, and awaited their moment. This is the way of preserving the self. Following the above discussion of "concealment," the text now turns to recluses. Such scholars did not wish to hide their bodies, seal their words, or conceal their knowledge—it was the times that were unfit. *Concealing knowledge* means appearing foolish when the state lacks the Dao. *The times were greatly perverse* means they were profoundly at odds with destiny; *miu* means opposition. *Returning to unity without trace* means achieving success without possession, allowing the Dao to be practiced while entrusting things to non-intention. What lies within me is unity alone—hence, "returning to unity." *Root and extremity* refer to one’s fundamental nature; *ji* means cessation. *Deeply rooting* is like retreating into secrecy; *settling in stillness* is like "calm your cessation." Preserving the self to await the moment—hence, "deeply rooting, settling in stillness, and awaiting"—preserving the self is preserving the self.

The ancients who conducted themselves in the world did not adorn their knowledge with eloquence, did not exhaust the world with their knowledge, nor exhaust virtue with their knowledge. Solemnly abiding in their place and returning to their nature—what more was there to do? The Dao is not to be practiced in petty ways; virtue is not to be known in petty ways. Petty knowledge harms virtue; petty action harms the Dao. Hence, it is said: "Rectify the self and that is all." To delight in wholeness is called "attaining one’s aspirations." Following the discussion of "preserving the self," the text now speaks of "conducting oneself." *Preserving* pertains to times of non-use; *conducting* pertains to times of use. *Not adorning knowledge with eloquence* means not embellishing one’s insights with florid words. *Not exhausting the world with knowledge* means not daring to use one’s surplus. *Not exhausting virtue with knowledge* means using knowledge without losing one’s natural nature. *Solemnly abiding in their place* means standing in loftiness. *Returning to their nature* is the same as "returning to unity without trace." Non-action is the greatness of the Dao; deliberate action is petty conduct, and petty conduct harms the Dao. Unknowing and unperceiving are the greatness of virtue; having knowledge and perception is petty knowledge, and petty knowledge loses virtue. Rectifying the self causes things to rectify themselves—one does not initially seek to rectify things—hence, "rectify the self and that is all." Taking this as joy means that what is joyful is complete; one’s gratification lies here, not in external things. *Attaining one’s aspirations* is like gratification; these two characters generate the following passage.

The ancients’ so-called "attaining one’s aspirations" did not refer to carriages and caps of office—it meant that nothing could augment their joy. Today’s so-called "attaining one’s aspirations" refers to carriages and caps of office. Carriages and caps on the body are not one’s nature or destiny. Their arrival is fortuitous, a lodging. When lodged, their coming cannot be resisted, nor their going halted—thus, one does not indulge their aspirations for carriages and caps, nor conform to custom in poverty and constraint. Their joy is the same in both, hence they are without sorrow. If one is unhappy when the lodging departs, then even in joy there is distraction. Hence, it is said: "Those who lose themselves in things and their nature in custom are called inverted people." One who is sufficient within seeks nothing without—hence, "nothing can augment their joy," for all things are complete within the self. Turning inward in sincerity, joy is unbounded. Nature and destiny are the heavenly nobility; carriages and caps are external things. Their arrival is accidental—hence, "fortuitous." Going and staying lie with them, not with me—hence, "lodging."

These three characters are exquisitely placed. Knowing that their coming and going cannot be certain, the enlightened are neither unrestrained in prosperity nor bent in adversity—hence, "one does not indulge their aspirations for carriages and caps, nor conform to custom in poverty and constraint." To "conform to custom" is to bend the self to follow the times. "That" refers to the Dao. Their joy in the Dao is the same as others' joy in carriages and caps—hence, "their joy is the same in both." If joy resides within the self, there is no moment when sorrow can arise; if joy depends on external things, then when those things depart, joy departs with them. Since their joy has coming and going, it is not true joy—hence, "even in joy there is distraction." "Inverted" means not knowing root from branch. The self and nature are the root; things and custom are the branch. To value the branch and lose the root is called "inverted people." This entire passage is a seamless text—one must carefully observe how it binds the end to the beginning and connects what follows to what precedes.

*End of the Seventeenth Scroll of the Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of Nanhua*
#1 "Spirit": The Ming edition reads "virtue/power."
#2 "Custom": The original text reads "custom custom"; one "custom" is deleted following the Ming edition.
#3 "Pure unity": The Ming edition reads "pure and unified."

*Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of Nanhua, Eighteenth Scroll*
By Lin Xi of Yuanzhai

**Outer Chapters: "Autumn Floods"**

When the autumn floods came, the hundred rivers poured into the Yellow River. The turbid currents swelled so vast that between its two banks and the isles within, one could not distinguish ox from horse. Thereupon the River Lord rejoiced, exulting that all the world’s beauty was his alone. Following the current eastward to the Northern Sea, he turned to face the east and saw no end to the waters. Then the River Lord at last turned his countenance, gazed across the ocean toward Ruo, and sighed:

There is a rustic saying: “Hearing of the Dao a hundred times, one thinks none can compare to oneself.” That describes me. Moreover, I once heard of those who belittled Confucius’s learning and made light of Boyi’s righteousness—I did not believe it at first. Now I have witnessed the boundlessness of your realm. Had I not come to your gate, I would have remained in peril. I would long have been ridiculed by those of great attainment.

*Turbid*: The Yellow River’s waters surge in and churn muddy, filling both banks—hence “the vastness of the turbid flow.” *Two banks*: This is not the Jing of “Jing and Wei.” *Isles and shores*: The isles within the river. The two characters *zhu* and *ya* carry equal weight; if *ya* were glossed as “boundary,” the phrase below would not cohere. *Unable to distinguish ox from horse*: Seen from afar, things are unclear. *No end to the waters*: One cannot know the water’s source. *Ocean*: The expanse of the sea. *Ruo*: The name of a sea deity.

The myriad principles of the world—if one has heard but a hundred, one thinks oneself abundant. The phrase “hearing of the Dao a hundred times” seems an ancient saying, its meaning directed at Confucius and Boyi, hence the analogy of rivers and seas.

*Great attainment*: The great Dao.

The Northern Sea’s Ruo said: “You cannot speak of the sea to a frog in a well—it is confined by its dwelling. You cannot speak of ice to a summer insect—it is bound by its season. You cannot speak of the Dao to a narrow scholar—he is shackled by his teachings. Now that you have emerged from your banks and beheld the great sea, you know your own inadequacy. You may now be spoken to of great principles.

No water in the world is greater than the sea. The ten thousand rivers return to it, yet it never fills, though they flow without cease. The Tail Pool drains it, yet it never empties, though it flows without end. Unchanged through spring and autumn, unmoved by flood or drought—its surpassing of the rivers’ flow cannot be measured. Yet I have never taken pride in this, for I compare my form to heaven and earth and receive qi from yin and yang. I stand between heaven and earth as a pebble or twig stands in a great mountain. Aware of my own smallness, how could I take pride?

*Confined by its dwelling*: Limited to its abode. *Bound by its season*: Knowing only one time, like the cicada unaware of spring and autumn. *Knows its own inadequacy*: Recognizes its own shame. *Tail Pool*: The Scorched Waste, mentioned in the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*—where the sea’s waters vanish as soon as they arrive.

Comparing the sea to heaven and earth, one sees only its smallness—how could one know its greatness? As the Chan masters say: “Even the greatest must rise from the earth; beyond the highest, there is still heaven.” This is the meaning here.

Consider the four seas within heaven and earth—are they not like a crevice in a great marsh? Consider the Central States within the seas—are they not like a grain of millet in a granary? The number of things is called ten thousand, yet man occupies but one. The nine provinces teem with people, where grain is grown and boats and carts travel—yet man occupies but one. Compared to the ten thousand things, is he not like the tip of a hair on a horse’s body?

What the Five Emperors inherited, what the Three Kings contended for, what the benevolent lamented, what the capable toiled over—all is encompassed here. Boyi renounced it to gain fame; Confucius discoursed on it to display his erudition. Their self-regard was no different from your former pride in your waters.

*Crevice*: A small hole, like a wasp’s nest. *Teeming people*: The multitude. Man is but one among the ten thousand things—this is reckoned within the vastness of the cosmos, considering all that can be named. Within the nine provinces, he is but one among grasses, trees, birds, and beasts. These two lines are exquisitely phrased. As Le Xuan said: “Though heaven and earth are vast and the human body small, a fist-sized stone in the void makes a splendid journey.” This is the meaning.

The world is so small that the knowledge and abilities of the Five Emperors, Three Kings, and all the sages and worthies do not exceed it. Such words are vast and profound, yet they hold truth. Boyi renounced it for fame; Confucius discoursed on it for breadth—who before has spoken thus?

*Capable scholar*: One who undertakes affairs, meaning those who govern the world.

The River Lord said: “Then may I consider heaven and earth great and the tip of a hair small?”

The Northern Sea’s Ruo said: “No. The measure of things is boundless, time has no end, divisions are not constant, beginnings and endings are not fixed. Thus the great-minded observe near and far: small yet not meager, great yet not excessive. Knowing measure is boundless, they verify the past and present—thus distant yet not weary, grasping yet not straining. Knowing time has no end, they discern fullness and emptiness—thus gaining without joy, losing without sorrow. Knowing divisions are not constant, they understand the level path—thus living without delight, dying without calamity, knowing beginnings and endings cannot be fixed.

What man knows is less than what he does not know; the time of his life is less than the time before his birth. To seek the limits of the greatest with the smallest is to become lost and unable to find one’s way. From this perspective, how can one know the tip of a hair suffices to define the finest boundary? How can one know heaven and earth suffice to exhaust the greatest realm?”

This turn of speech is also fine. Earlier, it spoke of greatness; here, it speaks of no small and no great—just as it is said: “Nothing in the world is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small.”

The measure of things is boundless—this means things cannot be measured or delimited. Time knows no pause—this means cold and heat, day and night follow one another without end. Divisions are not constant—this means being and non-being, gain and loss, the apportionments of men, may come first or last, with no fixed order. Beginnings and endings know no precedent—this means there is no end and no beginning, no new and no old.

Thus, those of great wisdom—those with profound understanding—are the ones who attain the four insights that follow. Observing the distant as if near, they do not regard size as determining quantity, and so they know measure is without limit. *Zheng xiang* means to examine and clarify. *Jin gu* means past and present. Understanding that past and present are one, they welcome what has not yet arrived without anxiety, though distant, and do not strain to grasp what is easily taken, though near. Only by awaiting it do they know time has no fixed pause. Fullness is gain; emptiness is loss. The waxing and waning of fullness and emptiness move with time, and not taking this as cause for joy or resentment, they know apportionments are not constant. Understanding the level path is to recognize the true Dao. Following the true Dao, they let life and death take their course—this is the meaning of "longevity and early death are not two, cultivate the self and await it." Understanding this, they know endings cannot be treated as precedents for beginnings. This is the teaching of tracing origins and grasping ends.

What man knows is man; what he does not know is heaven. For example, after birth, I know it; before birth, how could I know it? This is like the Chan saying: "the phrase of the Dao before father and mother were born." The smallest is the self; the greatest is heaven. To seek to exhaust heaven’s vastness with the self’s smallness is to become lost and disquieted—these few lines, in Chan terms, would be a great *gong’an*. Zhuangzi, however, speaks of it casually.

What follows, from "those of great wisdom" onward, explains the preceding lines. The phrasing expands and contracts, long and short, even yet uneven—this is the art of prose. *Ni* means tip; *yu* means realm. Speaking of the small, there is no tip; exhausting the great, there is no realm. Thus it is said: how can one define the finest tip? How can one exhaust the greatest realm?

The River Lord said: "Those who discuss the world all say the most refined has no form, the greatest cannot be encompassed—is this true?"

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: "One who views the great from the small cannot see it all; one who views the small from the great cannot see it clearly. The refined is the subtlest of the small; *fu* is the fullness of the great. Thus, differences arise—this is the nature of things. The refined and the coarse are limited to what has form. What has no form cannot be divided by number. What cannot be encompassed cannot be exhausted by number. What can be discussed in words is the coarse aspect of things. What can be grasped by intention is the refined aspect. What words cannot discuss, what intention cannot fathom, does not depend on refinement or coarseness.

This turn of speech is also fine. The most refined has no form—this is the subtle, not merely the smallest. To say "most refined" rather than "smallest" is where the language comes alive. *Xin qing* means: does one truly believe this statement? Viewing the great from the small cannot exhaust it—like peering at the sky through a tube. Viewing the small from the great cannot clarify it—like the roc bird looking down at wild horses and dust. The subtlest of the small is called *jing*—smaller and smaller. The fullest of the great is called *fu*—greater and greater. *Yin* means fullness. *Yi bian* means what is fitting differs. Introducing these two lines in the context of small and great is also exquisite. The formless small cannot be divided by number—whether hair or feather, it cannot be done. The unencompassable great cannot be exhausted by number—whether *ti* or *zhao*, it cannot be done. All things, refined or coarse, are confined to form, so they can be discussed in words and inferred by intention. But if the small and the great have no form, then words cannot discuss them, and intention cannot reach their limits. Since they are formless, one cannot speak of them in terms of refinement or coarseness—thus it is said they do not depend on refinement or coarseness. *Cha zhi* means to examine their utmost.

Therefore, the conduct of the great person does not extend to harming others, nor does it abound in benevolence and kindness. Their actions are not for profit, nor do they despise gatekeepers and servants. They do not contend over wealth, nor do they excessively defer to others. In affairs, they do not rely on others, nor do they overindulge in their own strength. They do not despise the greedy and corrupt, and their conduct differs from the common, though not excessively so. They follow the crowd without despising flatterers. The world’s ranks and emoluments are insufficient to encourage them; disgrace and punishment are insufficient to shame them. They know right and wrong cannot be fixed as divisions, nor can the fine and the great be defined as boundaries.

It is said: the Daoist does not strive, the one of utmost virtue does not attain, the great person has no self—this is the ultimate in moderation. Though they do not harm things, neither do they take loving things as their ability—thus it is said they do not extend to harming others. Not abounding in benevolence and kindness refers to gatekeepers and menial laborers who seek profit. As it is said: "Even if it were holding a whip, I would do it." Though I do not seek profit, neither do I regard those who seek profit through menial labor as wrong—thus it is said their actions are not for profit, and they do not despise gatekeepers. If one harbors the thought of despising menial labor while exalting oneself, one leaves traces. I do not contend over wealth, nor do I take deference as ability—thus it is said they do not contend over wealth, nor do they excessively defer. To take deference as one’s abundance is to approach fame. In all affairs, they act for themselves without relying on others, yet they do not exhaust their strength to feed themselves—thus it is said they do not rely on others in affairs, nor do they overindulge in their own strength. To say "not overindulging in strength" means they do not dare to use it all. They do not despise the greedy and corrupt—you are you, I am I—thus it is said they do not despise the greedy and corrupt.

Their conduct is truly different from others, yet they do not deliberately set themselves apart—thus it is said their actions diverge from the common, yet they do not excessively cultivate eccentricity. *Bi* means "perverse"; *bi yi* means "deliberate eccentricity." To act is to follow the multitude, blending light and merging with dust. They do not despise the fawning and obsequious, dwelling with them in ease, for such men cannot taint their intent. "Not despising" means they do not revile or loathe them. Such people make no distinctions of right and wrong, merging the great and the small—these are the men of the Dao, of utmost virtue, the great ones. "Not hearing" means namelessness. "Not obtaining" means neither gain nor loss. "Restricting one’s portion" means aligning with the utmost principle in its utmost simplicity and fulfilling one’s allotted role. *Wen yue* means "I have heard this saying from antiquity." "Restricting one’s portion" is simply another way of saying "fulfilling oneself."

The River Earl said: Beyond things, within things—where do distinctions of noble and base, great and small reach their limit?
The Lord of the Northern Sea said: Viewed through the Dao, things have no nobility or baseness. Viewed through things themselves, each esteems itself and devalues others. Viewed through custom, nobility and baseness do not reside in oneself. Viewed through gradation, if one magnifies what is great in each, then nothing is not great; if one diminishes what is small in each, then nothing is not small. Knowing heaven and earth to be but a grain of millet, knowing the tip of a hair to be a mountain—then the gradations of difference become clear. Viewed through function, if one affirms what each possesses, then nothing is without possession; if one negates what each lacks, then nothing is without lack. Knowing east and west to be opposites yet indispensable to one another—then the boundaries of function are fixed. Viewed through inclination, if one affirms what each affirms, then nothing is not affirmed; if one negates what each negates, then nothing is not negated. Knowing Yao and Jie each affirmed their own way and negated the other—then the tendencies of conduct become clear.

The earlier passage on not despising gatekeepers or the greedy and corrupt is here extended to include nobility and baseness, great and small. "Beyond and within things" means considering things in their external and internal aspects. *Zhi* means "limit." *Wu zhi* means "where does it reach its limit?" Noble and base, great and small—where does one seek their beginnings and endings? Viewed through things, each esteems itself and devalues others, like the pigweed and the *fuling* herb, which may at times be esteemed as imperial. What is unseen in oneself is known in others—this is like the hundred bones and nine orifices, each alternately serving as ruler and subject. This line is particularly well put. "Nobility and baseness do not reside in oneself" expresses the idea that cap and gown come as temporary lodgings.

*Cha* means gradation. If heaven and earth are but a grain of millet, and the tip of a hair rivals Mount Tai, then the numbers of gradation are not worth mentioning—they are plain to see. *Gong fen* means the boundaries of merit and duty. Each fulfills a role as their merit, hence "boundaries of merit." Farmers, merchants, artisans, and traders each exert their strength according to their portion, and the world cannot do without a single one—just as east and west, though opposites, cannot do without one another. *Qu cao* means the inclinations and integrity of one’s conduct. To take Yao as right and Jie as wrong is the natural tendency of conduct. Yet if one were to abolish the unworthy, how would a lord arise? From this, the instability of conduct’s inclinations is evident. Affirming their greatness or smallness, their possession or lack, their rightness or wrongness—this is the meaning of "equalizing things by following their 'that's it.'"

In ancient times, Yao and Shun abdicated and became emperors; Zhi and Kuai abdicated and perished. Tang and Wu contended and became kings; the Duke of Bai contended and was destroyed. From this, we see that the rites of contention and deference, the conduct of Yao and Jie, nobility and baseness—all have their time and cannot be taken as constant. Comparing Yao and Shun with Zhi and Kuai, Tang and Wu with the Duke of Bai—these are all impassioned arguments of the times. Such passages appear frequently; one must observe the flow of the text.

A roof beam can batter a city wall but cannot plug a rat hole—this speaks of different implements. The *qiji* and *hualiu* can gallop a thousand *li* in a day, but they are no match for a wildcat in catching mice—this speaks of different skills. The owl snatches fleas at night and discerns the tip of a hair, but when it emerges in daylight, it glares and cannot see a mountain—this speaks of different natures. Thus it is said: If one takes "this" as the teacher and rejects "that," or takes order as the teacher and rejects disorder—this is not yet to understand the principles of heaven and earth and the conditions of the myriad things. It is like taking heaven as the teacher and rejecting earth, or taking yin as the teacher and rejecting yang—its impracticability is obvious. Yet to persist in such speech without ceasing is either foolishness or deceit.

The abdications of emperors and kings differ; the successions of the Three Dynasties differ. Those who oppose their times and defy custom are called usurpers. Those who align with their times and follow custom are called men of righteousness. The River Earl, silent, asks: How could you know the gate of nobility and baseness, the house of great and small?

A *liang* is a roof beam. *Li* (read as *li*) is a ridgepole. Great and small each have their uses—hence "different implements." The *qiji* and the wildcat each have their abilities—hence "different skills." The owl, an ominous bird, sees clearly at night but is blinded by daylight—its nature differs. Right and wrong, order and disorder cannot be mutually abolished; these are necessities of the human world, hence the analogies to different implements, skills, and natures. Heaven and earth, yin and yang are likewise analogies for their indispensability. Usurpers and men of righteousness are the same as the discussion of Yao and Jie.

The River Earl said: Then what should I do? What should I not do? How should I decide what to accept or reject, what to pursue or abandon? What is my ultimate course?
The Lord of the Northern Sea said: Viewed through the Dao, what is noble? What is base? This is called "reversion and overflow." Without constraint in one’s intent, one greatly obstructs the Dao. What is little? What is much? This is called "decline and bestowal." Without uniformity in one’s conduct, one deviates from the Dao. Solemn as a state with its ruler, impartial in virtue; flowing as a sacrifice with its officiant, impartial in blessing; boundless as the four directions, without boundaries—embracing the myriad things, who bears them up? This is called "without direction."

All things are equal—what is short? What is long? The Dao has no end or beginning; things have death and life. Do not rely on their completion. Now empty, now full, they do not abide in form. Years cannot be lifted; time cannot be halted. Waning and waxing, fullness and emptiness—an end gives rise to a beginning. This is how one speaks of the great meaning’s direction, how one discusses the principle of the myriad things.

Things come to life as if galloping, as if racing—no movement without change, no moment without shift. What should be done? What should not be done? They will transform of themselves.

This question is well asked. Since there is no noble or base, no right or wrong, then how should I decide what to accept or reject? *Yan* means spacious and unconfined. *Fan* means to turn back and seek within. Viewed through the Dao, there is no noble or base, so one turns back to oneself, naturally at ease and expansive—hence "reversion and overflow." If one binds oneself with distinctions of noble and base, right and wrong, one strays far from the Dao—hence "without constraint in one’s intent, one greatly obstructs the Dao." *Jian* means obstruction. Bestowal entails more or less; when bestowal ceases, there is no more or less—hence "decline and bestowal." If one clings to uniformity in conduct, bound by more or less in bestowal, one deviates from the Dao—hence "without uniformity in one’s conduct, one deviates from the Dao." A state has its ruler, a sacrifice its officiant—both illustrate that this heart takes the Dao as its master, without private virtue or private blessing. This heart is vast, like the four directions without limit, so there is no private division—hence "without boundaries." These three sentences, each with its *qi*, are distinctly placed.

All things are complete within me—this is "embracing the myriad things"—yet without private attachment, hence "who bears them up?" *Cheng yi* describes the intent of private attachment. "Without direction" means "without heart." With no heart of my own, things have no short or long, no life or death. "Do not rely on their completion" echoes the earlier "do not assert completion." Fullness and emptiness follow the time; they cannot be fixed—hence "now empty, now full, they do not abide in form." *Bu wei* means "not fixed." Without past or present, years cannot be lifted; without going or coming, time cannot be halted. The "great meaning" is the great Dao.

Things come to life as if galloping, as if racing—this is what is meant by "that which passes is like this." Change and movement never cease. What is to be done? What is not to be done? All is left to nature’s transformation—hence "they will transform of themselves."

The River Earl said: Then what is noble about the Dao?
The Lord of the Northern Sea said: One who knows the Dao necessarily grasps principle; one who grasps principle necessarily understands adaptability; one who understands adaptability does not allow things to harm the self. The one of utmost virtue—fire cannot burn them, water cannot drown them, cold and heat cannot harm them, birds and beasts cannot injure them. This is not to say they slight these things. It means they discern safety and danger, remain composed amid fortune and misfortune, are cautious in approach and retreat—nothing can harm them. Thus it is said: Heaven is within, man is without; virtue resides in heaven. Know the conduct of heaven and man, root it in heaven, rest in attainment. Advance and retreat, bend and stretch—return to the essential and speak of the ultimate.

This question is also well asked. If one simply follows nature’s transformations, then why should man study the Dao? In Zhu Xi’s *Questions and Answers*, Liao Deming once raised this very question, but Zhu Xi did not answer—perhaps it was difficult to explain. Here, Zhuangzi introduces the term *quan* ("adaptability"), and with the phrase "does not allow things to harm the self," the meaning becomes even clearer. It seems Zhuangzi’s grasp of the Dao was intimate, but readers of his book often fail to see through it.

*Dao* is the all-encompassing term; *li* is the principle inherent in each thing. *Quan* is the application that lies within oneself. Only with the complete substance of the Dao does one attain this great function. One who understands adaptability does not allow things to harm the self—they know the weight of things. The four phrases about water, fire, birds, and beasts each use "cannot," then conclude with "this is not to say," showing how forcefully the argument is constructed. *Bo* means to press close. The person of utmost virtue certainly knows that all things follow their allotted course—how could external things harm them? Yet this does not mean they presume to press close to such things and remain unharmed. For example, though death by water or fire is said to be fate, would one willingly throw oneself into water or fire? The following phrase, "cautious in approach and retreat," makes the meaning even clearer—just as Mencius said, "One who knows fate does not stand beneath a crumbling wall."

Discerning safety and danger, settling fortune and misfortune, being cautious in approach and retreat—this is the human heart within the heart of the Dao. How could it all be left to nature’s spontaneity? Here, Zhuangzi is anything but vague or complacent. "Heaven is within, man is without" echoes the earlier passage: "The ruler is the Way of Heaven; the minister is the way of man." "Virtue resides in heaven" refers to natural virtue. Yet the word "know" in "know the conduct of heaven and man" arises from the human heart. Rooted in nature and content with what is attained—hence "root it in heaven, rest in attainment." This sentence belongs to the heart of the Dao. *Wei* means to dwell in peace. *Zhi ti* means advance and retreat. Advancing and retreating, bending and stretching—each follows its principle. This sentence belongs to the human heart, clarifying the essentials of the Dao and the ultimate of principle—hence "return to the essential and speak of the ultimate," much like Mencius’ "return to the simple and speak of the essential."

The River Earl said: What is heaven? What is man?
The Lord of the Northern Sea said: That oxen and horses have four legs is called heaven; that man places a halter on a horse’s head or a ring through an ox’s nose is called man. Thus it is said: Do not let man obliterate heaven; do not let purpose obliterate fate; do not let gain be sacrificed for fame.

Guard it carefully and do not lose it—this is called returning to one’s true nature. These several lines make the distinction between the human heart and the Dao-heart ever clearer. That oxen and horses have four legs is what they receive from heaven; naturally, they are not haltered or pierced, and thus have no need for such things—this is a matter of the human heart. To let man obliterate heaven, to let purpose obliterate fate, to covet gain and be sacrificed for fame—here the human heart flows into peril. The three phrases beginning with “do not” are prohibitive, much like the “four abstentions.” Having known heaven and also known man, if one guards this carefully and does not lose it, then the heavenly principle is preserved whole. Thus it is said: this is called returning to one’s true nature. Fate is the heavenly principle; purpose is human affairs; gain is the gain and loss of gain.

Kui pitied the centipede; the centipede pitied the snake; the snake pitied the wind; the wind pitied the eye; the eye pitied the heart. Kui said to the centipede: “I go forth with one foot, leaping and striding—none is like me.” Now you deploy ten thousand feet—how can you manage it? The centipede said: “Not so. Have you not seen one who spits? When he sprays, the large drops are like pearls, the small like mist, and those that fall in profusion cannot be counted. Now I move my heavenly mechanism without knowing how it is so.”

The centipede said to the snake: “I go forth with many feet yet do not match you who have none—why is this?” The snake said: “How can one alter what the heavenly mechanism moves? What need have I for feet?” The snake said to the wind: “I move my spine and ribs to go forth, and thus have some semblance of form. Now you rise whirling from the Northern Sea and enter whirling into the Southern Sea, yet seem to have no form—why is this?” The wind said: “Indeed, I rise whirling from the Northern Sea and enter whirling into the Southern Sea. Yet if one points at me, I am overcome; if one treads upon me, I am overcome. Nevertheless, to break great trees and topple great houses—only I can do this. Thus to take many small defeats as a great victory is also a great victory—only the sage can do this.”

Kui has no horns, walks on one foot (see the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*). The centipede is the hundred-footed insect; the snake has no feet. From one foot to no feet, all speak of the movement of the heavenly mechanism in its naturalness—this may be called the most marvelous passage in the world. In between, the comparison of the centipede’s feet to human spittle is also wondrous. At the end, it returns to the wind, while the eye and the heart are left unspoken—such shifts in the text are marvelous and yet more marvelous.

*Trendun* describes the manner of walking on one foot; “none is like me” means none resembles me. “How can one alter it?” means it cannot be changed. “Some semblance” means some visible form. *Pengpeng* is the sound of the wind. “Points at me” means to point at the wind with a hand; “treads upon me” means to tread upon the wind with a foot. Within the discussion of the wind, to add the idea of small defeats making a great victory is yet more marvelous—this is like the saying that “the many can overcome heaven, but heaven’s decree overcomes man.” Though small may not overcome, the great victory means that no thing in the world can escape the workings of creation. What is so of itself cannot be violated.

Confucius was traveling in Song when men of Song surrounded him several layers deep, yet he continued his zither playing and singing without pause. Zilu entered and said: “How can you be so at ease, Master?” Confucius said: “Come, let me tell you. I have long avoided adversity, yet cannot escape it—this is fate. I have long sought success, yet cannot attain it—this is timing. When it was the age of Yao and Shun, there were no men in adversity in the world, not because of their wisdom; when it was the age of Jie and Zhou, there were no successful men in the world, not because of their lack of wisdom. Such is the way of the times. One who travels by water does not avoid dragons and serpents—this is the courage of the fisherman; one who travels by land does not avoid rhinoceroses and tigers—this is the courage of the hunter; one who faces blades crossing before him and sees death as life—this is the courage of the stalwart; one who knows that adversity has its fate, that success has its time, and faces great peril without fear—this is the courage of the sage. You may rest now; my fate is in the hands of another.”

Before long, the armored men came forward to apologize: “We thought you were Yang Hu, so we surrounded you. Now that we know you are not, we beg leave to withdraw.” This passage speaks only of the naturalness of timing and fate, which human effort cannot foresee—what is there to fear? In between, the comparison of the fisherman, hunter, and stalwart to the sage also has its own reason. It is meant to make him cease and desist, without need for further words.

Gongsun Long asked Wei Mou: “In my youth, I studied the Way of the former kings; in maturity, I understood the practice of benevolence and righteousness. I united sameness and difference, separated hardness and whiteness, affirmed the un-affirmable, and denied the un-deniable, confounding the wisdom of the hundred schools and exhausting the eloquence of all disputants—I thought myself most enlightened. Now I hear the words of Zhuangzi and am lost in bewilderment. I do not know whether my reasoning falls short or my knowledge is inferior. Now I have no words to open my beak—may I ask the method?”

Prince Mou sighed deeply, leaned against his armrest, looked up to the sky, and laughed: “Have you alone not heard of the frog in the shallow well? It said to the turtle of the Eastern Sea: ‘How joyful I am! I leap and prance upon the well’s railing, rest at the broken edge of its bricks, plunge into the water to touch my armpits and support my chin, tread in the mud to sink my feet and cover my insteps. Looking around at the shrimp, crabs, and tadpoles, none can match me. Moreover, to possess the water of a single ravine and stand astride the joy of the shallow well—this is the utmost. Why do you not come in from time to time to see?’

The turtle of the Eastern Sea had not yet placed its left foot inside when its right knee was already stuck. Thus it retreated and told the frog of the sea: ‘A distance of a thousand *li* is not enough to describe its greatness; a height of a thousand *ren* is not enough to measure its depth. In the time of Yu, there were nine years of floods, yet the water did not increase; in the time of Tang, there were seven years of drought, yet the shore did not recede. Not to be moved by the passage of time, not to advance or retreat with the quantity of water—this is the great joy of the Eastern Sea.’”

Upon hearing this, the frog of the shallow well was struck with alarm, disoriented and at a loss. Moreover, to seek to comprehend the bounds of right and wrong with the limited understanding one possesses, and yet desire to examine the words of Master Zhuang—this is like commanding a mosquito to bear a mountain or a centipede to race across a river; it is surely beyond one’s capacity. And those who, though unable to fathom the subtleties of profound discourse, yet content themselves with the fleeting gains of the moment—are they not the very frogs of the shallow well?

For he now treads upon the Yellow Springs below and ascends the Great Vault above, unbound by south or north, released in all four directions, submerged in the unfathomable, unrestrained by east or west. Beginning in the dark and mysterious, he returns to the Great Pervasion. Yet you, with your narrow and scrutinizing gaze, seek to grasp this through examination and debate—is this not like peering at the heavens through a tube or measuring the earth with an awl? Is it not petty indeed?

Begone! Have you not heard of the young men of Shouling who went to Handan to learn its way of walking? Before mastering the local skill, they lost even their former gait, and so could only crawl home on all fours. If you do not leave now, you will forget your original ways and lose your own calling.”

Gongsun Long’s jaw dropped and would not close; his tongue lifted and would not descend. Thus he fled in haste. Gongsun Long was among the most eloquent debaters of his time—here his name is invoked merely to refute him. The parables of the well-frog and the sea-turtle are all inventions. How could the mind of this old Master hold so many petty comparisons?

(Note: *hán* are red worms in the well; *xiè* are crabs. In the confines of a shallow well, *hán*, crabs, and tadpoles all move about together, hence the phrase “tadpoles, crabs, and *hán*.” As for the nine years of floods and seven years of drought—this is how people commonly speak, but how could water and drought persist so long? Surely all humankind would perish. Yet when Master Zhuang adds the words “ten years of nine floods” and “eight years of seven droughts,” he sets himself apart from such trivialities, revealing the power of his brush.)

(*Shìshì* means the same as *xìxì*: trembling with fear. *Shāngjù* is a small insect. *Cǐ* means to tread. *Dàhuáng* is heaven. To tread upon the Yellow Springs below and ascend to heaven above is to speak of the loftiness and vastness of his vision. *Shìrán* means the same as *shìrán*: unbound, released in all four directions. *Lún yú bùcè*: to enter into the profound. *Shǐ yú xuánmíng*: to begin in the boundless dark. *Fǎn yú dàtōng*: to return to the Great Pervasion. To seek to exhaust the infinite with the petty clarity of examination and debate—is this not small indeed?)

The parable of losing one’s gait in Handan is especially fine. *Guónéng* refers to the way of walking in Handan. To learn a new skill before mastering it, only to lose one’s former step—this is why they crawled home. What Liezi says of Wei Mou and Gongsun Long differs entirely from this account.

When Master Zhuang was fishing at Pu River, the King of Chu sent two ministers to approach him first, saying, “We wish to burden you with the affairs of our realm.” Master Zhuang, holding his fishing rod, did not turn his head, and said, “I have heard that in Chu there is a sacred turtle, dead for three thousand years. The king keeps it wrapped in silk and stored in a casket in the ancestral temple. Would this turtle rather have died to leave its bones venerated, or lived to drag its tail through the mud?”

The two ministers said, “It would rather live and drag its tail through the mud.”

Master Zhuang said, “Go away. I too will drag my tail through the mud.”

(*Wǎng xiān* means to go and see him first, to convey this meaning beforehand. *Yǐ jìngnèi lěi* means they wished to entrust him with the governance of the state. The parable of the dead turtle leaving its bones versus the living one dragging its tail is truly extraordinary.)

When Huizi was chief minister of Liang, Master Zhuang went to visit him. Someone said to Huizi, “Master Zhuang is coming to replace you as minister.” Thereupon Huizi grew fearful and searched the state for three days and three nights. Master Zhuang went to see him and said, “In the south there is a bird called the *yuānchú*—have you heard of it? The *yuānchú* sets out from the South Sea and flies to the North Sea. It will not perch except on the *wútóng* tree, will not eat except the fruit of the bamboo, and will not drink except from the purest springs. Then a *chī* bird, having obtained a rotting rat, saw the *yuānchú* passing by and looked up, crying, ‘Hè!’ Now do you wish to frighten me with your state of Liang?”

(*Hè* is the sound made to scare away one who might seize its food. To compare the *chī* bird’s rotting rat to Huizi’s state, and the cry of *hè* to his attempt to frighten me—where does this old Master find so many fine parables? From Master Zhuang onward, all who write merely steal his devices. How could the world do without this book? Master Zhuang and Huizi were the closest of friends; this incident likely never occurred, but was a playful jab between them.)

(*Liànshí* is the fruit of the bamboo.)

Master Zhuang and Huizi were strolling on the bridge over the Hao River. Master Zhuang said, “See how the minnows dart about so freely—this is the joy of fish.”

Huizi said, “You are not a fish—how do you know the joy of fish?”

Master Zhuang said, “You are not me—how do you know that I do not know the joy of fish?”

Huizi said, “I am not you, so of course I do not know you. But you are certainly not a fish, so your ignorance of the fish’s joy is complete.”

Master Zhuang said, “Let us return to the beginning. When you said, ‘How do you know the joy of fish?’ you already knew that I knew it when you asked me. I know it here on the Hao River.”

(This exchange is most curious. *Xún qí běn* means to return to the origin. When you first asked, “How do you know the joy of fish?” you already knew my mind, which is why you asked. Since you knew me thus, then I, here on the Hao River, knew the fish in the same way. These two were the closest of friends; one can well imagine their conversation at the time.)
