This dialogue between the River Spirit and the Ocean Spirit is much like the exchanges in the *Transmission of the Lamp*, where National Teacher Zhong says, “Preaching without emotion, attaining Buddhahood without intent.” The great master Dahui remarked, “This old Master is so stubborn, and he’s met a monk just as stubborn—they’re stuck in their questions.”

The household thrives, the gates stand wide, the waves surge vast—yet the root of life is severed. These few words from Zhuangzi are most apt.

The detailed remarks of Dahui can be found in his *General Teachings*, Section 4. *The True Classic of Southern Florescence, Proper Meaning*, Scroll Eighteen, concludes here.

---

*The True Classic of Southern Florescence, Oral Exegesis*, Scroll Nineteen
By Lin Xiyi of Yuanzhai

**Outer Chapters: "Utmost Joy"**

Is there in the world an utmost joy, or is there not? Is there a way to preserve life, or is there not? What should one do? On what should one rely? What should one avoid? Where should one dwell? What should one pursue? What should one forsake? What should one delight in? What should one detest?

What the world honors are wealth, nobility, longevity, and goodness. What it delights in are bodily ease, rich flavors, fine garments, beautiful sights, and harmonious sounds. What it despises are poverty, lowliness, early death, and misfortune. What it suffers are the body denied rest, the mouth denied rich flavors, the form denied fine garments, the eyes denied beautiful sights, and the ears denied harmonious sounds. If one does not obtain these, one is deeply troubled and fearful—how foolish it is to be thus bound to form!

The wealthy exhaust themselves with toil, amassing wealth they cannot fully use—how alienated they are from their own form! The noble pass their days and nights in ceaseless deliberation, weighing good and ill—how estranged they are from their own form! Human life is born with worry, and the long-lived grow dull with age, enduring endless sorrow without death—how distant they are from their own form!

The steadfast knight is praised by the world as good, yet this is not enough to preserve his life. I do not know whether such goodness is truly good or truly not good. If it is good, it does not preserve life; if it is not good, it may preserve others. Thus it is said: "When loyal admonition goes unheeded, withdraw and do not contend." Thus Wu Zixu contended to the point of mutilating his form, yet even without contending, his name was not preserved. Is there truly goodness, or is there not?

Now, as for the world’s pursuits and its joys, I do not know whether its joy is truly joy or truly not joy. I observe the world’s so-called joys: the masses rush together in a frenzy, as if they cannot help themselves, all calling it joy. Yet I find it neither joy nor not joy. Is there truly joy, or is there not?

I hold that non-action is true joy, yet it is what the world deems the greatest suffering. Thus it is said: "Utmost joy is no joy; utmost praise is no praise." The right and wrong of the world cannot truly be settled. Nevertheless, non-action can settle right and wrong. Utmost joy and the preservation of life lie only in non-action, which nearly abides.

This chapter expands upon the previous passage, "Do not let things harm the self." The four phrases beginning with "What should one do? On what should one rely?" ask how one may act rightly, echoing the style of Qu Yuan’s *Encountering Sorrow*. Wealth, nobility, longevity, and goodness—these are four types of people. Good and evil are matters of reputation. "Toil" means laboring diligently. "Deliberating good and ill" means pondering one’s duties with anxiety. "Dull" describes the aged who are no longer clear-minded. The "steadfast knight" is one who seeks reputation. These four passages share the same meaning: all are cases of things harming the self.

Having discussed the three states of nobility, wealth, and longevity, the text now elaborates on the steadfast knight with a shift in phrasing—this is a literary technique. "Withdrawing" is akin to "keeping one’s distance." "Contending for wealth mutilates the form; not contending for fame brings no success"—these two lines expose worldly affairs, showing that striving for reputation to the point of mutilating the form cannot be called good.

The passage beginning "Now, as for the world’s pursuits" concludes the preceding four sections. "The masses rush together" describes the whole world rushing in unison. "In a frenzy" conveys an insistent, grasping intent. They act as if they cannot help themselves, hence "as if they cannot stop." "I find it neither joy nor not joy" means that I do not understand the world’s notions of joy and not-joy—this expresses deep disdain. Yet I take non-action as joy, while the world sees it as great suffering.

Utmost joy lies in no joy; utmost praise lies in no praise. But who among the world’s people knows the joy of no-joy or the praise of no-praise? Thus, the right and wrong of the world cannot truly be settled. Nevertheless, only non-action can settle right and wrong. In these few lines, one must recognize the rise and fall of the text to appreciate its excellence. "Nearly abides" means that through non-action, joy is nearly preserved.

Let me attempt to explain: Heaven is clear through non-action; Earth is tranquil through non-action. When the two non-actions unite, the myriad things are transformed. Vague and indistinct, without origin; indistinct and vague, without form. The ten thousand things flourish abundantly, all growing from non-action. Thus it is said: "Heaven and Earth practice non-action, yet nothing is left undone." Who among men can attain non-action?

These lines conclude the preceding discussion. Only when the two non-actions unite can the myriad things be transformed—this is "non-action yet nothing left undone." "Without origin" means no trace of beginning. "Grow" means to be born. All things arise naturally, hence "all grow from non-action."

From "Is there in the world an utmost joy" to "can one attain non-action?" this passage is a single piece of writing, with its rises and falls most worthy of contemplation.

When Zhuangzi’s wife died, Huizi came to offer condolences. Zhuangzi was squatting, drumming on a basin and singing. Huizi said: "To live with someone, raise a child to old age, and then, when they die, not weep would be enough—yet you drum on a basin and sing. Is this not excessive?" Zhuangzi replied: "Not so. When she first died, how could I alone be without sorrow? Yet I considered her beginning: originally, there was no life. Not only was there no life, but originally there was no form. Not only was there no form, but originally there was no qi."

Amidst the boundless and indistinct, transformation gives rise to qi; qi transforms into form, and form transforms into life. Now, it transforms again into death—this is like the succession of spring, autumn, winter, and summer, the ceaseless progression of the four seasons. A man lies at peace within the vast chamber, yet I wail and weep after him, believing myself to be ignorant of fate—thus I cease.

"Form transforms into life" means that form precedes the movement and activity of life. The Buddhists say that movement and turning belong to the wind, which is what this "life" refers to. They also say: in the eyes, it is seeing; in the ears, it is hearing; in the hands, it is grasping; in the feet, it is running—this is what "life" means. The progression of the four seasons is a metaphor for the inevitability of death following life. This passage elucidates the principle that life and death are one continuous process.

The tale of drumming on the basin is but an allegory. Consider Yuan Rang, who climbed a tree and sang at his parent’s death—could he truly have been devoid of human feeling? If he were entirely without human feeling, he would be a jackal or a wolf. Would the Master still have befriended him? The teachings of the sagely school aim to fulfill the duties of filial piety and reverence—how could they be ignorant of the principle of life and death? Yuan Rang, Zhuangzi, and their like sought to shatter the delusions of the human heart, and so they resorted to such excessive acts.

This is why the Daoist mind is so subtle and cannot be practiced in isolation in the world, hence the teaching of "holding to the mean." Did Zhuangzi and Liezi not understand this? They merely sought to correct the world’s weariness of convention, and so they put forth such arguments.

When Li Hanlao mourned his son and asked Dahui, fearing that his inability to forget his emotions might distance him from the Dao, Dahui replied: "If you did not weep for your dead son, you would be a jackal or a wolf." This elder’s words reveal profound insight. Other Buddhists, when asked such a question, would surely have spoken nonsense.

Zhili Shu and Hua Jieshu were observing the mound of Mingbo, the wasteland of Kunlun, and the place where the Yellow Emperor once rested. Suddenly, a growth appeared on Hua Jieshu’s left elbow, and he frowned in displeasure. Zhili Shu asked: "Do you dislike it?" Hua Jieshu replied: "No, why should I dislike it? Life is but a temporary borrowing. What borrows and gives rise to life is mere dust and grime. Life and death are like day and night. Moreover, you and I observe transformation, and transformation reaches me—why should I dislike it?"

"Hua Jieshu" implies a sense of humor—such a name must have been invented. "Where the Yellow Emperor rested" means the Emperor once rested there. "Liu" refers to a sore; today, people call it a boil. It seems such a term existed in ancient times. "Frowning in displeasure" expresses the sentiment of one afflicted by illness.

"Temporary borrowing" means this body is formed by the temporary convergence of external things. "Dust and grime" means that within the workings of creation, it is utterly insignificant and unworthy of esteem. The Buddhist idea of the "four conditions converging to form a false body"—and now, where is this illusory body?—truly originates from this.

"Observing transformation" means witnessing the changes of all things. "Transformation reaches me" means that I, too, will follow the Creator in transformation. Earlier, he frowned in displeasure, but now he says, "Why should I dislike it?" The statements seem contradictory. Yet displeasure in illness is human nature; understanding the principle of life and death and recognizing its origin is where the Daoist mind prevails.

When Zhuangzi traveled to Chu, he saw an empty skull, still intact in shape. He tapped it with his horse whip and asked: "Did you, sir, covet life and lose reason, becoming like this? Or did you suffer the fall of a state, the execution by axe, and become like this? Or did you commit some unworthy deed, bringing shame upon your parents, wife, and children, and become like this? Or did you endure the miseries of cold and hunger and become like this? Or did your years naturally come to this end?"

Having spoken, he took the skull as a pillow and lay down. In the middle of the night, the skull appeared to him in a dream and said: "Your words resemble those of a debater. All that you mentioned are the burdens of the living—death is free of them. Would you like to hear the truth of death?" Zhuangzi said: "Yes." The skull replied: "In death, there is no ruler above, no subject below, nor the affairs of the four seasons. At ease, with heaven and earth as spring and autumn, even the joy of a king facing south cannot surpass it."

Zhuangzi, unconvinced, said: "If I had the Controller of Fate restore your form, giving you bones, flesh, and skin, returning you to your parents, wife, children, neighbors, and friends, would you desire it?" The skull furrowed its brow deeply and said: "How could I abandon the joy of a king facing south and return to the toils of the human world?"

"Rao ran" describes the appearance of emptiness and solidity.

"Congran" signifies a state of ease and self-contentment. "All that you mentioned" refers to everything previously spoken of. This passage discusses the principle of life and death, introducing the peculiar dialogue with the skull. Readers should grasp its intent and not take it as literal speech.

When Yan Yuan journeyed east to Qi, Confucius wore a troubled expression. Zigong stepped from his mat and asked: "This student dares to inquire—why does the Master appear troubled as Yan Yuan travels to Qi?" Confucius replied: "Your question is excellent. Formerly, Guanzi spoke words I deeply admired: 'A small sack cannot hold a large object; a short rope cannot draw from a deep well.' Such is the way of things—fate has its completion, and form has its proper place, neither to be diminished nor augmented. I fear that Yan Yuan, in speaking to the Marquis of Qi of the Dao of Yao, Shun, and the Yellow Emperor, and further adding the words of Suiren and Shennong, will cause the Marquis to search within himself and find nothing. Finding nothing, he will be perplexed; perplexed, he will perish.

Have you not heard this before? Once, a seabird alighted in the outskirts of Lu. The Lord of Lu received it and offered it wine in the ancestral temple, performed the *Jiu Shao* as music, and prepared an ox, sheep, and pig as a feast. Yet the bird only gazed in dizziness and sorrow, refusing to eat a single morsel or drink a single cup, and died within three days. This was nourishing the bird with what nourishes man, not with what nourishes birds. To properly nourish a bird, one should let it roost in deep forests, roam the sandy plains, float upon rivers and lakes, feed on loaches and minnows, rest in formation, and dwell in tranquility. It detests the sound of human speech—why then subject it to clamor?

When the music of *Xian Chi* and *Jiu Shao* is played in the wilds of Dongting, birds hear it and fly away, beasts hear it and flee, fish hear it and dive deep, while men, upon hearing it, turn back to observe. Fish live in water, yet men die in it—they must differ, for their likes and dislikes are not the same. Thus, the sages of old did not unify abilities or standardize affairs; names were confined to reality, and principles were set according to what was fitting. This is called 'orderly attainment and the preservation of fortune.'

A *chu* is a cloth sack; a *geng* is the rope used to draw water from a well. This illustrates the idea that small strength cannot bear great burdens. Fate and form, bestowed by Heaven, each have their fixed measure, neither to be diminished nor augmented. To speak to the Marquis of Qi of the Dao of the ancient sages, without the power to move or transform him, would invite blame upon myself. This passage uses Yan Yuan to satirize the persuaders of the present age.

What nourishes birds is not what nourishes men; to feed a bird with human food violates its nature. The meaning is simply that one should not speak where speech is unfit, for to do so is to speak amiss. The Confucian school has but a single principle, yet here it is expanded into vast and sweeping discourse.

*Yu* (御) means to receive and offer wine; *shang* (觞) means to drink. *Tan* (坛) is pronounced like *dan* (但) and is the same as *chan* (澶), referring to sandy plains in riverlands. 'Not unifying abilities' means that human talents differ; 'not standardizing affairs' means each attends to their proper task. Names are confined to what is real, and principles are set according to what is fitting—thus, 'names are confined to reality, and principles are set according to what is fitting.' This means each follows their allotted place.

'Orderly attainment' means proceeding directly without strain; 'preservation of fortune' means that fortune endures. To hold (持) is to preserve. Not undertaking what exceeds one’s capacity avoids strain and preserves life, free from harm. The meaning is no more than this.

Liezi was traveling and eating by the roadside when he saw a century-old skull. Pulling aside the overgrown grass, he pointed to it and said: "Only you and I know that you have never died, never lived. If indeed you were nourished, would I indeed be joyful?" There are seeds of all kinds: when they obtain water, they become *gan*; at the water’s edge, they become the moss of frogs and toads; growing on mounds, they become *lingxi*; *lingxi* that obtains *yuqi* becomes *niaozu*; the root of *niaozu* becomes *qicao*, its leaves become butterflies. Butterflies, in time, transform into insects, born beneath the stove, resembling cast-off skins, named *quduo*. After a thousand days, *quduo* becomes a bird called *ganyugu*; the foam of *ganyugu* becomes *simi*, and *simi* becomes *shihai*. *Yixia* is born from *shihai*, *huangkuang* from *jiuyou*, *maorui* from rotten silkworms, and *yangxi* is akin to *busun*. Old bamboo gives rise to *qingning*, *qingning* to *cheng*, *cheng* to horses, and horses to men. Men, in turn, return to the mechanism. All things emerge from the mechanism and return to the mechanism.

'From seeing' means seeing as a consequence. 'Pulling aside the overgrown grass' refers to the skull lying amid the grass, which he drew aside to point at it. 'Nourishment' refers to eating and drinking in life; 'joy' refers to the stillness of extinction in death. Yet here it is expressed in such terms—this is merely playing with marvels in writing.

'You and I' refer to the skull. This 'joy' is the bliss of stillness and extinction. 'Seeds of all kinds' means that among the myriad things between Heaven and Earth, the seeds of life differ. Below, the most minute are described—not as a small metaphor for the great, but to show that the great is no different from the small. This conveys the idea of no small or great, no noble or base. The meaning is simply this, yet the artistry of the writing is unparalleled across the ages. Amid order, there is disorder; amid disorder, order—like watching scattered geese in flight, like gazing upon solitary peaks and rugged slopes. The more one reads, the finer it becomes. Liezi adds two sentences here, which would have been better omitted. *Gan* is the scum on water, the first growth of moss, not yet fully formed, with threads intertwined—yet it is a most minute thing.

The "clothing" of the turtle and freshwater mussel is none other than green moss. The "water-and-earth juncture" refers to where water clings to the bank—such places are typically lush and thick, hence called "clothing." Though these two lines speak of green moss, they then turn to the *lingtun*, the high ground in the fields. *Lingxi* is *cheqian* grass. *Yuqi* is manure and soil. When *cheqian* grass grows amid manure and soil, it transforms into *niaozu* grass; the roots of *niaozu* further metamorphose into *qicao*, while its leaves become butterflies. *Qicao* is the grub of the scarab beetle. *Xu* is another name for the butterfly. The addition of this line beneath the butterfly is especially striking.

Below, it speaks again of creatures born from transformation—those beneath the stove, some of which are called *quduo*, soft and without skin or grain, hence said to be "as if shed," like the silkworm today. *Quduo* can further transform into a bird called *ganyugu*, the "dried remnant bone." *Simi* is an insect. Its foam becomes another insect. *Shihai* is the *yimeng* midge. *Yimeng* transforms into *yilu*, *yilu* into *jiuyou*, *jiuyou* into *huanghuang*, *huanghuang* into *fuxuan*, and *fuxuan* into *maorui*. Here, two lines are omitted with the phrase "born from," a stylistic choice. *Huanghuang*, *jiuyou*, *fuxuan*, and *maorui* are all names of insects. The meaning here is that the transformations of the myriad things are ceaseless, their generation without end.

The preceding section having been expounded, it concludes with the most bizarre examples—this is where it startles the common world. Do not take it as literal truth. *Yangxi* is a type of grass. Grass resembling bamboo but not producing shoots is called "non-shooter." While the shoots of old bamboo are edible, these are not. *Qingning* is an insect. *Cheng* is also an insect, and *ma* is a grass, what is now called purslane or *malan* grass. *Ren* is also a grass, what is now called ginseng or *renmianzi*. Clearly, many grass names are used, yet the characters for "horse" and "man" are deliberately employed to craft strange and uncanny names. Previous commentators have all deemed these obscure, showing that for ten thousand generations, people have been baffled by Zhuangzi, unable to see through his artifice.

The transformations of the myriad things—such as the sparrow becoming a clam, the hawk into a turtledove, rotting grass into fireflies, or the rat into a bat—show that nothing fails to enter the mechanism. This speaks of returning to the ultimate end. To "emerge from the mechanism" and "enter the mechanism" is to emerge from and enter death and life—it is the transmission of fire, the unknowing of its end.

*Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Nineteen Concludes
*Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Twenty

The *Outer Chapters: "Attaining Life"* by Lin Xiyi of Yanzhai

One who attains the essence of life does not pursue what is of no use to life. One who attains the essence of fate does not strive after what knowledge cannot master. To nourish the body, one must first rely on things, yet there are cases where things are in excess while the body remains unnourished. To have life, one must first not depart from the body, yet there are cases where the body does not depart while life perishes. Life’s coming cannot be refused, nor can its going be halted—how lamentable that the people of the world believe nourishing the body suffices to preserve life, yet nourishing the body ultimately does not suffice to preserve life. If this is so, what in the world is worth doing? Though it may not be worth doing, one cannot but do it, for such doing is inescapable.

To escape doing for the body’s sake, nothing surpasses abandoning the world. Fleeing the world means being without entanglements; without entanglements, one is upright and equanimous; upright and equanimous, one renews life with the Other; renewing life, one approaches the ultimate. What need is there to abandon affairs? What need is there to cling to life? Abandoning affairs, the body is not wearied; forgetting life, the essence is not depleted. When the body is whole and essence restored, one becomes one with Heaven. Heaven and Earth are the parents of the myriad things: united, they form a body; dispersed, they return to the beginning. When form and essence are not depleted, this is called "the power to transform." Refining essence further and further, one returns to assist Heaven.

What is "of no use to life" refers to things external to the body—such as how many pairs of shoes a person wears in a lifetime, or how many spoons they use in a day. What "knowledge cannot master" refers to what lies beyond human power. Nourishing the body must rely on things, and having life must preserve the body—this is the common view of the world. Yet things are often in excess, while the body does not endure forever; the body may be preserved, yet life has its end. Thus it is said: there are cases where things are in excess yet the body is not nourished, and cases where the body does not depart yet life perishes. Though it may not be worth doing, one cannot but do it—this is what was previously meant by "nothing is worth doing, yet one cannot but do it." "Inescapable" means that whether one acts or not, one cannot avoid self-entanglement. To escape self-entanglement, nothing suffices but abandoning the world.

Abandoning the world does not mean fleeing it; it means dwelling in the world with a mind free of intent, responding only when moved, acting only when compelled, rising only when unavoidable. Then the self remains the self, and the world remains the world. "Upright and equanimous" means the mind is without preference or discrimination—akin to the Buddhist saying, "All dharmas are equal." "Renewing life" means becoming inexhaustible with the Other; the Other is the Creator. Moving in unison with the Creator, one is renewed day by day, hence "renewing life with the Other." At this point, one reaches the ultimate—*ji* (the ultimate) means "exhaustion." Knowing this, the affairs external to the body and the life one clings to are abandoned of themselves, without need for deliberate abandonment.

"Essence restored" means the spirit is not scattered outward. "United, they form a body" refers to the four great elements combining to form the body; "dispersed, they return to the beginning"—the beginning being the origin before things existed. "Form and essence" here means body and spirit. When body and spirit are not depleted, they possess the power to transform, hence "the power to transform." *Transform* means *change*. When one embodies the Dao to this degree, refining essence further and further, one can then assist in creation. "Assisting Heaven" means aiding Heaven. These two instances of *essence* differ from *form and essence* above. *Return* means *revert*—to serve and thereby return.

When Liezi asked Guanyin, "The perfected person walks underwater without obstruction, treads fire without heat, and moves above the myriad things without fear. May I ask how one attains this?" Guanyin replied, "This is the preservation of pure qi, not the realm of knowledge, skill, courage, or daring. Stay, and I will tell you. All that has form, image, sound, or color belongs to things. How can things be distant from one another? Why should one strive to surpass them? They are but appearances. Things arise from the formless and cease where transformation ends. One who fully attains this cannot be limited by things. They dwell within the measure of non-excess, abide in the principle without origin, and roam through the beginning and end of the myriad things. Unifying their nature, nurturing their qi, harmonizing their virtue, they commune with the source of things. One who is thus has their Heavenly endowment intact, their spirit unobstructed—how could things enter them?

Consider the drunkard who falls from a cart: though the fall is swift, he does not die. His bones and joints are the same as others’, yet the harm he suffers differs—his spirit is whole. He is unaware of riding, unaware of falling; life and death, terror and fear do not enter his breast. Thus he is not daunted by things. If one who is whole through wine is like this, how much more so one who is whole through Heaven? The sage hides in Heaven, and thus nothing can harm them.

A man seeking vengeance does not break the sword’s blade; even one with a vengeful heart does not resent a tile fallen by chance. Thus the world is in balance: there are no wars of aggression, no punishments of execution. This is the way of such a Dao. Do not open the Heavenly in man but open the Heavenly of Heaven. Opening the Heavenly gives birth to virtue; opening the human harms life. Do not weary of Heaven, nor neglect the people—thus one approaches the authentic.

"Walking underwater without obstruction" means moving silently without hindrance. "Moving above the myriad things without fear" is like riding the wind. "Preservation of pure qi" means guarding the original qi, keeping it unified and unadulterated. "Knowledge" refers to cunning; "skill" to force. This matter cannot be achieved through cunning or force. Though these words may seem impractical, the principle is real—observe today’s practitioners of qi-cultivation, and you will see.

"Form, image, sound, color" refer to having traces. All things in the world are bound by form; if I too have traces, I am no different from them—how then can I surpass what existed before things? People, confined to their single bodies, cannot perceive the beginning of the myriad things—all because they are burdened by traces. Thus it is said, "They are but appearances." *Appearance* means *traces*."

"Form, image, sound, color"—above, all four characters were listed, but here only one is cited; this is a matter of literary technique.

The Creator of things has no form, hence it is said, "things are created from the formless." Without end or beginning, unified and undivided, it is thus said to "abide where there is no transformation." *Transformation* means *change*; this speaks of its unchanging nature. To grasp this and exhaust its wonders is to comprehend the principle of creation.

To attain this principle and plumb its depths is to distance oneself far from the realm of existing things, hence it is said, "How could things be divided?" *Excess* means *disorder* and *instability*. *The measure of non-excess* is the unchanging standard. *The beginning without origin* is the inception before things. *Beginning* here means *principle*.

The end and beginning of the myriad things is creation. To unify one’s nature is to keep it pure and undivided. To harmonize one’s virtue is to maintain its wholeness without separation. To merge with the Creator is thus said to "penetrate to what things are created from."

To call it *Heaven* or *Spirit* is to refer to this principle within me. *Without division* means *without gap*. When what is within is complete and without gap, how can external things enter?

"Unmoved by things" means that though touched by things, one’s spirit remains undisturbed, hence unafraid. The analogy of the drunken man falling from a cart is most precise. "Hidden in Heaven" means none can harm him—this is the earlier passage on "not allowing things to harm oneself," which is called *non-action*.

A sword may wound a man, a flying tile may strike him, yet he feels no anger—because these things have no intent. These two lines serve as an analogy for *no-mind*, and their reasoning is most sound.

"Balanced throughout the world" means acting without preference or aversion. Where there is contention, there is war, slaughter, and strife; but if I have no mind, there is no contention—how then could such things arise? The *Heaven of man* still has mind, while the *Heaven of Nature* has no mind.

*Opening* means *illuminating*. *Virtue that gives life* is natural virtue. To "open man’s Heaven" is to leave the heart untransformed; if the heart remains untransformed, the six senses become six thieves—how much more so external things?

"Not rejecting one’s Heaven" means not abandoning one’s heavenly principle. "Not neglecting the human" means that while one does not disregard worldly affairs requiring action, one acts without contrivance. Thus one approaches the truth of reality—*approaches*, for it is near.

When Confucius traveled to Chu, he emerged from a forest and saw a hunchback catching cicadas with a pole as easily as if picking them up. Confucius said, "You are skillful—do you have a method?" The man replied, "I do. For five or six months, I balance two pellets on the pole without dropping them, and I lose only a few. With three pellets, I lose only one in ten. With five, it is as easy as picking them up."

"I hold my body still as a tree stump, and my arm steady as a withered branch. Though Heaven and Earth are vast and the myriad things numerous, I am aware only of the cicada’s wings. I do not turn or sway, nor do I let the myriad things distract me from the cicada’s wings—how could I fail?"

Confucius turned to his disciples and said, "When the will is undivided, it becomes concentrated in spirit." This describes the hunchbacked old man. *Catching cicadas* means using a pole to snare them. Balancing nine pellets on the pole’s tip—from two to five without dropping them—shows such concentration that one enters the realm of spirit. Guo Xiang’s use of "stillness" and "focus" here is also apt.

*A tree stump* is what we now call a *wooden stake*. *Root* means *stake*, *stump* is the name of the wood, and *fixed* means *immobile*. It seems these three characters existed in ancient times. *Not turning or swaying* simply means *concentration*. While catching cicadas, his body was as motionless as a wooden stake, his arm like a withered branch, yet his mind was fixed solely on the cicada, unaware of anything else—this is the height of purity.

"When the will is undivided" means the will is single-minded. "Concentrated in spirit" means focused to the point of spiritual mastery. Though this analogy illustrates the preservation of pure *qi*, such things truly exist in the world—even today—but people regard them as mere skill and do not recognize the Dao within.

*A hunchback* is one whose back is bent. Yan Yuan asked Confucius, "I once crossed the deep abyss of Shang. The ferryman handled the boat as if by magic. I asked him, 'Can one learn to handle a boat?' He said, 'Yes—those skilled in swimming can learn quickly. As for divers, they can handle a boat without ever having seen one.' I pressed him, but he would not explain. May I ask what he meant?"

Confucius said, "Those skilled in swimming can learn quickly because they have forgotten the water. As for divers who can handle a boat without ever having seen one—they see the abyss as level ground and a capsized boat as merely a cart rolling backward. Though countless dangers lie before them, they do not enter their minds—where could they find leisure to fear?"

"One who stakes tiles is skillful; one who stakes hooks is hesitant; one who stakes gold is troubled—yet their skill is the same. Where there is attachment, the weight is external." Whoever values externals is clumsy within.

*Shang* is the name of a deep abyss. *Swimming* means floating on the surface. *Divers* are those who submerge in water. A skilled diver sees water as level ground, so he can handle a boat without learning. Though countless dangers arise, his mind remains undisturbed—hence it is said, "they do not enter their minds." The mind is the dwelling of spirit and clarity.

*Staking* means *shooting at a target*. *To gaze at the object* is called *staking*. Wang Qinruo once said, "To make Your Majesty a lone stake"—this is the same *stake* character.

One who stakes tiles has no concern for gain or loss; one who stakes hooks begins to feel attachment; one who stakes gold grows more attached and thus more troubled. *Attachment* means *cherishing*. The archer’s skill is fundamentally the same, but when there is attachment, what is valued lies outside, and the mind becomes confused.

When the mind is confused, even the most skillful may at times become clumsy.

Having answered the question, he further seals it with this analogy—these two metaphors both embody the supreme principle of the world. Observe how the flow of his prose rises and concludes, itself most singular.

Tian Kaizhi visited Duke Wei of Zhou. The Duke said, “I have heard that Zhu Shen was a student of learning. You have kept company with Zhu Shen—what have you learned from him?”

Tian Kaizhi replied, “Kaizhi’s duty is but to grasp the broom and attend the gate—what could I have learned from the Master?”

The Duke said, “Tianzi, do not decline. I wish to hear it.”

Kaizhi said, “I heard the Master say: ‘One who nurtures life well is like a shepherd—he watches for those lagging behind and whips them forward.’”

The Duke asked, “What does this mean?”

Tian Kaizhi said, “In Lu there was a man named Shan Bao who dwelled in the cliffs and drank from streams, sharing no profit with the people. At seventy, his complexion remained that of a child. Unluckily, he encountered a starving tiger, which killed and devoured him. There was also a man named Zhang Yi who ran to every high gate and hanging curtain, yet at forty he died of internal heat. Bao nurtured his inner self, but the tiger consumed his outer; Yi nurtured his outer, but illness assailed his inner. These two men both failed to whip the laggards forward.”

*Ba hui* means *to grasp the broom*—*ba* as in *uprooting*, holding the broom to tend the gate, fulfilling the disciple’s duty of sweeping.

Shepherding sheep is naturally left to their own course, but if some fall behind and fail to follow the flock, they must be whipped forward. This implies that while one follows the Dao of Heaven, one must also fulfill human effort.

Shan Bao was a recluse yet was slain by a tiger; Zhang Yi frequented the houses of the rich and noble, though spared the harm of tigers, yet perished from inner turmoil and internal heat. Both cases show that human effort was incomplete—one cannot simply entrust all to Heaven.

This passage is most intimate to those who study the Dao, and from it one may infer Zhuangzi’s intent in expounding the Dao of Heaven and the Dao of Man throughout his work. First he sets forth the analogy, then confirms it with two examples—his prose is singular indeed.

Confucius said: “Do not retreat and hide away; do not advance and display yourself; stand like a withered tree in the center. If these three are attained, one’s name will surely reach the utmost.”

“Do not retreat and hide away” means not to be fixated on stillness. “Do not advance and display yourself” means not to be bound to activity. “Stand like a withered tree” describes standing without intent, its form like dead wood. Movement and stillness have no constancy, and one does not lean to either side—thus it is said, “stand in the center.” The “three” refer to the three phrases above; mastering these three, one may be called a Perfected Person. Hence it is said, “If these three are attained, one’s name will surely reach the utmost”—*utmost* meaning *supreme*.

Those who fear the road where ten kill one will warn their fathers, sons, and brothers, and only dare to venture forth with a great company of armed men—are they not wise in what men truly fear? Yet in the intimacy of bed and mat, in the midst of food and drink, they remain unaware of the need for caution—this is their error.

Drawing an analogy between the perilous road and the bedchamber conveys the same meaning as “the axe that hews life through the allure of moth-eyebrows”—this is a warning to restrain desire. Even sages and worthies, upon hearing Zhuangzi’s words, would surely nod in assent. How could this be the teaching of a heterodox school?

The invocator dons dark ceremonial robes to approach the pen and address the swine, saying: "Why do you abhor death? I shall rear you for three months as a sacrificial beast, purify you for ten days, fast for three, and spread white couch-grass beneath you. Then I shall place you, shoulder and haunch, upon the carved offering-tray—would you consent to this?" For the swine, he counsels: "Better to be fed husks and dregs and left in the pen." Yet for himself, he reasons: "If living brings the honor of high carriage and cap, and dying grants one a place upon the patterned bier amid woven bamboo, then so be it."

For the swine, he rejects such a fate; for himself, he embraces it. What, then, makes him different from the swine? *Dark ceremonial robes*: the cap of office. *Rear*: to nourish with fodder. *Haunch*: the hindquarters of the pig. *Patterned*: akin to *seal-script*, referring to the carved designs on the bier. *Bier*: the frame of the funerary platform. A frame adorned with patterns is called a *pig-bier*. *Woven*: bent, as in objects that gather things—baskets and containers of that sort. Earlier texts refer to *woven bamboo* as *bent strips*; thus we know this too is a bamboo vessel. In the second year of Duke Xuan of Lu, a pen-keeper roasted a bear’s paw improperly, killed him, and placed the body in a basket—this is of the same kind.

To live with the nobility of high carriage and cap, yet die by execution and be cast upon a stumbling-block, amid coarse baskets, and still find contentment—this is what Han Yu meant by "dwelling in filth without shame, meeting execution and death without remorse." To counsel the swine thus, yet choose otherwise for oneself—this analogy may be called apt.

Duke Huan was hunting in the marshes, with Guan Zhong driving his chariot, when he saw a ghost. The duke grasped Guan Zhong’s hand and asked, “What did you see, Father Zhong?” Guan Zhong replied, “Your servant saw nothing.” Upon returning, the duke fell ill from distress and did not emerge for several days. A Qi scholar named Huangzi Gao’ao said, “The duke has merely harmed himself—how could a ghost harm him? When pent-up qi scatters and does not return, it causes deficiency; when it rises but does not descend, it makes one prone to anger; when it sinks but does not rise, it makes one prone to forgetfulness. If it neither rises nor sinks but lodges in the middle of the body, striking the heart, it causes illness.”

Duke Huan asked, “Then do ghosts exist?” Huangzi replied, “They do. In the depths of the marsh, there is *Lü*; in the stove, there is *Ji*. The foul earth within the door is where *Leiting* dwells. Beneath the northeast corner of the house lurks *Bei’e Xielong*; beneath the northwest, *Yiyang* resides. In water, there is *Wangxiang*; on mounds, *Zhen*; in mountains, *Kui*; in the wild, *Fanghuang*; and in the marshes, *Weiyi*.”

The duke asked, “What does *Weiyi* look like?” Huangzi said, “*Weiyi* is as thick as a wheel hub and as long as a chariot shaft. It wears purple robes and a crimson cap. As a creature, it is fearsome—when it hears the rumble of thunder-chariots, it clasps its head and stands erect. Whoever sees it is destined for hegemony.”

Duke Huan laughed heartily and said, “This is what I saw!” He then straightened his robes and cap, sat with Huangzi, and before the day was out, his illness had vanished. This account resembles the tale of the *peishe*, though it is more extraordinary. *Eyi* is like the sound of retching—an ailment of reversed qi. *Fenchu* is stagnation. When illness strikes the body’s center, affecting the heart, it is what people today call a *zhongguan* malady.

*Shen* refers to the mud of ditches, where *Lü* dwells; *Ji* is another spirit of the stove. *Fanrang* is filthy earth, where *Leiting* resides. *Bei’e Xielong* is the ghost of the northeast corner of a house, while *Yiyang* inhabits the northwest. The above names all refer to spirits dwelling in households. *Wangxiang* is the spirit of water; *Zhen*, the spirit of small mounds; *Kui*, the spirit of mountains; *Fanghuang*, the spirit of the wild; and *Weiyi*, the spirit of great marshes. Since Duke Huan saw the ghost in the marshes, he inquired specifically about *Weiyi*. At first, he mistook it for an omen and fell ill from fear, but upon learning that seeing it foretold hegemony, he rejoiced, and his illness vanished. *Zhenran* describes the manner of his laughter.

This parable differs from the one about seeing a pig bearing mud or a cartload of ghosts, yet since the Sage included such words in the hexagrams, such things must exist in the world—there is no need for surprise.

Ji Xiaozhi was raising fighting cocks for the king. After ten days, the king asked, “Are the cocks ready?” Ji replied, “Not yet—they are still hollow and arrogant, relying on their qi.” After another ten days, the king asked again, and Ji said, “Not yet—they still respond to shadows and echoes.” After another ten days, the king asked, and Ji said, “Not yet—they still glare fiercely and bristle with qi.” After another ten days, the king asked, and Ji said, “Nearly so. Though other cocks may crow, they show no change. From a distance, they resemble wooden cocks—their virtue is complete. No other cock dares challenge them; they turn and flee.”

Responding to sounds and reacting to shadows means the heart is still moved by external things. “Glaring fiercely and bristling with qi” describes their spirit and qi flourishing. Earlier, they were “hollow and arrogant, relying on qi,” meaning their qi was still external; now, “glaring fiercely and bristling with qi” means their qi is internal. The word *ji* implies anger—it means a fixed gaze, not the same as a commoner gripping his sword and glaring. When they appear like wooden cocks, their spirit and qi are fully integrated. This passage uses cocks as a metaphor for the study of guarding one’s qi.

Confucius observed the Lüliang Falls, where the water plunged thirty *ren* and its foam stretched forty *li*, a place where turtles, alligators, fish, and soft-shelled turtles could not swim. He saw a man swimming there and thought he was in distress, seeking death. He sent his disciples to follow the current and rescue him. After several hundred paces, the man emerged, his hair unbound, singing as he strolled beneath the embankment.

Confucius approached and asked, “I took you for a ghost, but upon closer inspection, you are a man. May I ask if there is a method to treading water?” The man replied, “No, I have no method. I began with my origins, grew with my nature, and completed it with fate. I enter with the swirl and emerge with the surge, following the water’s way without imposing my will. This is how I tread it.”

Confucius asked, “What do you mean by beginning with origins, growing with nature, and completing with fate?” The man said, “I was born on the hills and am at ease on the hills—this is my origin. I grew up in water and am at ease in water—this is my nature. I do not know why I am so, yet I am so—this is fate.” This passage shares the same meaning as the earlier discussion of steering a boat.

*Bingliu* means following the current. *Gu* refers to one’s inherent state—Mencius said, “Those who speak of nature refer only to *gu*.” Nature and fate are the principles of spontaneity. *Qi* refers to the swirling of water; *gu*, to its surging. “Entering and emerging” means rising and falling with the water. “Following the water’s way without imposing my will” means going with the flow, not against it. Being born on the hills and at ease there, growing up in water and at ease there—all arise from following one’s nature without knowing why. The three terms *gu*, *xing*, and *ming* are initially undifferentiated; they are merely used this way in writing. To force meanings onto the words *sheng* (birth) and *zhang* (growth) would be a mistake.

Master Qing of Zi carved wood into a *ju*. When it was finished, those who saw it marveled as if it were the work of ghosts or spirits. The Marquis of Lu saw it and asked, “What technique did you use?” Master Qing replied, “I am but a craftsman—what technique could I have? Nevertheless, there is one thing.”

When I set out to carve the *ju*, I never dared to waste my *qi*—I first fasted to still my mind. After three days of fasting, I no longer dared to harbor thoughts of rewards, ranks, or emoluments. After five days, I no longer dared to harbor thoughts of praise or blame, skill or clumsiness. After seven days, I would suddenly forget that I had limbs or a body. At that moment, I was no longer aware of the court; my craft became single-minded, and all external distractions dissolved. Only then did I enter the mountain forests to observe the natural essence of things, where the form of the wood revealed itself in its fullness. Only then did the *ju* appear before me, and only then did I set my hand to it—otherwise, I would have stopped. Thus, I merged my nature with the nature of the wood. This is how the vessel gathers spirit—is it not so?

The *ju* resembles the *jiazhong* bell, though this is merely the interpretation of commentators. Since bells are made of metal, how could carved wood achieve the same? In my humble opinion, the *Da Guan Lei Pian* states that the *ju* is the ornament on bells and drums, akin to the *sun* and *□* (brackets) used to suspend them. These ornaments, shaped like birds or beasts and carved from wood with exquisite precision, can be seen in the *Kaogong Ji*. That people marveled as if it were the work of ghosts or spirits speaks to its unparalleled craftsmanship—beyond what any human could achieve.

"Wasting *qi*" means the *qi* is unsettled. Fasting stills the mind, and only then does the *qi* settle. Not harboring thoughts of rank or emolument, not harboring thoughts of praise or blame, forgetting one’s limbs—this means guarding the pure *qi* and shutting out external things. "No longer aware of the court" means even the thought of the court vanishes. Only thus does the mind’s skill become focused, and all external things that might disturb it dissolve and fade away.

"Entering the mountain forests to observe the natural essence" means observing the nature of the wood. Each piece of wood has its own inherent form, as if already complete. Only then does one select and use it. "Setting the hand to it" means taking it up. Merging one’s own nature with the nature of the thing is called "merging heaven with heaven."

Dongye Ji was summoned by Duke Zhuang of Wei for his charioteering. His advances and retreats were as straight as a plumb line, his left and right turns as precise as a compass. The Duke thought even Wen’s skill could not surpass this and ordered him to circle a hundred times before returning. Yan He encountered him and, entering the court, said, "Ji’s horses are about to fail." The Duke remained silent, but soon enough, the horses faltered and returned. The Duke asked, "How did you know?" Yan He replied, "His horses’ strength was exhausted, yet he still demanded more—hence, failure."

The six reins were woven like a pattern, and his driving was as skillful as weaving—hence, "even Wen could not surpass this." "Circling" refers to driving the horses in a hunt. "A hundred turns" means a hundred circuits. When the horses’ strength is spent yet they are still driven relentlessly, even the most skilled charioteer will fail. How, then, can one overtax their spirit through self-exertion? This analogy is most apt and precise.

When Gongchui turned his hand, it was as if compass and square were already there. His fingers transformed with the object, without the mind lingering. Thus, his spirit was unified and unshackled. Here, the text digresses briefly.

Gongchui served as the craftsman for Gonggong, hence "Gongchui." "Turning" means rotating the hand to draw a circle. When Gongchui crafted vessels, his hand turned, and the circle was as perfect as if measured by compass and square. The *Kaogong Ji* states that the roundness of a vessel symbolizes heaven and earth. The cover is the roundest of objects, hence the analogy—though it does not mean the vessel itself was a cover. It is like Wu Daozi painting the halo of a Buddha: with a single stroke, it became a masterpiece, transcending skill. Here, too, the craft is divine. A vessel’s roundness requires no compass—only the hand draws it, yet the skill is sublime.

"Fingers" refer to the hand. "Transforming with the object" is like the saying in calligraphy: "The hand does not know the brush, the brush does not know the hand." Hand and object forget each other, the mind no longer lingering—this is what is meant by "the senses halt, the spirit moves." Hence, "without the mind lingering." "Lingering" means clinging.

Some ask, "If it is round, it conforms to the compass—why mention the square?" They do not realize that within roundness lies the square. A circle that does not conform to the square is not truly round. When craftsmen carve wood into a circle, they first make it square, revealing how compass and square are inseparable. Thus, it is said, "The compass gives rise to the square."

"Spirit terrace" refers to the mind. "Unified" means pure and undivided. "Unshackled" means unbound. Forgetting the feet is the comfort of shoes; forgetting the waist is the comfort of a belt. Forgetting right and wrong is the comfort of the mind. No inner change, no outer compliance—this is the comfort of meeting events. Beginning with comfort and never departing from it is the comfort of forgetting comfort.

"Comfort" means ease. The feet are at ease in shoes, the waist at ease in a belt—it is as if they are not there, hence "forgetting the feet, forgetting the waist." "Meeting" means encountering. Encountering the Dao and attaining ease, the inner realm becomes pure and unchanging. Though one engages with the external world, they no longer know what they are doing. "Beginning with comfort and never departing from it" means that over time, even the sense of comfort is forgotten. It is like putting on shoes: at first, one notices how well they fit, but after wearing them long enough, the initial sense of comfort fades—this is forgetting comfort. This illustrates human nature to elucidate the Dao. One must personally experience it to grasp how Zhuangzi exhausts the principles of things.

There was a man named Sun Xiu who came to the door and lamented to Bian Qingzi: "In my village, I am not seen as diligent; in times of crisis, I am not seen as brave. Yet when tilling the fields, I meet with poor harvests; when serving a lord, I meet with unworthy times. I am shunned by my village, driven from my district—what crime have I committed against heaven? Why must I suffer such fate?" Bianzi replied: "Have you never heard of the conduct of the perfected person? They forget their liver and gall, abandon their ears and eyes, wander aimlessly beyond the dust and grime, roam freely in the realm of no affairs. This is called acting without reliance, growing without domination. Now you adorn your knowledge to astonish the foolish, cultivate your conduct to expose others’ flaws, shining as brightly as if carrying the sun and moon. How can this be?"

"Yet you have preserved your whole form and body, retained all nine orifices, and—unlike those struck midway by deafness, blindness, lameness, or deformity—are counted among the ranks of men. This is already fortune enough. Why then spare time to resent heaven?

Be gone."

Sunzi departed. Bianzi entered, sat for a while, then looked up to the sky and sighed. His disciples asked, "Master, why do you sigh?"

Bianzi replied, "Just now, when Rest came, I spoke to him of the virtue of the perfected person. I fear he was startled and may fall into confusion."

The disciples said, "Not so. If Sunzi’s words were right and yours were wrong, then wrongness could not confuse rightness. If Sunzi’s words were wrong and yours were right, then he was already confused when he came—what fault is yours?"

Bianzi said, "Not so. Once, a bird alighted in the outskirts of Lu. The Lord of Lu delighted in it, prepared a grand feast to entertain it, and performed the *Nine Shao* to please it. The bird grew anxious, sorrowful, and dizzy, and dared neither eat nor drink. This is called nourishing a bird with what nourishes oneself. As for nourishing a bird as a bird ought to be nourished, one should let it roost in deep forests, float upon rivers and lakes, feed on whatever it finds, and rest on level ground—nothing more.

Now, Rest is a man of narrow vision and shallow learning. When I spoke to him of the virtue of the perfected person, it was like burdening a field mouse with chariots and horses, or delighting a sparrow with bells and drums. How could he not be startled?

*Banished by his village* means cast out by his village. *Exposing others’ flaws* means setting himself apart from vulgar customs. *Adorning knowledge to astonish the foolish, cultivating conduct to expose flaws*—this speaks of his deliberate pursuit of fame to distinguish himself. *Shining as brightly as if carrying the sun and moon*—this shows his desire for renown.

He was already confused when he came; his confusion was not of my making. What fault is mine?

*Narrow vision* refers to his limited perspective, like a small opening. *Shallow learning* means his knowledge is superficial. His understanding was already shallow, yet I spoke to him of lofty matters. How could he not be startled and fall into self-doubt? This is meant to satirize the scholars of our time, whose vision is narrow and who remain ignorant of the great Dao.

*Feeding it with whatever it finds* means allowing it to eat freely and at ease. *Whatever it finds* means self-sufficiency.

The parable of nourishing the bird has already appeared in the *Supreme Joy* chapter."

*The *Nanhua Zhenjing Kouyi*, Scroll Twenty, concludes here. #1 *Lame*: The Ming edition reads *broken*.*
*The *Nanhua Zhenjing Kouyi*, Scroll Twenty-One, by Lin Xiang of Yuanzhai.*

**Outer Chapters: The Mountain Trees**

When Master Zhuang was traveling through the mountains, he saw a great tree with luxuriant branches and leaves. A woodcutter stood beside it but did not fell it. Asking the reason, he was told, “It is of no use.” Master Zhuang said, “This tree, by being useless, has fulfilled its natural lifespan.”

Emerging from the mountains, he lodged at the home of an old friend. The friend, delighted, ordered his servant to kill a goose and cook it. The servant asked, “One can caw, the other cannot—which should we kill?” The host replied, “Kill the one that cannot caw.”

The next day, a disciple asked Master Zhuang, “Yesterday, the tree in the mountains, by being useless, fulfilled its natural lifespan, yet today the host’s goose, by being useless, was killed. Where should the Master stand?” Master Zhuang laughed and said, “I would stand between usefulness and uselessness. Yet even between usefulness and uselessness, one only *seems* to be free—thus one is not yet free from entanglement. But if one rides the Dao and floats upon virtue, it is otherwise: no praise, no blame, now a dragon, now a serpent, transforming with the times, never clinging to a single form. Rising and falling, one takes harmony as one’s measure, drifting upon the origin of the myriad things. Treating things as things yet not being treated as a thing by them—how then could one be entangled? This is the method of Shennong and the Yellow Emperor.

As for the passions of the myriad things and the traditions of human relationships, it is not so. Union leads to separation, completion to ruin, sharpness to blunting, honor to criticism, action to loss, worthiness to scheming, unworthiness to deceit—how can one be certain of anything? Alas! Remember this, my disciples: only in the realm of the Dao can one be secure.

That uselessness preserves one’s natural lifespan has been said many times before. Now, adding the case of the goose killed for its uselessness, another meaning emerges. For whether useful or useless, one still clings to form and trace, and thus remains entangled. Only when good and evil are both dissolved, when nothing can be named, is one’s natural wholeness preserved.

To *ride the Dao* is to follow nature. *Now a dragon, now a serpent*—like Dongfang Shuo’s saying: “When used, it is a tiger; when unused, a rat.” Whether employed or set aside, one follows the times without fixed intent, thus free from both slander and praise. To *cling to a single form* is to have intent; to *never cling* is to be without intent. *Rising and falling* means advancing and retreating. *Harmony* is compliance. *Measure* is standard, principle. Taking compliance with nature as one’s rule, whether rising or falling, all is acceptable. *The origin of the myriad things* is the beginning of all things. This is what Shennong and the Yellow Emperor could do—hence it is called *the method of Shennong and the Yellow Emperor.*

*The passions of the myriad things* refers to private desires. *Tradition* means custom. *The traditions of human relationships* are the inherited practices of humankind. The following lines exhaustively describe human nature: where there is union, there is separation—so it is said, “In this world, no feast lasts forever.” Where there is completion, there is ruin—“Were nothing ever abolished, how could a ruler rise?” One who exposes their edges will inevitably be blunted; one who stands above others will be criticized. One who acts with intent will suffer loss in reputation. People resent success and delight in failure, so the worthy must scheme for self-preservation—hence *worthiness leads to scheming.* The unworthy, fearing loss, will stop at nothing, resorting to deceit and treachery—hence *unworthiness leads to deceit.* In worldly affairs, one cannot be certain of anything—hence *how can one be certain?* *Alas!* laments the imperfection of the world, the impermanence of human affairs, the peril of hidden dangers. These words strike close to home, so I urge you, my disciples, to remember them well. Only by following nature can one avoid harm—hence *only in the realm of the Dao can one be secure.*

When Shinan Yiliao met the Lord of Lu, the lord wore a troubled expression. Shinan said, “My lord, why do you look troubled?” The Lord of Lu replied, “I study the Way of the former kings, uphold the legacy of my ancestors, revere the spirits and honor the worthy, practicing these without ceasing—yet I cannot escape misfortune. This is why I am troubled.”

Shinan said, “My lord’s method of avoiding misfortune is too shallow. The sleek fox and the patterned leopard dwell in the mountains and forests, crouch in caves and grottos, remaining still. They move by night and rest by day, ever vigilant. Though hungry and thirsty, they still keep their distance from the rivers and lakes, seeking food with caution. Yet they cannot escape the snares and traps—what crime have they committed? Their pelts bring them disaster. Is the state of Lu not your pelt?

I wish you would shear away your form, shed your pelt, cleanse your heart, and cast off desire, wandering in the wilds where no one dwells. *Residing thus*—calm and at ease. Here, the idea of *using or not using* leading to misfortune means that though one should have no cause for trouble, one still cannot escape it. *Hidden and constrained*—dwelling in seclusion, even when hungry and thirsty, one emerges to seek food by the rivers and lakes, yet still avoids others, keeping one’s distance. *Mutually*—as in the saying, ‘pecking sideways, looking all around, dwelling deep and venturing out little.’ To *be burdened by one’s pelt* means that having fame and position in the world only invites disaster. This truth cuts deep—only those deeply entangled in worldly affairs can understand it.

In the southern lands, there is a place called the State of Establishing Virtue. Its people are simple and unrefined, with few private desires. They know how to work but not how to hoard, give without seeking repayment, do not know where duty lies, nor where propriety leads. Wild and uninhibited, they tread the great Way. Their lives are joyful, their deaths are fitting. I wish you would abandon your state, cast off custom, and walk alongside the Dao.”

The preceding discourse on the "wilds without people" speaks of the origin before all things—here again named the State of Establishing Virtue. Reading this passage, one sees that today’s practice of "seeking rebirth in the Pure Land" traces its source to the Warring States era. The southern lands had yet to connect with the Central States, so the text borrows their name without other intent.

"Knowing how to work but not how to hoard" means tilling the land to feed oneself without private accumulation. Unburdened by the names of ritual and duty, they are said not to know where duty leads or where propriety goes. "Wild and uninhibited" describes following the heart’s desires, all of which accord with the Dao—thus "treading the great Way." "Walking alongside the Dao" means encouraging one another with a heart that admires the Way, aspiring to reach this land.

The lord said: "That Way is distant and perilous, with rivers and mountains in between. I have no boat or carriage—what can be done?"
Master Shinan replied: "Be without rigid form, without lingering attachment—let this be your carriage."
The lord said: "That Way is secluded and far, with no one there. Who would be my neighbor? I have no provisions, no food—how could I reach it?"
Master Shinan replied: "Reduce your expenses, lessen your desires—though you lack provisions, you will find sufficiency. Cross the river and float upon the sea; gaze as far as you can and see no shore, advance further and know no end. Those who see you off will all turn back from the shore—from then on, you will be far away.

"Without rigid form" means not clinging to one’s body. "Without lingering attachment" means not clinging to one’s state. If you can cultivate this mind, you may go—thus it is called your carriage. With no desires, nothing is lacking—thus, "reduce expenses, lessen desires, and though you lack provisions, you will find sufficiency." Crossing rivers and floating on the sea, gazing without seeing the shore, advancing without knowing the end—these three words, "advancing without end," are expounded here. "Those who see you off all turn back from the shore—from then on, you will be far away"—this line is most profound.

It speaks of those who study the Dao: once awakened, what once aided their enlightenment—like those who bid farewell and see one off to the sea’s edge—all return. Whether awakened by the sound of bamboo or the rolling up of a blind, these are but the senders. Like one who sees swordplay and masters calligraphy, the sword was the means at first, but once awakened, the sword becomes the sender. Even reading books serves as a sender.

Thus, to possess others is a burden; to be possessed by others is sorrow. Therefore, Yao neither possessed others nor was possessed by them. I wish to free you from your burdens, remove your sorrows, and wander alone with the Dao in the boundless land.

When two boats cross a river side by side, if an empty boat drifts and strikes them, even a hot-tempered person would not grow angry. But if there were someone aboard, one would shout to make them push away—if the first call goes unheard, a second, and then a third, anger would surely follow with harsh words. Before, there was no anger, but now there is; before, the boat was empty, now it is full. If one can empty oneself and wander through the world, who could harm them?

"Possessing others" means using the self to control things. "Being possessed by others" means being controlled by things. Neither accords with the natural Way. Yao neither used the self to control things nor was controlled by them—thus it is said he neither possessed others nor was possessed by them.

The "boundless land" is the vast emptiness of the Great Void—the same as the "wilds without people" and the State of Establishing Virtue. This concludes the preceding chapter, its meaning now complete, followed by an analogy.

"Two boats side by side" refers to paired vessels. If my boat is underway and struck by an empty one, since the boat is empty, I would not grow angry. But if someone were suddenly aboard the empty boat, I would call out to make them push away. If my first call goes unheard, then a second, and by the third, I would surely curse. No one means emptiness; someone means fullness. Before, with no one, there was no anger—now, with someone, anger arises. Such is human nature. This analogy is excellent.

It means: if I am without intent, I will not clash with things. Wandering through this world with an empty heart, what harm could there be?

After this long discourse, the analogy brings it to a close—this is the method of structuring a text from beginning to end. *Liezi* contains a similar passage:

When Beigong She levied taxes for Duke Ling of Wei to cast bells, he built an altar outside the city gates and completed the upper and lower chime racks in three months. Wang’s Qing Ji saw this and asked: "What technique did you employ?"
She replied: "In the midst of purity, I dared not impose anything. I have heard that once carving and polishing are done, one returns to simplicity. Unknowing and carefree, drifting in boundless uncertainty, I sent off the departing and welcomed the arriving—letting newcomers come without restraint, letting the departing go without hindrance, following their strength, adapting to their shapes, and letting them reach their own ends. Thus, though I levied taxes day and night, not a hair was harmed—how much more so for those on the great path?"

Levying the people’s wealth to cast bells, he first made offerings before smelting—thus "building an altar and completing it in three months." Bells have frames to hang them, and the frames have two tiers—hence "upper and lower racks," referring to the chime arrangement.

"What technique did you employ?" means: what method allowed such speed? "Purity" means undivided. Following the principle of nature, maintaining purity from beginning to end without interference—thus "in the midst of purity, I dared not impose anything." It is like saying nothing else could be inserted here.

"Once carving and polishing are done, one returns to simplicity" means shedding sharp edges to return to nature.

How vacant and unknowing in appearance! How hesitant and doubtful, as if without any intent or purpose! Some come, some go—neither leading nor welcoming—hence "gathered yet scattered." "Gathered" suggests a solid mass; "scattered," the absence of form. Let those who come not be barred, and those who go not be detained—this means following their natural course without welcoming or sending off. Those who depart in defiance and refuse to comply are crooked and cling stubbornly; those who turn back and attach themselves to me, I follow and heed, allowing them to be as they are. "Self-exhausting" means self-arriving. Whether compliant or resistant, in the end, none seek yet all arrive of themselves—thus "following their self-exhaustion." Though I levy taxes, not a hair of the people is harmed—hence "not a hair was harmed." Those on the great path proceed smoothly and openly; simply approach it with a mind free of intent, and all is swiftly accomplished.

When Confucius was besieged between Chen and Cai, he went seven days without cooked food. Taigong Ren went to console him, saying: "You nearly died, did you not?" "Indeed," replied Confucius. "Do you detest death?" "Indeed." Ren said: "Let me speak to you of the way of not dying. In the Eastern Sea there is a bird called the *yidai*. As a bird, it is slow and sluggish, appearing incapable. It takes flight only with the aid of others, and perches only when pressed. It does not dare to lead in advancing nor to lag in retreating. It does not dare to be the first to eat, but must take the leavings. Thus, though it flies in formation, it is not driven away, and outsiders never harm it—so it avoids disaster. The straightest trees are felled first; the sweetest wells run dry first. You, with your intent to adorn knowledge to startle the ignorant, cultivate yourself to expose others’ flaws, and shine forth as if carrying the sun and moon in your stride—how could you escape harm? Long ago, I heard a man of great attainment say: 'Those who boast of themselves achieve no merit; those who take pride in their achievements ruin their names. Success is already a loss—who can relinquish merit and fame and return to the common fold? The Dao flows yet does not shine; dwelling in attainment, it does not claim a place. Pure and constant, it resembles madness. Erasing traces and relinquishing power, it does not pursue merit or fame—thus it bears no blame from others, and others bear none from it. The perfected person remains unknown—why do you delight in fame?'"

Confucius said: "Well said!" He then parted ways with his acquaintances, dismissed his disciples, and fled to the great marsh. He wore coarse furs and ate wild fruits, moving among beasts without disrupting their herds, among birds without disturbing their flocks. Neither beasts nor birds shunned him—how much more so for people!

"Do you detest death?"—this means: in this dire strait of mortal peril, does your heart also loathe it? "The way of not dying" refers to self-contentment free from disaster. The *yidai* is today’s swallow. "Slow and sluggish" describes its flight. "Taking flight with the aid of others" means flying in flocks. "Perching when pressed" means nesting near humans. "Not daring to lead in advancing nor to lag in retreating" means it does not contend in coming and going. "Leavings" are what others discard—it eats insects and the scraps of the world. "Not driven away" means not being numerous. Though it flies in formation, it does not gather in great numbers like crows or geese; each relies on human dwellings, and outsiders do not harm it. The straight tree and sweet well are metaphors for those who make themselves known through reputation.

The "man of great attainment" is a scholar of the great Dao. Those who boast of themselves cannot succeed; those who delight in merit and fame ultimately bring ruin upon themselves—all is self-inflicted harm. "Return to the common fold" means withdrawing to be as others. Proceeding in accord with the Dao, one remains obscure and self-effacing—hence "the Dao flows yet does not shine." Though one dwells in a time when one’s will may be fulfilled, one does not exalt oneself through reputation—hence "dwelling in attainment, it does not claim a place." "Not claiming" means not possessing. "Pure and constant" means unity. "Resembling madness" means appearing without intent. "Erasing traces and relinquishing power" means not pursuing merit or fame—this implies transformation without leaving a mark. I do not blame others, and others forget me—this is the perfected person. The perfected person desires no renown in the world. Why then do you delight in fame?

The final passage echoes the sentiment of "eating pork as if it were human flesh." Here, the name of Confucius is borrowed to expound the teaching—this is emphatic repetition.

Confucius asked Zisang Hu: "I was twice exiled from Lu, had a tree felled upon me in Song, erased my traces in Wei, was impoverished in Shang and Zhou, and besieged between Chen and Cai. I have endured these many hardships—my close associates have grown more distant, and my disciples and friends have scattered. What is the reason for this?" Zisang Hu replied: "Have you not heard of the man of Jia who fled? Lin Hui abandoned a jade disc worth a thousand gold pieces and carried a baby on his back as he fled. Someone said: 'Was it for the sake of money? The baby is of little worth. Was it for the sake of burden? The baby is a great encumbrance. Why abandon a jade disc worth a thousand gold pieces and carry a baby on your back as you flee?' Lin Hui said: 'That was bound by profit; this is bound by Heaven. Those bound by profit, when pressed by poverty, disaster, or harm, abandon one another; those bound by Heaven, when pressed by poverty, disaster, or harm, draw closer together. The difference between drawing closer and abandoning is vast. Moreover, the friendship of the noble is as bland as water; the friendship of the petty is as sweet as wine. The noble are bland yet intimate; the petty are sweet yet easily severed. Those who unite without cause will part without cause.'"

Confucius said: "I respectfully receive your instruction." He then walked slowly and leisurely back, abandoned his learning, discarded his books, and his disciples no longer vied for his attention—yet their affection for him grew even deeper.

Zisang Hu—*Hu* means "door." "The man of Jia" refers to a man from the state of Jia. The metaphor of abandoning jade to carry a child is most apt. Those bound by Heaven always draw together; those bound by profit always abandon one another. The friendship of the noble is bland yet intimate; the friendship of the petty is sweet yet easily severed—this perfectly captures the ways of the world. Though these words appear in the *Analects* and *Mencius*, they are fitting here.

"Those who unite without cause will part without cause—this is clearly seen in the *Mang* poem. This single line forms another fine thread of coherence.

'His disciples no longer vied for his attention'—unrestrained by immediate concerns. *Yi* refers to the ritual of bowing. Yet their affection for him grew even deeper.

Later, Zisang Hu said: As Shun was about to die, he truly admonished Yu, saying: 'Be ever vigilant! In form, follow the natural course; in feeling, follow the natural impulse. Following the natural course ensures no separation; following the natural impulse ensures no toil. Without separation or toil, one does not seek adornment to await the form; without seeking adornment to await the form, one fundamentally does not depend on external things.'

*Ling* is pronounced *ling*, meaning 'to enlighten.' Shun spoke to Yu with the true and unadorned Dao, hence 'truly admonished.' *Yuan* means to follow its natural state; *shuai*, to comply with its natural tendency. 'No separation' means to become one with the Dao. 'Form' refers to the self. 'Adornment' refers to things external to the body. 'Not seeking adornment to await the form' means not relying on external things to sustain the self—hence 'fundamentally does not depend on external things.' Today, when people entertain guests, they say 'to await guests'—this is the sense of the first *dai*. Not treating externals as adornment means having no need for things—hence 'fundamentally does not depend on things.' The second *dai* here carries the sense of 'not relying on.' The three instances of *dai* thus divide into two distinct meanings.

Zhuangzi wore coarse cloth patched with rags, tied his shoes with twisted hemp, and passed by the King of Wei. The king said: 'Why is the Master so weary?' Zhuangzi replied: 'It is poverty, not weariness. When a scholar possesses the Dao and virtue yet cannot put them into practice, that is weariness. Worn clothes and tattered shoes are poverty, not weariness—this is what it means to be out of step with the times.'

'Have you not seen the leaping monkeys? When they find themselves among nanmu, catalpa, and camphor trees, they grasp the vines, swing through the branches, and reign as kings among them—even Yi or Feng Meng could not take aim at them. Yet when they find themselves among thorny brambles, prickly ash, and wolfthorn, they move cautiously, glance about in fear, and tremble with dread. It is not that their sinews and bones have suddenly stiffened and lost their suppleness, but that their circumstances are unfavorable, leaving them unable to display their abilities. Now, dwelling among dark rulers and chaotic ministers, how can one avoid weariness? This is comparable to the case of Gan, whose heart was cut out as proof.'"

Cloth of coarse hemp is but a rough fabric. *Hui* refers to a sash; a proper sash is tied at the waist. To "bind the shoes" means to thread them with cord when they are worn out. *Bei* signifies illness. *Lan* means to grasp; *man*, to entwine—these two words depict the monkey in the trees, naturally and without carelessness. "Reigning as king" expresses the fullness of its ambition and the satisfaction of its will. *Zhe*, *ji*, *zhi*, and *gou* are all thorn-bearing trees. "Trembling" denotes fear. The phrase "not supple" with the addition of "stiffened" is particularly apt. Medical texts describe a condition of stiffened neck and nape—this is stiffness without suppleness, and it vividly captures the monkey’s state.

"As proof" means that, by comparing this to the case of Bi Gan, one sees its verification. These three characters are also striking.

When Confucius was stranded between Chen and Cai, he went seven days without cooked food. Leaning against a withered tree with his left hand and striking its withered branches with his right, he sang the airs of the *Yan* clan. There was the form but not the measure, the sound but not the tones of gong or jue. The sound of wood and the sound of man—neither held constancy in the human heart. Yan Hui stood upright, hands folded, and turned his gaze to observe.
