Boils appear above, hemorrhoids below—yet the lower the cure, the richer the reward. To gain chariots by licking hemorrhoids is base, a humiliation unworthy of esteem."

Duke Ai of Lu asked Yan He: "I regard Confucius as the state’s pillar; will the realm not be well-ordered?" Yan He replied: "Perilous indeed! Dangerous and crumbling! Confucius adorns feathers with paint, engages in florid speech, exalts the branch over the root, and forces his nature to govern the people—yet he neither knows nor trusts himself. His heart clings to this, his spirit is ruled by it. How could he be fit to lead the people? Does he truly benefit you, or do you merely sustain him? You would be deceived. Now, if you cause the people to abandon truth and study falsity, this is no way to instruct them. If you consider posterity, it would be better to cease. A steadfast pillar suffices to support affairs.

The *Book of Songs* says: 'The pillar of the state.' A steadfast pillar is like a worthy assistant. 'There is healing' means the state’s ills can yet be cured. *Ji* means peril; *dai* likewise means danger. 'Perilous indeed! Dangerous and crumbling!'—this is extreme peril. *Hua* means color; after coloring an object, he further adorns it with feathers—his embellishments are excessive. 'Florid speech' refers to ornate, extravagant words. 'Exalting the branch over the root' means his guiding principle lacks foundation. 'Forcing his nature' means artificial zeal. 'Governing the people' means standing above them. 'Neither knows nor trusts' means he does not recognize his own insincerity. 'His heart clings to this' means his heart is fixated on it. 'His spirit is ruled by it' means his spirit takes it as its master. 'How could he be fit to lead the people?' means he is unfit to guide them. 'He' refers to the Master; 'you' refers to Duke Ai. 'Does he truly benefit you?'—thus he says, 'Does he suit you?' *Yi* means to nourish. If you regard him as worthy and sustain him, he will bring you no benefit but only deception. 'Deceived, perhaps' means deception may well occur. Now, if you cause the people of the state to abandon truth and learn deceit, this is no way to teach them. *Shi* means to instruct. If you consider posterity, it would be better to cease. *Xiu* means to stop.

Difficult to govern! To act upon others yet not forget it is not the Heavenly Way. Merchants are not esteemed; even if circumstances force one to rank with them, the spirit does not esteem them. External punishments are metal and wood; internal punishments are action and transgression. When petty men incur external punishments, metal and wood interrogate them; when they incur internal punishments, yin and yang consume them. Only the true person can escape both internal and external punishments.

The people need not be governed; to govern with intent is to make governance difficult—thus it is called 'difficult to govern.' 'To act upon others yet not forget' means governing with intent. *Shi* means to administer policy. *Bu* means to display. The Heavenly Way is the Heavenly Principle. To administer policy and instruction with intent is not the Heavenly Principle. It is like merchants: a gentleman would never rank with them, and even if circumstances force a gathering, his spirit remains displeased. Likewise, a person of the Dao would not rank with those who act with intent. This analogy likens merchants to scholars of benevolence and righteousness.

External punishments are the blade, saw, and cangue; internal punishments are action and transgression. A person’s movements and faults are akin to corporal punishment. *Xun* means interrogation. 'Yin and yang consume them' means they are afflicted by the Creator’s reproach. *Shi* is like the eclipse of the sun—it brings illness. The first clause describes external punishment; the second, internal. *Li* means attachment.

Confucius said: "In general, the human heart is more treacherous than mountains and rivers, harder to know than Heaven. Heaven has its seasons—spring, autumn, winter, summer, dawn, and dusk—but man has a thick exterior and deep emotions. Thus, some appear honest yet seek profit; some seem talented yet conceal their abilities; some are gentle and yielding yet discerning; some appear firm yet are weak and pliant; some seem slow yet are quick-tempered. Therefore, those who rush to righteousness are as thirsty for it as they are eager to flee it. Thus, the gentleman sends them far to observe their loyalty, brings them near to observe their respect, burdens them to observe their ability, questions them suddenly to observe their knowledge, sets urgent deadlines to observe their trustworthiness, entrusts them with wealth to observe their benevolence, warns them of danger to observe their integrity, intoxicates them with wine to observe their restraint, and mingles them with others to observe their demeanor. When all nine tests are complete, the unworthy are revealed.

'Thick exterior and deep emotions' means that feigned appearances are not easily seen, and hidden feelings are not easily fathomed. Some appear simple and honest yet secretly seek profit; some harbor great talent yet outwardly seem incapable. *Bu xiao* means 'not resembling.' Some are gentle and yielding yet discerning; *man* means entangling. Some seem firm yet are weak and pliant—*The Book of Songs* says: 'Once a hundred-fold refined steel, now pliable as a finger’s curl.' *Man* means to curl around a finger. *Han* means urgency. Some seem slow yet are quick-tempered. All this shows how inscrutable people are. 'Rushing to righteousness as if thirsty' describes their fervent advance."

Those who abandon righteousness as if scorched retreat swiftly—this describes their hasty withdrawal. The phrase "advancing fervently, retreating swiftly" is thus rendered with striking precision.

Those far apart are easily deceived, so observe their loyalty from afar. Those close and intimate are prone to familiarity and disrespect, so observe their reverence up close. Those tasked with urgent and complex matters may falter under pressure, so assign them sudden burdens to test their competence. Those slow to perceive hesitate in response, so question them abruptly to gauge their wisdom. Pressing deadlines easily lead to broken promises, so impose tight schedules to assess their trustworthiness. Facing wealth, one may resort to improper gain, so entrust them with riches to observe their benevolence—here, *benevolence* aligns with the term *Dao/Way*. Confronted with peril, one may seek cowardly escape, so warn them of danger to examine their integrity. Wine clouds the mind, so observe their dignity when drunk. Beauty bewitches, so place them in mixed company to see if they maintain self-restraint. *Zheng* means verification. Testing them through these nine methods reveals the worthy from the unworthy.

This passage’s reasoning is sound, though attributed to Confucius, showing that Zhuangzi was not disrespectful toward him. When Zheng Kaofu received his first appointment, he stooped; at the second, he bent; at the third, he prostrated himself, shuffling along walls—who would dare not follow his example? Yet there are those who, upon their first appointment, strut with arrogance; at the second, dance atop chariots; and at the third, address elders by name—who could reconcile such conduct with the ways of Yao and Xu You? *Yu* means a hunched back; *lou*, a bent waist; *fu*, bowing to the ground—all signify that the higher one’s rank, the lower one’s posture. Shuffling along walls shows one dares not walk the main path, embodying humility. If the world had such virtuous men, who would not take them as models? *Gui* means model. *Er fu* refers to such men. *Lü ju* describes a haughty demeanor; dancing on chariots, frivolous behavior; calling elders by name, arrogance toward kin. *Tang* refers to Yao; *Xu*, to Xu You. Yao offered the throne to Xu You, who refused—how could such petty men, upon slight success, grow so arrogant, oblivious to the examples of Yao and Xu You? *Xie* means alignment. Comparing them to Yao and Xu You reveals the disparity. *Shu xie* asks: who could align them with such paragons?

No thief is greater than one whose virtue is deliberate, whose mind has eyes—once it has eyes and turns inward, inward vision leads to ruin. These words strike closest to the heart of those who pursue the Dao/Way. Chan Buddhists call this the "leaking mind" or the "second thought," capturing this very idea. *De/virtue* here means "to practice virtue." To practice virtue while being conscious of it is to act with intent—this is the greatest hindrance to those on the Dao/Way, hence "no thief is greater than one whose virtue is deliberate." Within this intent, if one begins calculating and scheming, it is as if the mind grows another eye—this is the "leaking mind," the "second thought." With this eye turned inward, distinctions multiply, chaos reigns, and the primordial unity is lost, leaving no path to the Dao/Way. Thus, it is called *ruin*—failure.

There are five pernicious virtues, with the central one foremost. What is the central virtue? It is self-satisfaction that scorns what one does not do. The five pernicious virtues correspond to the heart, ears, eyes, nose, and mouth, with the central virtue being the heart. The harm of the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth does not compare to that of the heart, hence "the central virtue is foremost." *Having self-satisfaction* means believing in one’s own abilities. *Pi* means to disparage or mock. To belittle others for what they cannot do is to render the heart unfit for the Dao/Way. The *Yuanjue Sutra* says: "Do not disdain long practice or slight beginners." Dahui warned: "Never think, 'I understand, they do not'—this is the very meaning here."

Exhaustion has eight extremes, success three certainties, and the body six repositories. Handsome beards, tall stature, robust build, radiant beauty, strength, courage, and boldness—eight traits surpassing others—lead to ruin when relied upon. Compliance, adaptability, and timidity, though inferior to others, ensure smooth passage. Wisdom and cunning, when outwardly displayed, breed resentment; courage and daring invite grievances; benevolence and righteousness bring reproach. Those who grasp the essence of life are enigmatic; those who grasp knowledge are elusive. Those who grasp the great mandate follow; those who grasp the small mandate encounter.

*Exhaustion has eight extremes* means that reliance on any trait leads to ruin. *Success has three certainties* means that those who humbly acknowledge their shortcomings will inevitably thrive. *Beautiful* refers to appearance; *ran*, to having a beard (as Fang Xuanling said of Li Wei’s beard). *Tall* means height; *large*, girth; *strong*, physical power; *radiant*, splendor; *brave*, vigor; *daring*, resolve. These are the eight extremes—traits that surpass others. Relying on them leads to ruin. *Compliance* means yielding and adapting to circumstances. *Adaptability* means rising after falling. *Timidity* means distress and fear. These three traits, though inferior to others, ensure smooth passage, as people favor those who do not compete. These are Zhuangzi’s contrarian arguments.

*The body has six repositories* refers to the six accumulations within the human form. *Repository* means a place of storage. Wisdom is one repository; *outwardly displayed* means applying wisdom externally to seek success. Courage is another; relying on strength breeds resentment. Benevolence and righteousness form another; seeking fame through them invites reproach.

Kuai (sounds like "魁").

*Attaining life* is one repository—violating the principles of life leads to haughty self-exaltation. *Attaining knowledge* is another—grasping the insights of the multitude necessitates scrutinizing every matter. Xiao (sounds like "消").

*Attaining destiny* is another repository. That which lies with Heaven is great; that which lies with oneself is small. To attain what lies with Heaven is to follow and yield to it, heeding nature. To attain what lies with oneself is to accept whatever one encounters as fate. Though encounters may bring gain or loss, a heart that entrusts itself to destiny remains free of attachment. These two are distinct in meaning. The six repositories conclude with the character *destiny*, which is elaborated into two clauses—this is a matter of literary structure.

There was a man who had an audience with the King of Song. The king bestowed upon him ten carriages, and with these ten carriages, he grew arrogant toward Zhuangzi. Zhuangzi said: "By the river lived a poor family who made their living weaving reeds. Their son dived into the depths and obtained a pearl worth a thousand gold pieces. His father said to him, 'Bring a stone and pound it!' For a pearl of such value must lie in the ninefold abyss beneath the chin of a black dragon. That you could obtain it means you must have encountered the dragon while it slept. Had the black dragon been awake, what scrap of you would have remained?"

"Now, the depths of the state of Song are not merely a ninefold abyss, and the King of Song is fiercer than a black dragon. That you could obtain these carriages means you must have encountered him while he slept. Had the King of Song been awake, you would have been ground to powder."

*Arrogance* here means haughty condescension, as if patting Zhuangzi like a child. *Weaving* means to plait; *reeds* are rushes. This is the same as the character for "编曲." They relied on this craft for sustenance, selling their wares. "Bring a stone and pound it" expresses disdain for the pearl and the desire to destroy it. This analogy illustrates that those who seek wealth and rank tread a perilous path, deceiving their ruler. If the ruler awakens, they will surely face execution. "What scrap of you would have remained" means being devoured without a trace.

Someone sent an invitation to Zhuangzi, who replied to the messenger: "Have you seen the sacrificial ox? It is clothed in embroidered silk and fed with fine hay and beans. Yet when it is led into the grand temple, though it may wish to be a lone calf, how could that be possible?" This echoes the earlier passage about the turtle dragging its tail in the mud.

When Zhuangzi was near death, his disciples wished to bury him with lavish rites. Zhuangzi said: "I take heaven and earth as my inner and outer coffins, the sun and moon as my paired jades, the stars and constellations as my pearls and beads, and the myriad things as my funeral gifts. Are not my burial preparations already complete? What could be added to them?"

His disciples said: "We fear that crows and kites will feast on you."

Zhuangzi replied: "Above, I would be eaten by crows and kites; below, by ants and mole crickets. To snatch me from one to give to the other—how partial you are!" This was a rebuke of those in his time who practiced extravagant burials. To take from crows and kites to give to ants and mole crickets is partiality. Though his words may seem extreme, they are not easily matched by those who have not truly attained the Dao.

To level with what is not level is to fail to achieve levelness; to verify with what is unverified is to fail to achieve verification. The enlightened are but servants of things; the spiritually attuned verify them. That the enlightened cannot surpass the spiritually attuned has long been so. Yet fools rely on their limited perceptions to impose upon others, seeking merit in externals—is this not lamentable?

The principles of the myriad things are fundamentally level. If I use an unlevel mind to level what is already level, then what was level becomes unlevel. The principles of the myriad things are each verifiable. If I use an unverified mind to verify them, then what was verifiable becomes unverified. Thus it is said: to level with what is not level is to fail to achieve levelness; to verify with what is unverified is to fail to achieve verification.

*Verification* means confirmation. "Servants of things" describes those who, though they do nothing, are made to act as if by something else—this is to impose intention where there is none. The enlightened are often burdened in this way. As for the spiritually attuned, they simply allow things to respond naturally. That the enlightened cannot surpass the spiritually attuned means that human effort cannot surpass non-action. Fools rely on their private views to impose upon others, constantly seeking merit in externals—is this not lamentable?

*Oral Exegesis of the Southern Florescence Perfect Scripture*, Scroll Thirty-One (concluded)
*Oral Exegesis of the Southern Florescence Perfect Scripture*, Scroll Thirty-Two

Lin Xiyi of Yanzhai Studio, *Miscellaneous Chapters: "The World"*

The world abounds with those who cultivate methods of governance, each deeming their own approach unsurpassable. Yet where, truly, does the ancient *Dao*-art reside? It is said: nowhere it is not present. Then by what means does the numinous descend, and from whence does clarity emerge? The sage’s arising and the king’s accomplishment both originate from the One. Not departing from the Source is called the "Heavenly Person." Not departing from essence is called the "Spiritual Person." Not departing from the authentic is called the "Perfected Person." Taking Heaven as their source, virtue as their root, and the Dao as their gate, presaging through transformation—this is the sage. Taking benevolence as their thought, righteousness as their principle, propriety as their conduct, and music as their harmony, suffused with compassion and kindness—this is the noble person. Taking law as their division, names as their markers, conduct as their verification, and examination as their judgment—such is the enumeration of one, two, three, four, by which the hundred officials rank themselves. Taking duty as their norm, clothing and food as their priority, they foster growth, store provisions, and care for the elderly, the weak, the orphaned, and the widowed—all to nurture the people. Such is the governance of the common folk.

The ancients were truly complete. They matched the divine luminaries, harmonized with Heaven and Earth, nurtured the myriad things, brought harmony to the world, and extended their blessings to the hundred clans. Clear about fundamental principles and connected to the yet-unmeasured, their operation—encompassing the six directions and the four openings, the refined and the coarse, the great and the small—was nowhere absent. Those manifestations of clarity that reside in measures and degrees are still largely preserved in the transmitted records of ancient laws. Those found in the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music* are often elucidated by the scholars of Zou and Lu, the girdle-wearing masters. The *Odes* guide the will, the *Documents* guide affairs, the *Rites* guide conduct, the *Music* guides harmony, the *Changes* guide yin and yang, and the *Spring and Autumn* guide names and duties. These principles, dispersed throughout the world and established in the Central States, are at times expounded and transmitted by the hundred schools.

Yet when the world fell into great disorder, the worthy and the sagely were obscured, the Dao and virtue were no longer unified, and the world’s people each grasped but a single insight to cherish as their own. Like the ear, eye, nose, and mouth—each possessing its own clarity yet unable to communicate with the others—so too are the hundred schools and their various arts, each possessing its own strength and occasional utility. Nevertheless, they are neither comprehensive nor all-encompassing, being but partial scholars. To judge the beauty of Heaven and Earth, to analyze the principles of the myriad things, to examine the wholeness of the ancients—few can fully embody the beauty of Heaven and Earth or match the countenance of the divine luminaries. Thus, the Way of inner sageliness and outer kingship has grown dim and obscured, stifled and unexpressed. The people of the world each pursue what they desire, fashioning their own methods.

Alas! The hundred schools have gone forth and not returned; they will surely never converge. Later scholars, unfortunate in not witnessing the purity of Heaven and Earth or the greatness of the ancients, will see the *Dao*-art rent asunder by the world.

In the final chapter, Zhuangzi’s preface on the learning of past and present resembles the closing of Mencius’ work, where "hearing knowledge" and "seeing knowledge" are discussed. From "The world abounds with those who cultivate methods of governance" to "the *Dao*-art will be rent asunder by the world," it serves as a clear introduction. Having provided this general preface, he then proceeds to discuss the various schools, placing his own work among them. Yet the learning of Zou and Lu is expounded within the general preface, revealing that this elder’s intent was never to dismiss the Confucian tradition as merely one-sided or extreme—he was well aware that the Sage’s gate was the true standard. Reading this preface, one sees that his learning was fundamentally sound. As Su Dongpo observed, Zhuangzi never disparaged the Master.

*Fangshu* means "learning" or "art." Each person deems their own learning unsurpassable, for all are self-assured. The ancient *Dao*-art—this *yan* (衍) is akin to "benevolent arts" or "heart arts." Where does it reside? Nowhere it is not present—this conveys the idea of the "mean in timing," for though the hundred schools differ, the Dao is never absent from their midst. By what means does the numinous descend, and from whence does clarity emerge? This asks how the Way of spirit and luminosity may be perceived. The sage’s accomplishments in arising and the king’s in completion are the same as the principles of Heaven and Earth’s generation—all originate from the One. The One is creation itself. "Source," "essence," and "authentic" are all synonymous with the One, differing only in phrasing.

Taking Heaven as their source, virtue as their root, and the Dao as their gate—all are non-action and spontaneity. "Presaging through transformation" is the same as "originating from the One." The sage is thus the Heavenly Person, the Perfected Person, and the Spiritual Person. "Suffused with compassion and kindness" describes their demeanor. Laws entail distinctions, hence "taking law as their division." Names serve as standards, hence "taking names as their markers." "Taking conduct as their verification" and "examination as their judgment" mean that their verifications and judgments are each grounded in evidence. The enumeration of one, two, three, four signifies meticulous clarity in all details. "Ranking themselves" means that great and small, high and low are ordered. "Taking duty as their norm" means each has a regular office. "Taking clothing and food as their priority" means teaching the people agriculture and sericulture. "Fostering growth and storing provisions" refers to practices like storing a year’s food for every three years of farming. "Caring for the elderly, the weak, the orphaned, and the widowed" means that in enacting governance and bestowing benevolence, these four groups must come first. All their divisions of offices, arrangements of duties, governance, and instruction are for the nurturing of the people.

"The ancients were truly complete" means the ancient sages could fulfill all these. They could match the divine luminaries and harmonize with Heaven and Earth. "Harmonized" means attuned. "Nurturing the myriad things, harmonizing the world, extending blessings to the hundred clans" describes the vastness of their efficacy. "Fundamental principles and yet-unmeasured degrees" are akin to "refined and coarse, root and branch." "Connected" means interrelated, signifying that root and branch do not depart from one another. "Six directions and four openings" mean east, west, south, north, above, and below—nowhere is unusable. "Operation" means the Dao.

The operation of the Dao encompasses the small and large, refined and coarse—all are the Dao, hence it is said to be present everywhere without exception. Examining these several lines, one sees that the substance and function of the Dao are never left obscure.

Numerical standards and degrees are what can be recorded, meaning their methods and measures—clear and traceable—are all transmitted through established models of past ages. *Shi* refers to written records. There are still many such accounts, for all these matters are documented therein.

The scholars of Zou and Lu, the girdled gentlemen—these refer to the sagely lineage, explicitly speaking of Confucius’ Six Classics. The *Spring and Autumn* upholds proper names and distinctions, for even the two words "names and distinctions" already contain a warning against rebellious ministers and traitorous sons. Their teachings spread throughout the world, meaning that while Zou and Lu preserved the complete tradition, its learning dispersed across the land, establishing instruction in the Central States and branching into a hundred schools. There were still those who occasionally spoke of these matters, yet none could match the completeness of the learning of Zou and Lu.

The great disorder of the world refers to the period after the *Spring and Autumn*. The worthy and sagely were no longer manifest; above, there were no Wen or Wu, no Duke of Zhou, and below, no disciples like Confucius or Yan Hui. The Way and virtue were no longer unified, scattering into a hundred schools. Many in the world grasped but a single fragment, examining it and taking pride in it, meaning they merely scrutinized one aspect and boasted of it. The ears, eyes, nose, and mouth cannot function interchangeably—ears cannot see, eyes cannot hear, mouths cannot smell, noses cannot taste—each follows its own capacity, hence it is said that each has its own clarity. This analogy applies to the hundred schools and their various arts: each has its strengths and may be useful at times, yet none can fully encompass the comprehensive Way of the sages. Thus, they are but partial and one-sided scholars.

The beauty of Heaven and Earth is thereby divided and incomplete; the principles of the myriad things are thereby fragmented and discordant. If one examines them through the complete learning of the ancients, one knows that the one-sidedness of the hundred schools rarely embodies the full beauty of Heaven and Earth or matches the countenance of the divine luminaries. *Beauty* refers to the Dao within, its substance; *countenance* refers to the Dao without, its function. *Matching* means being fitting. Few can truly match the countenance of the divine luminaries, meaning they fall short of being fitting.

Inward sageliness is substance; outward kingship is function. With the Dao of inner and outer thus obscured, each person pursues what they desire and fashions their own methods. The learning of the hundred schools, from this point onward, has strayed and cannot return, making reunification impossible. Later scholars cannot perceive the pure wholeness of Heaven and Earth or the complete body of the ancient Way—this is the misfortune of later ages.

The arts of the Dao in the world have since become fragmented, hence it is said, "The arts of the Dao will be torn asunder throughout the world." This concluding line is exceptionally forceful and finely wrought.

Not extravagant toward later ages, not wasteful toward the myriad things, not dazzled by numerical standards, yet using the carpenter’s line to correct oneself and prepare for the world’s emergencies—such were the ancient arts of the Dao. Mo Di and Qin Guli, hearing of this approach, delighted in it. Yet they carried it to excess, imposing rigid uniformity, creating the doctrine of "opposing music" and calling it "frugality." They forbade singing in life and mourning in death; Mozi advocated universal love, mutual benefit, and opposition to conflict. His Way eschewed anger, and he was fond of learning and transmitting without deviation, yet he did not align with the former kings, instead condemning the rites and music of antiquity.

The Yellow Emperor had the *Xianchi*, Yao the *Dazhang*, Shun the *Dashao*, Yu the *Daxia*, Tang the *Huo*, King Wen the music of the *Biyong*, and King Wu and the Duke of Zhou composed the *Wu*. In ancient mourning rites, noble and base had their proper forms, superior and inferior their respective ranks. The Son of Heaven had seven layers of inner and outer coffins, the feudal lords five, high ministers three, and officers two. Yet Mozi alone forbade singing in life and mourning in death, using a paulownia coffin three inches thick without an outer coffin as the model. Teaching others thus seems unloving; practicing it oneself is surely self-neglect.

This does not yet defeat Mozi’s Way. Yet to sing yet oppose singing, to weep yet oppose weeping, to delight yet oppose delight—is this truly reasonable? Their lives are toilsome, their deaths meager; their Way is harsh, causing people sorrow and grief. Their conduct is difficult to uphold, and one fears it cannot be the Way of the sages. It runs counter to the hearts of the world, and the world cannot endure it. Though Mozi alone could bear it, what could he do about the world? Separated from the world, he is far from the kingly Way.

Mozi spoke of the Dao, saying: "In ancient times, Yu controlled the floodwaters, dredged the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers, and connected the four barbarians and the nine provinces. There were three hundred famous rivers, three thousand tributaries, and countless smaller streams. Yu personally wielded the spade and basket, mingling with the laborers across the land’s rivers. His calves bore no flesh, his shins no hair; he bathed in heavy rain and combed his hair in fierce winds, establishing ten thousand states. Yu was a great sage, yet he wearied his body for the world." Thus, later Mohists often wore coarse garments of felt and hempen sandals, laboring day and night without rest, taking self-imposed hardship as the ultimate virtue. Those who could not endure this were deemed unworthy of the Mohist name and insufficient to be called followers of Yu.

The disciples of Xiangli Qin and the followers of Wu Hou, along with the southern Mohists like Ku Huo, Ji Chi, and Deng Lingzi, all recited the Mohist canon yet diverged in their interpretations, calling one another "deviant Mohists." They engaged in debates over the "hard and white" and "same and different," responding to one another with sophistry and contrariness. They revered the *Juzi* as a sage, all wishing to serve as his representative, hoping to succeed him, yet to this day they remain unresolved.

Mo Di and Qin Guli’s intentions were sound, but their conduct was misguided. They would have later Mohists necessarily wear themselves out—calves without flesh, shins without hair—competing in asceticism. This is the height of disorder and the nadir of governance.

Though indeed, Mozi was truly one who loved the world—one whom one might seek in vain, yet even if he withered away, he would not abandon his cause. A man of true talent! He did not indulge later generations, nor did he teach them indulgence. "Lavishness" means adornment; he did not take the embellishments of the myriad things as adornment. "Radiance" means splendor; he did not take ritual, music, measures, or numbers as radiant splendor. The "inked line" was self-restraint; he restrained himself to correct the world, desiring that all under Heaven have abundance. His intent lay in frugality to ensure sufficiency, thus he spoke of meeting the world’s urgent needs, for people take clothing and food as urgent, leading to strife and disorder.

Among the arts of the Dao of antiquity, there were those that resided in this. Yet only Mo Di and Qin Guli heard of this teaching and rejoiced in it, hence it is said they "heard its wind and delighted in it." Precisely because they rejoiced in it, they proceeded to act upon it. "Excessive" means going too far. "Following" means compliance; "great compliance" refers to their doctrine’s overbearing restraint, thus it is called "their own great compliance." "Their own" conveys the sense of suppression. *Against Music* and *Moderation in Use* are chapter titles in Mozi’s writings. Having composed these, Mozi desired that in life, people would not sing—rejecting music—and in death, they would have no mourning garments, nearing bare burial, all to moderate use. "Universal love and mutual benefit" meant loving all without exception, thus deeming strife wrong and non-anger the Way. "Broad and undifferentiated" meant esteeming uniformity. Expanding his doctrine to serve as instruction, he centered it on esteeming uniformity. Though he sought unity, his teachings did not align with the former kings. From the Yellow Emperor to King Wu, none had done without music, yet Mozi sought to abolish it. From ancient times, from the noble to the base, none had lacked mourning rites, yet Mozi sought to abolish them, setting a standard of three-inch coffins without outer coffins—moderation in use. Teaching people thus was too harsh, hence it is said, "I fear this does not love others," for it is not the way to love people. "Not loving oneself" means self-affliction. "Ultimate ruin" means Mozi’s Way, in the end, cannot be practiced. People cannot live without song, yet Mozi deemed song wrong; human nature cannot do without weeping, yet Mozi deemed weeping wrong; they cannot do without joy, yet he deemed joy wrong. His Way was entirely removed from human sentiment, thus it is said, "Does this truly resemble it?" "Resemble" means proximity. Does this truly align with human sentiment? In life, they toiled in hardship; in death, they practiced meager burials. "Too crude" means too unrefined. Their conduct was difficult to emulate. They opposed the hearts of all under Heaven, being far from human sentiment. Though all under Heaven could not endure it, Mozi alone could—endurance, too, is endurance. Yet if only one can endure while all under Heaven cannot, what can be done? Having estranged the hearts of the people, it cannot serve as the Way to rule all under Heaven.

The great rivers between Heaven and Earth are called "famous rivers"; the tributaries were dredged by Yu. The *nang* was a vessel for carrying earth; the *si* was a tool for digging. The Nine Rivers were brought together, their functions harmonized to govern all the rivers under Heaven. Mozi’s doctrine held that Yu was a great sage who labored thus himself—how much more should others? "Raised heels" and "flat feet" are the same; "straw sandals" and "wooden clogs" are the same—wooden footwear is called *ji*, straw footwear *jue*. "Service" means use.

Xiangli was a surname; Qin was a given name, also a student of Mohism who became a teacher in the world. His disciples were all followers of the five feudal lords, indicating many studied under him. Ku Huo, Ji Chi, and Deng Lingzi were the names of three men. All three resided in the south, also studied the Mohist canon, yet their eccentricities surpassed even Mozi’s. Moreover, their doctrines all differed, so they named themselves "deviant Mohists," meaning separate branches of Mohism. "Not contrary" means not differing. Odd and even are inherently distinct, yet they claimed they did not conflict—this was forced sophistry. They used such contrarian rhetoric in their exchanges, hence it is said they "responded to one another." The *Juzi* was akin to the "foremost disciple," what Chan schools call a "Dharma heir." Among those who transmitted his teachings, they took the most accomplished as sages and made them their leaders. "Corpse" means leader. Hoping to become his successors, the *Juzi* transmitted it to their disciples as their posterity. "Posterity" still means descendants. "Unbroken" means uninterrupted, indicating its transmission continues to this day.

Tracing its origins, Mo Di’s intent was indeed noble, but his conduct was excessive, hence it is said, "his intent was sound, but his conduct was misguided." "Vying with one another" means emulating one another, for those who transmitted Mozi’s Way emulated self-affliction, desiring thereby to govern all under Heaven. Yet before governance could be seen, they first brought about disorder, hence it is said, "the height of disorder." Though Mozi’s goodness arose from the sincerity of his heart, there are no such people in the world today. "Seek in vain" means there are no longer such men.

"Unceasing" means unrelenting. Though they exhausted themselves to the point of emaciation, they never ceased their efforts—such men may indeed be called heroic scholars. "Scholars of talent" is a term for heroic figures. Mencius rejected Yang Zhu and Mo Di, and this text likewise mentions them together repeatedly. Yet when discussing the various schools by their doctrines, it omits the Yangists, for their teachings are deemed unworthy of inclusion.

Unburdened by convention, unadorned by externals, uncompromising toward others, unopposed to the multitude, they wished for the world’s peace to preserve all lives, seeking only that all—self and others—be fully provided for, and no more. In this they purified their hearts. Among the ancient arts of the Dao, some were found in this. Song Jian and Yin Wen, hearing of their example, were delighted. They fashioned the *Huashan* cap as their emblem, engaging all things by beginning with "distinguishing constraints," and called their teaching of the heart’s capacity "the conduct of the heart." They sought to harmonize and unite, to reconcile and pacify, proposing to establish this as their guiding principle.

They endured insult without shame, sought to end the people’s strife, forbid aggression, and halt warfare to save the age from conflict. With this, they traveled the world, persuading rulers above and instructing the people below. Though the world rejected them, they persisted stubbornly, unyielding in their advocacy—hence it is said, "both high and low grew weary of them, yet they forced themselves upon all."

"Unburdened by convention" means free from worldly entanglements. "Unadorned by externals" means not indulging in material things. "Unopposed to the multitude" means not defying human nature. Their wish was for all to live, seeing others as themselves, desiring only that each be sufficiently provided for. In this they centered their hearts and proclaimed it to the world—such was the teaching of Song Jian and Yin Wen.

*Huashan* is the name of their cap. "Distinguishing constraints" is akin to "being in ease." To "distinguish" is to abide by one’s lot, and to "be in ease" is to rest in spacious tranquility. "Beginning" means foundation. They engaged all things with this intent—"engaging" means drawing others in. "The heart’s capacity" refers to the heart’s inherent state. They expounded its nature to others, calling it "the conduct of the heart," for conduct is the heart’s function. This is akin to what the Buddhists call "the great function manifesting before one."

With the intent to harmonize, they sought to unite others in joy, to reconcile and unify all under Heaven, proposing to exalt Song Jian and Yin Wen as the leaders of their teaching. Seeing the people’s love of strife, they taught "enduring insult without shame" to save them. Seeing the age’s love of war, they taught forbidding aggression and halting warfare to save it. Above, they persuaded rulers; below, they instructed the common people. Though the world ignored them, they persisted stubbornly in their advocacy, boasting and expounding without cease. Both high and low grew weary of them, yet they forced themselves upon all—this saying must have been common at the time, hence it is repeated here to conclude.

Yet their concern for others was too great, and their care for themselves too little. They said: "Let us simply secure five *sheng* of rice—this will suffice." The master feared he would not be full, while the disciples, though hungry, never forgot the world, laboring day and night without rest, saying: "We must surely save lives!" How haughty were these would-be saviors of the world! Their concern for others was excessive, and their self-imposed suffering too great.

Their teaching held that each day, five *sheng* of rice would suffice for master and disciples to share. The master would still go hungry, so how could the disciples not? Thus, both master and disciples endured hunger to uphold their teaching. Yet they claimed: "We do not forget the world, laboring day and night without cease." They said: "Our self-imposed suffering is thus—how could this be a path to long life? But we do this to correct those who falsely claim to save the world while seeking their own gain." Hence it is said: "How haughty were these would-be saviors of the world!" "Haughty" means to correct. This is akin to Yu Rang’s words: "What I do is most difficult, to shame all those ministers who harbor divided loyalties." Li Bai’s poem *Drinking Alone, Sent to Wei Liu* contains the line: "I think of you wandering the world’s dust, haughty and self-mocking"—this is the same sense of "haughty."

They said: "The noble man does not engage in petty scrutiny, nor lend himself to things. If something is of no benefit to the world, clarifying it is not as good as abandoning it."

To take the prohibition of attack and the cessation of warfare as external matters, and the reduction of emotions and desires as internal ones—such are the distinctions between the great and the small, the refined and the coarse, and their practice extends no further than this.

Their teaching further states: "Do not engage in petty scrutiny, for petty scrutiny is contrary to the principle of *bie you* (distinguishing boundaries)." This means one should not insist on the distinction between self and other. "Not lending oneself to things" means that in all matters, one acts for oneself and does not rely on others for assistance. If something brings harm to the world and no benefit, even if one clearly knows it can be done, it is better to abandon it. Hence it is said: "Clarifying it is not as good as abandoning it."

The essence of their learning is this: externally, one should eliminate the conflicts of attack and warfare; internally, one should eliminate the turbulence of emotions and desires. *Gua qian* (reduction and restraint) refers to diminishing and curtailing emotions and desires. Though their learning varies in scale and refinement, the general thrust of their practice amounts to no more than this. *Shi* means "only."

Impartial yet not partisan, yielding yet without self-interest, resolute yet without fixed position, following things without duality, unburdened by deliberation, unguided by cunning—indiscriminate toward things, moving with them in unison: such were the ancient arts of the Way.

Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao heard of this teaching and delighted in it. They took the equalization of the myriad things as their guiding principle, saying: "Heaven can cover all things but cannot bear them; earth can bear all things but cannot cover them; the great Dao can encompass all things but cannot distinguish them. Knowing that all things have their *ke* (what is permissible) and their *bu ke* (what is not permissible), they said: 'Selection is never universal; teaching never reaches all; only the Dao leaves nothing behind.'"

Thus, Shen Dao abandoned knowledge and self, following only what could not be avoided. He let things flow naturally, taking this as the principle of the Dao, saying: "To know that one does not know is to approach the thinnest edge of knowledge—this is harmful." Xi Tan (or Xidan) said: "Without responsibility, he mocked the world’s esteem for worthies; unrestrained and unprincipled, he rejected the world’s great sages." Pushing and pulling, turning with things, he abandoned right and wrong, seeking only to avoid trouble. He did not rely on wisdom or planning, nor did he distinguish before or after. He was like a drifting gale, like a spinning feather, like a grinding stone’s rotation—whole yet without fault, moving or still without error, never incurring blame. Why? Because things without knowledge have no peril of self-assertion, no burden of cleverness. Moving or still, they do not depart from principle, and thus they pass their lives without praise. Hence it is said: "One reaches the state of things without knowledge, rendering worthies and sages useless."

A clod of earth does not lose the Dao. Yet the heroic laughed together, saying: "Shen Dao’s Way is not the conduct of the living but the principle of the dead—how bizarre!" Tian Pian was the same. He studied under Peng Meng and attained the teaching of "no instruction."

Peng Meng’s master said: "The ancient men of the Way reached the point of neither affirming nor denying anything." Their manner was abrupt and unyielding, difficult to describe. They often opposed others, avoided gatherings, and did not fall into the trap of rigid distinctions. What they called the Dao was not the Dao, and what they spoke of could not escape being wrong.

Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao did not understand the Dao. Nevertheless, in general, they had once glimpsed something of it.

"Not partisan" means also "without self-interest."

The *Yi* is level and smooth. *Jue* means to discard private intentions and have no partiality. "Following things" refers to the principles and tendencies of the myriad things. "Not two" means oneness. "Not turning to deliberation, not scheming with wisdom" means having no calculation. "Toward things, no selection"—no choosing—means the eye’s scope is even. "Going along with them" means following nature and acting. Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao were all recluses of Qi. Their teachings held that heaven and earth are also one among the myriad things, and if one calls them "one," then all are equal. Yet what leads them is the Way of non-action. Heaven can cover but cannot bear; earth can bear but cannot cover—this speaks of their partiality. The "Great Way" refers to the scholars of the Daoist school. They knew only to embrace all as one without distinction, a mode of discourse that existed in their time. "Each has what it affirms and what it denies" means each has its own partiality. If one selects among the myriad things, then one cannot be all-encompassing. To take this as a teaching is to fail to reach its ultimate. But if one returns to the Way, then nothing is left out. Hence it is said: "The Way leaves nothing behind." Selection entails affirmation and denial; to abandon knowledge, discard the self, and follow necessity—this is non-action. *Lingtai* means uninhibited. "Cool and unburdened toward things" means free from constraint. What they took as the principle of the Way was that things move without obstruction as the highest truth. Their teaching said: If one divides by knowledge and ignorance, one will be pressed by knowledge and come near to self-harm. *Bo* means pressing; *lin*, near. *Xikuo* describes something crooked and unstable. "No responsibility" means not fixing the mind on affairs. *Ren* means esteeming worthies to take up tasks. Since they did not engage in affairs, they laughed at the world’s esteem for worthies. The learning of the sage must uphold conduct, but since they were unrestrained and without conduct, they took the world’s scholars of sageliness as wrong. "Pushing and cutting off"—both mean having no sharp edges. "Turning with things" means having no sharp edges, no affirmation, no denial, with the aim of merely avoiding worldly entanglements. "Not taking knowledge and deliberation as a teacher" means having no thought. "Not knowing before and after" means no calculation. *Wei* (read as *wei*)—*weiran* means the sense of being towering and unmoving. "Pushed, then it moves; pulled, then it goes; pressed, then it responds"—this means rising only when compelled. "Wind returning, feather whirling, the path of a millstone"—all are metaphors for being without intent and turning with things. *Sui* means turning, revolving. They sought to preserve themselves by not being seen as wrong in the world, moving and resting in accord with nature without excess, thus avoiding offense to others. What was the basis of their learning? It was this: Only things without knowledge have no urgency for self-affirmation and no burden of concern. Moving and resting all follow the natural, so they do not depart from principle. Not seeking knowledge from human desires, they live their lives without praise. Precisely because they have no praise, they have no blame. Hence it is said: "They never incurred fault." Things without knowledge—such as wood, stone, tiles, and pebbles—are of this kind. "Establishing the self" means affirming the self and standing alone. Thus their teaching said: In living in the world, why use the names of sages and worthies? If one can be like a clod of earth, a thing without knowledge, then one does not lose the Way. Hence it is said: "The clod does not lose the Way." These words resemble those of the ascetics who practice austerities in remote mountains and valleys. Thus the heroic laughed at them, saying they were like dead men. "Strange indeed!" refers to Peng Meng and his followers being seen as odd by the world. "Received no instruction" means that in their early learning, they naturally resonated without needing teaching. Peng Meng was jealous of having a teacher, but his teacher’s words said: The ancients who possessed the Way took the absence of right and wrong as their foundation. *Huo ran*—the sound of wind—means their speech was like the rushing of wind. Without concern, though they spoke, what was there to hold in their words? Hence it is said: "How could one speak of it?" Their views were always contrary to the world, unable to gather and observe with others, thus becoming a one-sided teaching. "Not exempt from"—they merely sought to have no sharp edges. *Yuanduan* means having no sharp edges. Though their words were grand, what they called the Way was not the Way, so they were not exempt from the world’s ridicule. *Wei* is the same as *wei*. Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao did not understand the Way—this is Zhuangzi’s concluding judgment. "In general"—viewing them broadly, they had all heard something of this Way, but did not grasp its true essence. Such closing lines reveal his literary style.

The root is taken as essence, things as coarse; accumulation is seen as insufficient. Serene and alone, they dwelled with the spirit-like clarity—this was one of the ancient arts of the Way. Guan Yin and Lao Dan heard of their teachings and delighted in them. They established them on the constant of "nothingness and being," centered them on the Great One. They took gentleness, weakness, humility, and yielding as their outward form, and emptiness, non-destruction of the myriad things as their substance. Guan Yin said: "Abiding nowhere in the self, the forms of things manifest on their own. In movement, they are like water; in stillness, like a mirror; in response, like an echo. Fleeting as if vanished, silent as if pure. Those who are the same are in harmony; those who grasp lose. They never precede others but always follow." Lao Dan said: "Know the masculine, keep to the feminine, and be the world’s valley. Know the white, keep to the disgraceful, and be the world’s lowland. When others all seek to be first, I alone seek to be last, saying: I receive the world’s filth. When others all seek the substantial, I alone seek the empty. Having no store, thus I have surplus."

Abiding thus, it stands towering and ever-abundant. In conducting oneself, it is unhurried yet without waste, effortless yet mocking all contrivance. While others seek fortune, I alone seek the preservation of wholeness through bending, saying: "Merely to avoid blame." Taking depth as the root, restraint as the guiding principle, I say: "What is hard will shatter; what is sharp will break." Ever tolerant toward things, never carving away at others—this may be called the ultimate attainment.

Ah, Guan Yin and Lao Dan—were they not the great perfected of antiquity? The root is the Dao; things are the ten thousand affairs. Those who regard accumulation as insufficiency speak of treasuring wealth for all under heaven. Dwelling with the numinous and luminous is to guard the natural. That Guan Yin was a disciple of Lao Dan—this merely means that the disciple came first and the master later, a fleeting stroke of the brush. Taking nothingness as the essence, the inception of the Great Ultimate as the ruler—establishing this, too, is to rule.

"Gentle, weak, humble, and yielding" express the meaning of "the soft tongue endures." As outward form, this describes how one engages the world and interacts with things as seen externally. In emptiness, all things are preserved whole; thus it is said: "Taking emptiness and non-destruction of the myriad things as substance." Substance is the true principle. As Le Xuan said: "Where nothing exists, all things are complete."

"Abiding nowhere in the self" means having no private agenda. "The forms of things manifest on their own" means that the appearances of things arise naturally as they are. The movement of water, the stillness of a mirror, the response of an empty valley—all are without intent. "Fleeting as if vanished" describes the indistinct presence of something that seems both there and not there. "Silent as if pure" means that purity is not seen as purity. Harmony comes from being the same as things; to grasp is to lose. "Never preceding others but always following" means acting only when pressed, rising only when unavoidable.

"Know the masculine, keep to the feminine"—this is to conceal ability within inability. "Know the white, keep to the disgraceful"—this is to remain lowly while knowing one’s worth. Valleys and lowlands lie below yet contain all things; to be a valley or lowland is to embody the greatness of receptivity. "When others all seek to be first, I alone seek to be last"—this is the same as never preceding others but always following. "Receiving the world’s filth" is to know purity yet guard disgrace. Not taking the substantial for emptiness, nor emptiness for substance, thus when others all seek the substantial, I alone seek the empty. "Having no store, thus I have surplus"—this is the same as regarding accumulation as insufficiency. Only by taking emptiness as substance does one remain towering and ever-abundant, for where nothing is stored, all things are complete.

"Unhurried" means at ease. "Without waste" means without loss. While others prize skill, I find skill in non-action, thus I mock their contrivance. While others seek fortune, I seek fortune in the absence of misfortune. "Preservation of wholeness through bending" means that by yielding, one preserves oneself. "Merely to avoid blame"—there is no greater fortune than the absence of misfortune. "Taking depth as the root" means that the foundation lies in the inception of the Great Ultimate. "Taking restraint as the guiding principle" means that the utmost simplicity and frugality are the methods of preserving oneself. "Guiding principle" means method. All things that are hard or sharp will break or be blunted—this is what is meant by "teeth, being hard, will shatter."

Taking the capacity to contain all things as one’s measure, nothing can diminish one. "Never carving away at others" means preserving one’s own life alone. "This may be called the ultimate attainment"—this is the ultimate Dao under heaven. To call them "great perfected" is an expression of reverence.

Vast and formless, ever-changing and constant, death and life as one, coextensive with heaven and earth, moving with the numinous and luminous—where does it go? Where does it wander? All things are encompassed, yet none can be its refuge. Among the arts of the Dao in antiquity, some were like this. Zhuang Zhou heard of their teachings and delighted in them, expounding with absurd and boundless words, wild and unbounded speech, limitless and unconstrained phrases, at times unrestrained yet never partial, never showing bias in his views.

He saw the world as sunk in turbidity, unfit for solemn discourse, so he used "goblet words" to ramble, "weighty words" as truth, and "parables" to broaden his meaning. Alone he roamed with the spirit of heaven and earth, yet never looked down upon the ten thousand things, never reproached right or wrong, and lived among the common world. Though his writings were intricate and marvelous, they flowed without harm; though his words were uneven and strange, they were profound and worth contemplating. His fullness could not be exhausted. Above, he wandered with the Creator; below, he befriended those beyond death and life, without beginning or end.

In regard to the root, his teachings were vast and expansive, profound and unbridled. In regard to the essence, they may be called well-tempered and supremely attained. Yet in responding to transformation and dissolving things, his principles were inexhaustible, his arrival unchanging. Vague and obscure, their depths remain unfathomed.

Vast and formless—this is nothingness. Ever-changing and constant—this is to take non-unity as unity. Death and life as one—this is to be ignorant of life and death. From this single phrase, one knows that the learning of the Śākya has long been present. "Coextensive with heaven and earth"—this is to be of the same body as heaven and earth. "Moving with the numinous and luminous"—this is to move in harmony with creation. "Where does it go? Where does it wander?"—this is to act without trace. "All things are encompassed"—this is to fully realize the principles of the ten thousand things. "None can be its refuge"—this means that none can know its ultimate destination.

"Absurd and boundless" means distant and unfathomable. "Wild and unbounded" means vast and limitless. "Limitless and unconstrained" means without beginning or end. "At times unrestrained yet never partial"—his teachings were free yet without faction. "Partial" means partisan. "Never showing bias in his views"—his insights were not confined to one aspect. "Bias" means singularity.

He saw the people of the world as foolish and sunk in turbidity, unable to be enlightened by sincere and earnest speech. "Solemn discourse" means dignified and truthful speech.

Spreading and unfolding—this means boundless. "To be true" means to invoke the weight of antiquity, first desiring others to regard it as real. "To be vast" means to lodge meaning in words that are broad and unrestrained. To commune with the spirit of Heaven and Earth, to befriend the natural workings of creation—this is to be a true companion. "Not scorning the ten thousand things" means not using this to scorn the world. Yet Zhuangzi’s intent was precisely to scorn this world, and thus he spoke in such contrary terms.

"Not reproving right and wrong" means that right and wrong are not clung to. Only when there is no right and no wrong can one dwell among the common customs of the age. "Magnificent and grand"—this means lofty and majestic. "Interwoven and harmonious"—this conveys the meaning of blending and merging as one. "No harm"—this means no mockery of others. "Uneven and irregular"—sometimes this, sometimes that; sometimes suppressed, sometimes exalted—it cannot be fixed. "Playful and cunning"—this means witty, slippery, and elusive. These two lines reveal the intent behind his writing: though his words may seem strange and absurd, they are worthy of contemplation. Once these two lines are understood, one can read Zhuangzi.

"That which is replete and cannot be restrained"—this means that within his book, principles fill every space, making it a work the world cannot do without. "Root" means the fundamental teaching. The root and teaching of his book are nothing other than the vast, profound, and harmonious Dao. "Opening wide"—this means expansive. "Unfettered"—this means freely released. "Ascending to fulfillment"—this means it can ascend to the principles of Heaven. Though his words are all of non-action and naturalness, when applied to the world, they respond to transformation and resolve the principles of things—meaning they can civilize customs and clarify principles.

"Its principles are inexhaustible"—this means their use is never depleted. "Not shedding"—this means his words arise from the Dao and do not depart from it. "Vast and obscure"—this describes the profound depth of his book. "Not yet fully expressed"—this means that what he attained in his heart cannot be fully conveyed in words.

From the beginning onward, he distinguishes five teachings and places himself last, following Laozi, explicitly stating that his learning derives from Laozi. The first three sections each begin with "though," all making definitive statements about the validity of his learning. Only Laozi is free of such judgments. Here, he again uses "though," saying his learning is not without use in the world. This is where the text shifts, displaying its highest literary skill—it must be read with great care.

Hui Shi was versatile in many arts; his writings filled five carts. Yet his Dao was contradictory and flawed, and his words did not hit the mark. His "intent in surveying things" states: "That which is supremely great has no outside—this is called the Great One. That which is supremely small has no inside—this is called the Small One. Without thickness, it cannot accumulate, yet its greatness spans a thousand *li*. Heaven and Earth are low; mountains and marshes are level. The sun is just at its zenith yet already slanting; things are just born yet already dying. Great sameness differs from small sameness—this is called the small sameness and difference. The ten thousand things are entirely the same and entirely different—this is called the great sameness and difference."

Mo Di, Song Xing, Peng, Tian, and Shen Dao were all partial in their grasp of the Dao, but Hui Shi merely delighted in debate and thus did not partake in the true arts. His mention in the "Lineage of Those Who Have Heard the Wind" appears only at the end of the chapter. "His writings filled five carts"—this means his books, though numerous, could not be contained even by five carts. Yet despite their volume, his learning was not correct, and his words were not apt, hence the criticism of their contradictions and inaccuracy.

"Intent in surveying things"—this means examining one by one the ideas he discussed regarding things. "Supremely great has no outside"—this refers to the great void. "Supremely small has no inside"—this refers to things like the tip of an autumn hair. These eight characters align with what Zhuangzi said, but by calling them the Great One and Small One, he introduces the beginning of disputation. If one speaks of "the One," there is no great or small; yet within the One, he distinguishes great and small—this is sameness within difference and difference within sameness.

"Without thickness"—this means supremely thin. "Cannot accumulate"—for if it accumulates, it becomes thick. Accumulate without cease, and its greatness can reach a thousand *li*. Thus, he speaks of great and small as the same: the vastness of a thousand *li* is merely the accumulation of that which has no thickness. Though Heaven is high and Earth spread low, when Heaven’s *qi* descends, it too becomes low—hence "Heaven and Earth are low." Though mountains are higher than marshes, the *qi* of marshes can reach mountains, so "mountains and marshes are level."

"Slanting"—this means looking sideways. When the sun is at its zenith, if one looks at it sideways, it is no longer at the center. Thus, "just at its zenith yet already slanting." Things are just born, yet their seeds must have come from what died before—hence "just born yet already dying." To speak of great and small is to speak of small sameness and difference. To unite the ten thousand things in sameness and difference is to speak of great sameness and difference. Though one may call it great, it does not transcend the accumulation of small things; though one may call it small, when combined, it can become great—thus there is neither sameness nor difference.

"The south has no limit yet has a limit. Today I go to Yue, yet I came yesterday. Linked rings can be unlinked. I know the center of the world—it is north of Yan and south of Yue. Embracing all things with universal love—Heaven and Earth are one body." Hui Shi regarded these as grand insights into the world, and those skilled in debate among the world’s debaters delighted in them.

"The south"—this refers to the sea. Though it is boundless, to call it a "direction" implies it must have a limit. This is true of all four directions, but he speaks only of the south not merely to illustrate one and imply the other three, but because Heaven leans to the northwest and the sea lies only in the south, while the other three directions in the north are distant—hence he speaks of it specifically.

"Today I go to Yue, yet I came yesterday"—though my feet have not yet reached Yue, knowing of Yue’s name and having come later, today’s departure can also be called yesterday’s arrival. Two rings linked together cannot be unlinked, yet each ring is itself a circle and cannot adhere to the other. If they do not adhere, they are not truly linked rings.

"Embracing all things with universal love—Heaven and Earth are one body"—this is the teaching of Mo Di. Hui Shi took this as a grand vision of the world, and those skilled in debate among the world’s debaters rejoiced in it.

In the north lies Yan, in the south Yue—neither is the center of the world. Yet the people of Yan know only Yan, and the people of Yue know only Yue. At the world’s beginning, neither knew of the other, each taking their own land as the center of Heaven and Earth.

All things form one body with Heaven and Earth, so though Heaven and Earth are vast, they are but one thing among the ten thousand things. How then can there be great or small? They are of one body.

The grand vision claims this as uniquely lofty above all under Heaven, and thus its doctrine is taught to those who study debate. Once the world’s scholars rejoiced in it together, its influence spread ever wider, giving rise to the following arguments:

Eggs have hair.
A chicken has three feet.
Ying possesses all under Heaven.
A dog can be a sheep.
A horse lays eggs.
A tadpole has a tail.
Fire is not hot.
Mountains speak.
Wheels do not touch the ground.
Eyes do not see.
Fingers do not reach, yet what reaches is not continuous.
A tortoise is longer than a snake.
A carpenter’s square is not square; a compass cannot draw a circle.
A chisel does not fit its socket.
The shadow of a flying bird never moves.
An arrow in flight has a moment of neither motion nor stillness.
A dog is not a hound.
A yellow horse and a black ox make three.

A white dog is black. A solitary colt has never had a mother. A one-foot staff, halved each day, will never be exhausted for ten thousand generations. Debaters used these arguments to engage with Hui Shi, exhausting themselves without end.

Huan Tuan and Gongsun Long, disciples of the debaters, adorned men’s minds and altered their intentions. They could overcome others in speech but could not win over their hearts—such was the confinement of the debaters. Hui Shi daily wielded his knowledge to contend with others, uniquely crafting monstrosities with the world’s debaters; this was his foundation.

Yet Hui Shi, in his oral disputations, deemed himself the most worthy, declaring, “How grand are Heaven and Earth!” Though he maintained a bold stance, he lacked true method.

As for the claim that eggs have hair: though the hair within an egg is not yet visible, the feathers of sparrows and chickens differ. For instance, if a chicken were to brood a duck’s egg, what emerges would bear duck feathers, not chicken feathers—thus, eggs have hair.

A chicken, by nature, has two feet, but there must be something that moves and propels it—hence, three.

That Ying possesses all under Heaven: the capital of Chu was at Ying, where its ruler declared himself king, no different from one who has gained the world.

That a dog can be a sheep: the names “dog” and “sheep” arise from human convention, not from the things themselves. Had the first beings called a dog a sheep, people today would likewise regard it as a sheep; had they called a sheep a dog, people today would regard it as a dog.

That a horse lays eggs: though live birth differs from egg-laying, the terms “womb-born” and “egg-born” are human constructs. If one may call a womb an egg, then the same logic applies to dogs and sheep.

Dingzi refers to the toad or frog; in Chu, it is called *dingzi*. Though the toad has no tail, it begins as a tadpole, which does have a tail—thus, one may say the toad has a tail.

That fire is not hot: heat and cold are also human designations. Moreover, there are fire-dwelling rats and fire-washed cloth. If rats can enter and exit fire, and fire can wash cloth, then it is not hot.

That mountains speak: empty valleys transmit sound; when one calls out, an echo answers—is this not the mountain having a mouth?

That wheels do not touch the ground: when a wheel rolls upon the earth, it is a wheel, but the moment it touches the ground, it cannot turn—thus, one may say wheels do not tread the earth.

That eyes do not see: only after the eye sees can the finger reach. Yet the eye cannot reach what the finger cannot see—thus, what reaches is neither separable from nor continuous with the eye and finger.

That a tortoise is longer than a snake: if a tortoise were as long as a snake, it would no longer be called a tortoise. Since it is called a tortoise, its length is naturally thus—one may also say it is longer than a snake.

That a carpenter’s square is not square, and a compass cannot draw a circle: once called a square, it cannot also be called square; once called a compass, it cannot also be called round.

That a chisel does not fit its socket: though the tenon rests within the mortise, its rotation cannot be restrained by the mortise—thus, one may say it does not fit, or that the fit is imperfect.

That the shadow of a flying bird never moves: once the bird takes flight, the shadow follows it away. One may speak of the bird’s flight, but not of the shadow’s movement.

That an arrow in flight has a moment of neither motion nor stillness: when the arrow is on the bowstring, it is at rest; when it strikes the target, it is in motion. Between leaving the string and reaching the target, there is a moment of neither motion nor stillness.

That a dog is not a hound: dog and hound are the same thing. If called a dog, it cannot be called a hound; if called a hound, it cannot be called a dog—thus, a dog is not a hound.

That a yellow horse and a black ox make three: horse and ox are two bodies; yellow and black are two colors. To speak of two bodies alongside two colors is to make three.

That a yellow horse and a black ox make three: yellow and black are two colors; horse and ox are two bodies. When two colors attach to two bodies, they become three.

That a white dog is black: the names “black” and “white” do not arise from the original nature of things. Thus, one may also call white black.

That a solitary colt has never had a mother: to name it “solitary” is to deny it ever had a mother; one cannot say it is solitary yet once had a mother.

A one-foot staff, broken in half each day: today one uses this half, tomorrow that half. Though divided endlessly, it will never be exhausted for ten thousand generations.

All the above arguments were learned from Master Hui, expanding his doctrines to engage with him. Throughout their lives, they ceaselessly debated—such were Huan Tuan, Gongsun Long, and their ilk.

To adorn men’s minds is to obscure them; to alter their intentions is to confuse them. In a moment’s debate, though one may silence another in speech, the other’s heart remains unconvinced. The debaters, lost in their own labyrinth, do not perceive this—thus, it is called their *enclosure*.

Hui Shi daily wielded his knowledge to contend with others, relying on his cleverness to overpower them in debate. Alone, he and his followers became objects of astonishment—yet this was the extent of his ability, and thus it is called his *foundation*. *Foundation* means root.

He prided himself on his rhetorical skill, deeming his grandeur equal to Heaven and Earth. Though he maintained a bold stance, he was truly devoid of learning and method.

In the south there was a man named Huang Liao who asked why Heaven and Earth do not collapse or sink, and the causes of wind, rain, thunder, and lightning. Hui Shi did not decline but answered without hesitation, discoursing on the myriad things without pause. Though his words were many, he deemed them few and added ever more monstrosities.

He took contrarianism as truth and sought to prevail over others in reputation, which is why he never fit in with the crowd. Weak in virtue yet strong in disputation, his path grew ever more obscure.

Viewing Hui Shi’s abilities through the Dao of Heaven and Earth, he was no more than a mosquito or gadfly’s labor—what use was he to the world? To fill one vessel is possible; to exalt the Dao further is near perfection. Yet Hui Shi could not find peace in this. Scattered among the myriad things, never satisfied, he ultimately gained fame as a master of debate.

Alas for Hui Shi’s talent—so unbounded yet unfulfilled, chasing the myriad things without return! He exhausted echoes for sound, while form and shadow raced in vain. How lamentable!

Those who lean upon others are men of strange divergence. In the south there was a solitary lofty man named Huang Liao, who questioned Hui Shi: “Why does Heaven not fall? Why does Earth not sink? Who truly brings forth wind, rain, thunder, and lightning?” These are the marvels of Creation—how could words contain them? Yet Hui Shi did not decline but answered without hesitation, responding without deliberation, discoursing on the ten thousand things in endless variety. The myriad things are manifold indeed. Though his words were many, he deemed them few and added ever more monstrosities. Taking contrarianism as truth, he sought to prevail over others through eloquence, crafting a reputation for himself—thus he never harmonized with the world. *Not fitting* means not finding accord. Within, he had no true attainment, hence “weak in virtue.” Outwardly, he forced disputation, hence “strong in things.” *Ào* means dark and secluded; his path was neither bright nor upright but obscure and crooked.

Viewing Hui Shi’s abilities through the Dao of Heaven and Earth, he was no more than a mosquito or gadfly’s labor. What use was he to the world of men? To fill one vessel is possible; to deem this superior to exalting the Dao is perilous. *Yù* means to surpass; *jī* means peril. Unable to find peace within himself, he scattered his efforts among the myriad things, never satisfied, ultimately knowing not the Dao but gaining fame as a master of debate. *Zú* means in the end.

Hui Shi was indeed a man of talent, yet his dissipation brought no attainment, and his pursuit of externals left him without return—how regrettable! *Dài* means dissipation. Echo arises from sound, sound being the root and echo the branch; to exhaust echoes for sound is to forget the root. Shadow arises from form, form being the root and shadow the branch; to seek rest for the shadow without stopping the form is to race with it—another parable of forgetting the root.

This concludes the *Zhuangzi*, ending with Hui Shi. Though he did not stand among those who grasped the Dao, his words as a debater were ever turning nothing into something, and his speech was indeed extraordinary—thus he fittingly closes this chapter. For though this work differs from composition, it too has its own structure, with deliberate openings and endings. Like the *Spring and Autumn Annals*’ final brushstroke at the capture of the qilin, or the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s “Heaven’s charge is soundless, scentless,” this book’s Inner Chapters—with “Hundun’s seven orifices”—all follow a single pattern, which must not be overlooked.

Those who explain the classics in terms of literary technique may not grasp the principle; those who grasp the principle may overlook the literary art. Thus their readings lack vitality, and their interpretations lack savor. Only Master Aixuan, whose Dao was lofty and whose prose was exquisitely refined, gave the Six Classics an interpretation that stands apart through the ages. Alas, after Wangshan and Lexuan, his learning was not transmitted, and no one today knows of it.

*End of the Thirty-Second Scroll of the Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*

Here follows the translation of *Postscript to the Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*:
