The *Book of Southern Florescence* is a marvel of brushwork across past and present. Yet those who revere it may drift into hollow emptiness, while those who mock it may doubt its strangeness and extravagance. Though its literary brilliance cannot be erased, its annotations have long remained obscure, a lasting burden upon the text.

In my youth, I served Master Chen Lexuan, hearing fragments of his discourse. I came to admire the text but could not fully grasp its passages. Later, I traveled and studied with Zhuxi, often taking it up to read together. I delighted in its lucid dissections, though its divergences from common understanding were many. The more I read, the deeper my admiration grew.

After passing the imperial examinations and returning south, I lived in leisure for a long while. I devoted myself to the study of the classics, and with this book, the more I read, the more I loved it—and the more I doubted it. For this book is difficult to comprehend: its words often differ from our own, its arguments sometimes contradict the ancient sages, and its purport resists inquiry—like grasping at shadows in midair or seizing a horned dragon with bare hands. Its unifying principle eludes certainty, like tracing the three rivers to their hidden tributaries or following the nine streams to their lost courses.

Each time I opened the scroll, I could not help but leap with joy, nor could I avoid sinking into confusion. In the year *wuwu*, I visited Zhuxi by the stream, and in conversation, he suddenly said to me: "I once wished to cleanse Master Nanhua’s old immortal of Guo Xiang’s vulgarities, but with each meal and every shift of circumstance, I never found the time to shut my door and write. Since misfortune and setbacks have forced me into retirement, I have turned to this work to ease my cares and amuse my old age. Now, at last, the book is complete."

Overjoyed, I sought it out. Upon returning, I read it eagerly and saw how it divided and analyzed, branched and dissected, with no empty phrases in its chapters, no superfluous words in its lines. It unfolded with boundless freedom, stirring and transforming like a dance without end. Yet every word and phrase had its place, as if waking from a dream to find clarity, or being freed from bonds to gain release.

Only then did I understand that this book stands as a school unto itself, unbound by conventional meanings. Though it roams the profound and obscure, it does not neglect worldly affairs. It does not fail to recognize the worth of sages and worthies but disdains mere conformity. It does not ignore the excesses of cunning and deceit but champions defiance of the vulgar. Whether in ancient or modern times, those who recite it may differ, but all have merely glimpsed its fence without reaching its inner sanctum.

Since assuming my post in this humble district, though official documents pile high and my days are constrained, in the quiet of early dawn before the clerks assemble, I must light a lamp and chant its verses—sometimes finishing a single chapter, sometimes an entire scroll—dancing with hands and feet, as if meeting the author in person.

Thus I declare: the *Book of Southern Florescence* is indispensable to this world, and Zhuxi’s exegesis is indispensable to *Southern Florescence*. For Zhuxi’s learning derives from Lexuan, Lexuan’s from Wangshan, and Wangshan’s from old Master Aixuan, transmitted through three generations without deviation. Zhuxi not only mastered his teacher’s transmission but also scoured the Buddhist and Daoist texts beyond the Six Classics, the Masters, and the Histories. Thus he was able to fathom the hidden subtleties of this old master and exhaust his ingenious insights. If *Southern Florescence* were to return to life, he would surely be its confidant.

Now, those who read this book may do so without regret. Though our district is remote, my devotion to it runs deep, and I wished to spread its transmission. By economizing on furs and provisions, I have fortunately brought the project to completion. Here I record why I love it, how I came to understand it, and the joy it has brought me.

Zhuxi of the Lin family, styled Suweng, once held office as a literary official. Now he serves as *Baomo* Director of the Jade Bureau Abbey. *Yanzhai* is the name of his study. His prose often resembles that of Zhuangzi. This book is titled *Oral Exegesis* because it does not strive for literary polish but freely mixes the colloquial with direct exposition.

In the first year of the Jingding era, during the Zhonghe Festival, Lin Jingde, *Xuanjiao Lang* and Magistrate of Jianning County in Shaowu Prefecture, composed this preface.

Zhuangzi’s prose soars with heroic grandeur, traversing all things in spirit and roaming beyond the cosmos in mind—his joy and insight unmatched by any in antiquity. His words surge and transform, eclipsing sun and moon, cleaving through clouds and rivers, at once subtle and flowing, resplendent as scales and feathers, vast as heaven and sea. Though lavish, they never entangle; though bold, they never overreach—truly the most towering literary achievement under heaven.

Yanzhai’s exegesis of this work is like the soaking immersion of rivers and seas, the nourishing moisture of fertile rains. He enters Zhuangzi’s emotions as his own, follows his thoughts as his own, dreams his dreams and awakens to his awakenings. Thus, he speaks Zhuangzi’s words and points to his pointers, bringing forth voice, laughter, and presence as if in person—so that readers encounter him face to face. How could this be achieved by mere luck or effort?

Yanzhai’s learning is profound, his discernment peerless; his roots run deep, his practice refined. In the realm of his awakening, no height is too lofty to brush against; in stillness and depth, his insight ascends effortlessly. I observe Yanzhai: his bearing is noble, his form and function harmonious with heaven and earth, his spirit full and luminous, stretching forth with self-assured majesty—is he not like the *kun* and *peng*? Yet he has also steeped himself in this text, and who but Yanzhai could grasp its words as he does?

Now, Yanzhai’s work stands resolute, reviving Zhuangzi from dry bones and unlocking a treasure trove of millennia. Is Yanzhai not himself a figure of great magnanimity, a heroic and towering scholar? When I first obtained this text, I read it with astonishment, recording my marvel at the end to pass down to my descendants—not that I dare claim to fully comprehend Yanzhai’s exegesis.

When the Old Immortal of Qiyuan composed this work, his vision of the Dao was precise, his indignation at the world keen. Only his reclusive and untrammeled ways allowed him to express it, and only his extraordinary vigor allowed him to unfold it—venturing into boundless obscurity, stirring transformations beyond measure. One may trust the reach of his eye and the force of his brush. Yet he did not know when he overstepped, when he verged on the extravagant. Did he ever intend, at the outset, to leave this for posterity or establish a teaching? Or to exalt Laozi while suppressing the Confucians? Why, then, do readers fail to perceive this? Some dismiss it as mere "emptiness and nothingness," others condemn it as "heterodoxy." They see its transcendent vision, hear its world-shaking words, yet often stumble over incomplete sentences or unclear characters, resorting to doubt, omission, or excuses. Did Zhuangzi ever wish for such treatment from later generations?

Master Yanzhai of the Jade Bureau, Lord Lin, received the Dao of the Sage from Lexuan. Lexuan’s relation to Zhuangzi is like that of Ziyun to later ages; Yanzhai’s to Lexuan, like Houba to the *Great Mystery*. Thus, he emerged to compose this work—organizing its chapters, parsing its sentences, clarifying its characters—so that no chapter lacks explanation, no sentence lacks resolution, no character lacks illumination. What was once empty is now solid, what was divergent now unified, what was doubtful now certain, what was fragmented now complete. Only after thousands of years does the *Nanhua Jing* become a whole book in the world. Not only will the Old Immortal leap for joy above the ninefold heavens, but Lexuan, too, will surely dance with hands and feet between the seen and unseen.

Some ask: If one applies philological scholarship to a text on life and destiny—like Master Zhu’s "culmination of all learning," which offers exegesis from the *Book of Changes* to the *Songs of Chu*, yet leaves Zhuangzi’s work untouched—is this not a flaw? I reply: Does not Han Yu’s saying hold—"from the ancient *Ya* and *Song* to Zhuangzi and Qu Yuan"? And did not Master Zhu himself say, "The scholars of the Jin and Song did not fully grasp Zhuangzi’s truth"? If not, is there still more to uncover, or was this left for a reason yet to come? Yanzhai’s achievement may well stand no lower than Master Zhu’s.

I fear that later scholars, forgetting past difficulties and delighting in present ease, may grow complacent. Thus, I reiterate these words.
